description: The food is amazing. The smells coming from the kitchen when we entered were intoxicating. The restaurant is simple in design, clean, warm and homy. The staff is super friendly. Loved the Ethiopian beer, St. John. We'll definitely be back!
author: Marissa T.

description:
I've been on an Ethiopian roll lately, and it's probably because I've been on a vegan kick and so much of Ethiopian cuisine veers in that direction. Now Eritrean cuisine is technically not Ethiopian as they are neighboring countries, but to this ethnically challenged, Bourdain wannabe layman, they appear to be pretty close in flavor and execution. It all starts with the injera, the spongey, sourdough-risen flatbread which is usually both rolled up in a basket and serves as an edible platter for all the goodies on top of it (photo: http://bit.ly/2pwuVrk). I happened upon this spot on Geary after a Kaiser appointment one evening last week.

It was pretty empty at around 8PM with just one young couple at a table next to the window. The host let me sit anywhere, so I helped myself to a large table near the takeout window. There were quite a few temptations in the menu both carnivorous and vegetarian. I indulged a bit and ordered the $14.95 Vegetarian Sampler. It was quite an extravaganza with eight different items on the large sheet of injera (photo: http://bit.ly/2pxZwon). There was the Vegetable Alicia, a combination of potatoes, carrots, bell peppers, and cabbage lightly seasoned. Then there was both okra and zucchini in tomato sauce.

They also added Shiro, ground chickpeas cooked with onions and tomatoes; Bersin, which were mildly seasoned lentils; and stewed spinach and collard greens. A small dollop of yogurt and a small salad of lettuce and tomatoes completed the set, which turned out to be generous since the menu lists only three items in the sampler. Delicious and hearty with plenty of variety. No fork please as it requires tearing into the injera to scoop up the goodness. Had I known I was getting that much food, perhaps I wouldn't have ordered the $2.75 bowl of Lentil Soup, which again was a generous serving and also quite warming and filling (photo: http://bit.ly/2G0jsKY). Ah, so this is Eritrean food.

FOOD - 4 stars...quite a potpourri of Eritrean delights on that addicting injera
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...simple, sparse and a bit dark
SERVICE - 4 stars...a very attentive host
TOTAL - 4 stars...now I know what Eritrean cuisine is
author: Ed U.

description: This place is fantastic! The food is so great. It's clean and well lit. The staff is friendly. The beer and wine are good. Try the Ethiopian beer. We got the meat sampler and the vegetarian sampler and it was a feast. I'm looking forward to our next visit.
author: Charles T.

description: Had a really great dinner here.  After taking our guests to The Japanese Tea Garden and then on a Red and White Fleet boat ride around the bay, we capped off our day with a dinner here at Assam.  The service was nice and friendly.  We were very hungry, so I ordered a LOT...  a veggie combo plus three extra veggie dishes.  I loved the okra one and the mushrooms were heavenly spicy... gotta love that berbere spice!  The injera was dark and tangy.  We got more, but then ended up with some left over.  Everyone ate and ate until they could eat no more.  It was a feast.  While we were there, the restaurant filled up until every seat was taken.  Nice to see a family restaurant with a loyal following.  There seemed to be a good deal of first dates there!  Those daters get points for creativity!  Bottom line, an excellent restaurant with lots (and I do mean lots) of good food!
author: Kelly B.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE

I've had several other Ethiopian foods and have kept bouncing around searching for quality.

I found this place a month ago and have been there once a week since. 
Food is delicious, of better quality than most. The injera is delicious! Great flavors! Great service! The waiter is such a charmer too.
Great job Assab! You guys rock! 

I've been bringing my friends here too, and the food is consistent. Really, never a disappointment.
author: Eli B.

description: I've been here for dinner twice. I really like this place. Friendly service, and delicious food. I also appreciated that both times I've been here, there are people here, but there isn't a wait for food. The meals are affordable. This is a perfect spot for vegetarians, as the veggie items are flavorful and delicious. I'm a dipper. I love to dip bread into saucy and soupy things. So if you are a dipper, this place is for you. One thing to note: I like spicy food. If you are averse to spicy food, you may want to consult with your server to see what might be right for you. Ask your doctor if spicy food is right for you.
author: Jason P.

description: We had a wonderful dinner experience here and will be back soon! Deliciously flavorful and authentic food.  Warm and welcoming owners who take pride in delivering excellent Eritrean food, which is very similar to Ethiopian food.  Feels like a rare find in San Francisco.
author: Jessica W.

description: Went here for a friend's going away party and had a delightful time. We ordered a few veggie samplers and a few meat samplers and everything was very flavorful and filling. The wait staff was VERY friendly and awesome too. I'll definitely be bringing more friends back to Assab
author: Jason P.

description:
I was fed injera once at a potluck when I was six and spent many years trying to figure out the name of that fluffy bread I fell in love with. It wasn't until a decade later that I learned my neighbor who moved away had successfully gotten me hooked onto Eritrean cuisine. 

Eritrean cuisine is very flavorful, stew heavy, and filling. You eat with your hands and you damn well will enjoy doing so. Anyways, Assab is located on Geary so the trusty 38 will drop you off right in front of the place. Easy to make a reservation or if it's during the week and you're a smaller group, you might just get lucky and be able to walk in.

Items ordered-

Veg. Sambusa
Meat Sambusa
Kelwa Derho
Zucchini
Spinach

Surprisingly I enjoyed the meat sambusa over the vegetable, although both were delicious. The other half of the table ordered the beef and really enjoyed it whereas we opted for more vegetables and the chicken. Loved the kelwa derho! That was definitely the first item gone from the plate. The zucchini and spinach were both good, if I had to rate one over the other, then the spinach would be the winner.

The waiter was sad that we couldn't finish all the food, but alas, guess our eyes were bigger than our stomachs. Definitely bring a group and come in to Assab!
author: Arezou A.

description:
Just want to share my experience in this place, Since i have time now to post.
It feels like in Ethiopian County when you were there. Food was good and delicious I suggest you guys to bring your friends when you got there. Staff were also nice and friendly.
author: Joseph R.

description:
Really great find in my neighborhood! Delicious food, friendly service, and fair value. I must admit it's the only Ethiopian restaurant I've ever been to...
I really enjoy eating here because the flavors are unique and it can be light enough that I don't feel gross after which is a huge bonus.
One time I took someone who had a lot of Ethiopian food growing up and it got her stamp of approval.
author: Emma B.

description:
i've had my eye on this place for a while and am so glad we finally stopped in. we asked the owner what we should order for the entree, which was a good decision. the service was excellent and they definitely made us feel at home. we got:

one veggie sambusa
one meat sambusa

#3 zigni (beef, spicy!) - yuuuum. served with yogurt to balance the spice
#18 veggie sampler - loved this! perfect addition with the zigni. super glad we got to try a variety of the veggies offered 

i was so full at the end and we had a good amount of inerja left over. the owner suggested taking it home (he said it is the best part!). i ate it the next day with an egg on top. yuuuuum.

i heard some other tables talking about how good the lentil soup is, so i'll have to try that the next time i stop by.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Always welcoming, always satisfying, always delicious.

I suggest the spicy chicken and the lamb dish (currently # 5 and 8). Apologies, we have been going for years and always order these two, because they are amazing. We also love the sambusas as a starter when we are super hungry, and we always order a bottle of Tej(honey wine).
author: A R- T.

description: I hate to say anything negative about any Ethiopian restaurant as it's my favorite and I want to promote it. But... We were not impressed tonight. Three of us ordered the vegetarian platter, our usual for never-fail awesome take out dinner. The second we opened our food, everything looked almost identical and smelled like ketchup. Both not a good sign. It was hard to tell each item apart by taste. The only two that were different were the (bitter) greens and carrots/potatoes. The veggies in some of the other dishes were greasy/slippery, not the feeling you want. The injera was light and spongy, I ended up dipping it in the yogurt and eating it up, ignoring everything else. I'd be willing to try some other things, hopefully won't taste like it was only seasoned with ketchup.
author: Melanie F.

description: Good African food here.  The spices weren't quite as vivid as other Ethiopian type places I've been but the service was good and I Enjoyed the meal well enough.
author: Darius J.

description: Great Ethiopian food. So many different flavors, but like usual, the lentils are the best.
author: Max P.

description: Our favorite East African spot, just a real gem. We typically get the vegetarian and meat sampler and are satisfied every time. The lamb and chicken dishes are excellent. It's a great place to eat with friends as the food is typicall shared. Can be spicy but there are non-spicy options as well. Service and the family running it are great. Highly recommend giving this place a try!
author: Jason P.

description: Best Eritrean food in the city! Good portions, good prices. Be warned, unlike some of the other Ethiopian restaurants where everything is ala carte, at Assab each entree comes with 3 sides so don't order too much! Also, don't miss the honey wine! Perfect way to dull the heat if you order it too spicy! Best food, nicest staff! Definitely one of my top 10 restaurants in the Bay area!
author: Amy L.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! and the owner is so nice! We ordered the vegetarian Sampler and the mushroom order- the foods were so scrumptious, we scarfed down the entrees in less than 15 min!
author: L. w.

description: I crave the vegetarian combo from here all the time, even though I'm not vegetarian. It's better than every other Ethiopian restaurant I've tried in the city. I also like that their injera is not too sour. My only gripe is the ambiance, they will have the tv on full volume with the music playing at the same time, its pretty annoying but the food and the friendly service keeps me coming back.
author: Kristina P.

description: When I entered the place I could smell Curry and ambience didn't look great. I had the veggie and the meat platter, and I had a veggie appetizer I don't remember the name of, it just tastes like samosa . I did like the food but ambience is laid back.
author: Reshma R.

description: Loved the place. First time trying this cuisine. Great and unique flavors. Definitely need to go again.
author: Jaime O.

description:
It was my first time of African Food. It is good! spicy, but good.

it is so different compared to any other food in SF. 

I tried veggie and meat sambusa which were amazing! 
then the meat platter ($16.95) for two. good value, alot of food, all in all it is worth the burning sensation in my throat after eating it.

the owner is very friendly too!

love it, will come back.
author: Kallista P.

description:
It's pricey, but everything is good. Service, beverages (get the tea; it's amazing), the food, the waiters, the timeliness...the fact you never have to make reservations or wait...

This place is local to me and it's one of my favorite local places. Get one of the combos and you can try a bunch of different dishes. You'll leave stuffed or with leftovers. Get extra Injera to make full use of all the food they bring, and ///make sure to order it served family style/// for the full, food-on-injera experience. 

If I had to describe it, the flavors are just a bit more influenced by Indian/middle eastern than your average Ethiopian. Makes sense to me...Eritrea borders Ethiopia and the red sea...where they'd have more contact with India and the middle east? Just a guess. 

Anyway, super good food, a bit pricey, but I love to go there as much as I can.
author: Chris S.

description:
Assab Eritrean Restaurant was our first try at African cuisine and it was great! 

First of all the portions are huge!!! like ridiculously huge! We ordered one vegetarian and one meat combo (not family style) and the plate was so big! Everything tastes really good. I love their pita, it's sour and super tasty! 

We also one vegetable and one meat sambusa! crunchy and tasty they were the perfect start to a delicious meal.

It's messy food, and the best way to eat it is the ditch the utensils and just use pita to scoop the food!

The service is kinda slow during rush hour but it's well worth it!
author: Tamara S.

description:
Thanks to a friend I took my first dive into African food at Assab. I can comfortably say this is probably one of the most pleasing ways to have a meal with a friend or better yet four. In a world of germaphobes having a place to eat with your hands is such a nice change. Frankly if I could do it every day without being frowned upon I would. 

The restaurant is small but roomy. It was quiet that night but only because of the rain that came down. When we arrived we were the first customers of the night. The couple who runs the place took turns serving us and were so attentive to our needs. I felt like I was being cared for by my own parents. The menu is pretty straight forward. Order and item or two and share away on a giant plate of Injera bread (think doughy pancake with a sourdough flavor) topped with whatever you ordered. This time we went with the lamb and the beef (Kitfo). Kitfo as I was told is probably their most popular dish and I immediately tasted why. Along with our meals we had honey wine and some hot tea. 

After the meal we were absolutely full but it was a comfortable full. The only thing that would have made the night better was if they had a couch and a fireplace where we could relax and hang out with the owners a bit more. I look forward to making this a regular stop in my eating rotation. If you haven't tried Eritrean or anything like it stop into Assab and they'll make you feel right at home.
author: Joco F.

description:
Lucky to find this authentic Eritrean restaurant open late, with aromatic hot tea and good food that were just right for a cool, rainy night. 
   Food 3-4 /5  Food was served family-style on a large injera bread, at the request of our group. When one person requested less spicy versions of the food choices, the restaurant made sure the colorful wheel of food had those portions separate. There were several choices for combination plates. At first the hot tea may look like plain black tea, but the restaurant adds spices to the hot water before adding the tea bag, so the result is aromatic and nice. 
    Service 4/5. Servers were pleasant and efficient.  
One of the managers stopped to talk and make sure our food was ok. 
    Facility 3/5. Small but clean. Not too noisy. Mostly small tables. 
    Location 2/5.  On-street parking only, so u may have to walk a couple of blocks, but this is common in SF. In a pretty stable part of town. 
Prices : Average (see menu photo)
author: Jay S.

description: My husband, kids and I ate here tonight and it was dynamite. One of the first things that impressed me is how clean everything is, despite the tired looking exterior. But the food pleased our entire crew, even the 10 year old who refuses to eat vegetables and chicken. We ordered double of their vegetable sampler along with the chicken breast dish. Every bite was delicious. Both kids said if I made lentils that tasted like that, they'd eat them. We practically licked the dish clean. I just wish we'd come here sooner. We'll be back!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Eritrean cuisine is amazing and this restaurant is amazing.

It is small, the people who run it are nice, and the food is delicious. The quality, quantity, and the price are all worth noting and more than enough reason to keep coming back around.

Plus, the host seemed to enjoy how happy I was just eating the food (quietly, by myself, smiling the whole time as I stuffed myself) and I think you can tell a lot about people who enjoy you enjoying their food.
author: Duran S.

description: This is a very pleasant and well priced neighborhood restaurant, that offers good quality and unusual food. When I come with a friend, we usually order a meat combo and a vegetarian combo, so as to get a good cross-section of the available dishes. I also enjoy the honey wine.
author: Jethro B.

description: We were looking for something different with 2 other couples in town - this was perfect ... unique food experience and super tasty too. Great way to converse with old and new friends as you can share everything- and use your hands too!   Very fun!
author: Matt D.

description:
I've been a few times now, and their food is pretty decent. 
The kitfo (my favorite dish in Ethiopian cuisine) is decent, the kelwa was a bit too salty. 
The man (owner perhaps?) passes out additional injera before you run out, without you having to ask. 
Hospitable staff, they stay on top of things and really treat you as a guest, not just a customer.
author: Mima G.

description: Limited hours, so check before you go. I always get the kitfo, so I can't speak for much else, but it's pretty good. The man and woman who run the place are very friendly.
author: Owen S.

description: Ww really  like this place, the food was very good and my and our kids love it! well my wife been habesha can taste the difference! so every time we are at SF we will visit this Restaurant!
author: Sebastian R.

description:
Ethiopian food is one of those love it or hate it food genre due to the spongy bread called injera.  It's semi sour taste and lukewarm temperature doesn't contribute much to everyone's sensitive taste buds.  For me, I'm a big fan of it either but I'm a big fan of the social experience eating with our hands with our trusted friends.  To be honest, you'll more likely to remember the experience and the spicy (or non-spicy) items on top of the injera than the actual taste of injera unless you're eating the injera straight up without any toppings.

To plan your next visit, bring only your cleanest friends or coworkers.  You wouldn't want to bring a coworker that doesn't wash their hands when they use the bathroom.  Second, decide on the toppings.  The meat and veggie platters are a great way to taste the various different toppings.  I'll also recommend the mushroom one on the veggie section since it really complements all of the meats and lentils you will eat.  Third, order either the Ethiopian beer or the sweet honey wine to complete the experience.
author: Ronald L.

description: Pretty good veg sampler, lamb was very game-y though. The restaurant was almost empty unfortunately.
author: Martina W.

description:
This may not be everybody's idea of a 5-star dining experience, but the food is absolutely delicious.  Usually when I go it's on impulse - a sudden craving for which there is no other satisfaction.  It's head and shoulders above any other Eritrean or Ethiopian food you find in SF, and they hit it perfectly every time.

The service is friendly and attentive.  I've seen people here complaining about the slow service... yes, the food does take a while to arrive but the service is hardly to blame for that.  This is why restaurants give you bread or some other snack to hold you over and at Assab they should give that some thought.  The ambiance is nothing to write home about - I think the ad would say "clean and well-lit" and that's about it.  Aside from the decor, an easy improvement would be some hot towels for desert.  You do eat with your hands after all.

You can't go wrong wth any of the entrees, really.  My faves would be the ground beef (#2) served rare, and the lamb cubes (#7) but the veggie dishes are damn good too, especially the mushrooms.  And don't miss out on the sambusas for appetizers or the African beers.  I wouldn't bother with the honey wine, even though it may sound like a fun, exotic addition.
author: Oscar C.

description:
The hubby and I spent the day with my cousin and his wife at Angel Island and I had mentioned that I had never eaten Ethiopian/Eritrean food, but had been wanting to try it for some time.  My cousin's wife said, "we could have that for dinner", which is why we ended up eating at Assab.

I didn't know what to expect, but my cousins warned that you'll be eating with your hands.  I was a bit weary as I'm a germaphobe, but since I was going with my cousins, I was fine.  So, if you plan to eat here, make sure you eat here with people you know that are clean. 

They said we had to try the honey wine as it's different.  Indeed it was!  You can definitely taste the alcohol at first sip, but get the honey taste after.  I liked that it wasn't overly sweet.

For food we ordered:

Meat Combination (sampler of zigni, tsebhi derho, & alicha beggee. served with dollop of yogurt) 

Vegetable Combination (sampler of veg, alicha, okra & zucchini. served with dollop of yogurt )

The meat and vegetable combination came in a large tray with injera layered beneath the two combinations.  We also ordered four additional injera's.  The way to eat is you tear the injera into pieces and dip it into the stews.  The injera is quite interesting as it's a bit sour tasting.  It reminded me of a crumpet with all the little holes, but a lot thinner.  Injera is a flatbread made from teff, wheat, or sorghum.  

The meat combination came with beef, chicken, and lamb.  I'm not sure how the beef and lamb tasted as I don't eat either.  However, the chicken was delicious. It was a skinless drumstick simmered with clarified butter, onions, tomatoes and seasoned hot pepper.  It had good heat.  

The vegetable combination came with medium-mildly seasoned, potatoes, carrots, bell peppers, okra, & zucchini.  It was very tasty.  

I came in not knowing what to expect, but my stomach left happy!  Everything I ate was super tasty and delicious!  I would definitely return!

Assab is great for groups as you can order a variety of dishes to share.
author: Candice H.

description: This place is good! I had the veggie combo and the flavors worked very well together. The waiter was really sweet. He was the only one working there but he was patient and friendly. I would highly recommend! The veggie platter is enough for 2 people
author: Debbie T.

description:
Try everything!
Went with a vegetarian and a group of non vegetarians. Having one vegetarian platter separate from the other platter was no problem at all. Beautiful plate of food! The food was also nicely spaced out so everyone could reach the smaller side dishes. I can't really remember what we had. Just go and order things. The raw beef was ok, but not that flavorful, I'd rather have raw beef at a Korean restaurant. 
If you haven't been before then do eat with the bread. If I go back I'll probably use a fork. That bread is filling!
author: Heather F.

description: Ordered the Kelwa and Kelwadero and the Veggie Alicha. Came in one gigantic plate. Well worth it. Three of us were full at the end.
author: Randy L.

description:
My review is 4.5. They lose half a star because the wait was ridiculous and I was ready to go anywhere else so I wouldn't die of starvation. The restaurant is small, so there is no waiting area. Standing for over an hour is killer, especially as you're staring at everyone while they eat and hoping they hurry up!

I'm glad we didn't leave. This was my second time having Ethiopian food, and this place was delicious! We tried the chicken, beef, and okra, and all were seasoned just right. They are limited in the amount of injera they give you. It's about $2 to get another couple of rolls which isn't bad, but it's almost a guarantee you'll need more than what they give you. Again, not only was the wait time to be seated a very long time, but the wait time for the food was also very long. BUT, the service was incredible and every bit, amazing. So that made up for all the waiting. But bring a snack in case you have to wait though, seriously.
author: Karen G.

description:
This is my new favorite Eritrean or Ethiopian restaurant in San Francisco. It is not as good as Zoma in Manhattan, which is my favorite in the country as of right now, but it is the best in the West for now.

Every single dish was freshly made and came out piping hot. The injera was excellent as was the honey wine. The portions huge and more than enough for two. We split a vegetarian and meat combination. The beef and chicken were outstanding but the collard greens and lentils were even better.

The service was personal and you felt like you were dining with the owners rather than being served. It was fun to watch a young couple come in and have  the guy on the date try to explain the food to his girl. Everyone seemed to walk away with a smile. 

The spice was perfect and I look forward to dining here many times in the future.
author: Michael R.

description:
I definitely recommend reservations. If you get here and the tables are full, there is no sitting area or bar to pass the time while you wait and you will be stuck standing awkwardly in the doorway. The wait however is worth it. 

All the food we had was full of diverse flavors and plentiful (you will most likely have leftovers) but mild enough even for those not a fan of spice. If you prefer spicier food, you may want to have them turn up the heat a bit. The meat sampler and honey wine combination was a winner, but the Kifto came out a little dry. Slightly more expensive than the average Ethiopian place in the city but dramatically better.
author: Lisa F.

description: This restaurant is delicious and a great place to go with friends. They are very accommodating of groups. If you are coming with a large group it is nice to make a reservation but I have always been able to get a seat with or without one. The food and service keep me coming back.
author: Chelsea M.

description: Let's just say that the service was impeccable and the food was serviceable. I LOVE African cuisine. This place had the least seasoning of any Eritrean restaurant I have ever been too. I ordered my food extra spicy - oh well, that didn't happen. They didn't have the spicy shaker of yummy seasonings available and salt did little to help the situation, but would have improved the lentils vastly had they been cooked with salt added.
author: Mush S.

description: I've been going to Assab since 2004 when it first opened, and words can't express how wonderful this restaurant is. The owner will take your order, and his wife will be in the back meticulously cooking authentic Eritrean cuisine. I've tried every dish and love them all. The food, the service, the flavored teas-- you won't be disappointed.
author: C Y.

description:
Food was ok.

The guy in waiting staff was rude. When I asked a question on the menu, he didnt say anything. He just pointed his finger on the menu and looked back at me without saying a word. 

I will not go there again.
author: Brijesh C.

description:
I would rate the flavor of the food as a 5, the healthiness as a 3, and the service as a 3.5
I am not an expert on Eritrian food by any means but I can say that this restaurant was the most delishious out of 3 restaurants I've ever sampled. I really like the flexibility, pouroseness, and tenderness of the traditional flatbread. 

The dishes are quite mouthwatering and hearty. The owners use clarified butter to cook up the goodness. If you do not typically consume a lot of oily foods, be prepared for some strange stomach noises to follow your dining experience. My bf and I were serenated by our singing tummies for hours. 

The restaurant is very small but cozy. We were one of about 4 parties there on a Monday evening. Despite the rather laid back atmoshpere, the service was not very attentive but still pleasant enough. 

All in all, I definitely enjoyed my meal and will probably bring my adventurous friends and family to try it as well.
author: Nina M.

description: Called in a take-out order and food was promptly ready within 15 minutes during dinner time. Everything was nicely packaged with a ton of injera to go with your dishes. Loved everything we ordered, would highly recommend.
author: Ricky S.

description:
Passing by this restaurant many times and smelling that wonderful aroma of delicous food, i knew i definitely had to try this place!

Went on a friday night, the place was not busy. the instant you walk in, you are greeted with the smell of spices and herbs that have been slowly cooking in their kitchen. The place feels like you're in the middle of the African Plains with their decor and wall paintings. Hehe.. 

We ordered the Meat sampler and the Vegetable combo. Waiter asked if we wanted "Family Style" and we said YES! Basically, family style they combine all the food in one BIG ROUND PLATE! Yes i said BIG! It was only 2 of us and we couldnt finish the whole plate. Along with your order of entrees they give you soft spongy bread to eat with the food. The food was AMAZING~~~~!! The beef was so tender, the chicken too and they were all delicately seasoned with spice and herbs and not tooo salty or too spicy. everything was right as i have imagined it to be. nothing felt over greasy. 

Will definitely come here again soon, anytime i am craving for some good ethnic food!! Come here hungry, you leave satisfied!!!
author: Steve S.

description:
So I am a bit of a novice to Eritrean food. One of my friends mentioned this place was near his house, so I decided hey why not try something new.  We ordered the Zigni (beef) and the Kelwa Derho (chicken) to share.  The servings are big and it just makes sense to eat family style.  Both dishes were well seasoned (I asked for spicy, but you can choose your spice level).  Having to eat with your hands and the dish being fairly saucy, it was a mess, luckily they are generous with the napkins!  But the food was delicious, and the server (I suspect he may be the owner as well) was awesome and attentive.  Gave us recommendations, which turned out to be great.  I also tried the honey wine which I highly recommend.  It was a very different taste for a wine, but I enjoyed it and am now on the hunt for a bottle (go figure). 

All in all food was really good, service was great, and bonus easy to find parking in the neighborhood.  I will definitely be back!
author: Trenicia W.

description:
This is a quaint, "mom and pop" type restaurant which is just delightful.  The food is full of flavor, very reasonably priced, and just delicious.  No frills at this restaurant, but that's not an issue for me.  This is just a great, local restaurant that is true to what it claims to be - genuine Eritrean food.

The man and woman who work here, I assume, are the owners.  They have a very gentle, polite demeanor and are warm and welcoming (I disagree with one of the previous reviews that states that they aren't.  Maybe it was a bad night).  I am very happy to offer a 5 star review for this place, and I hope to return many times again in the future.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I'll base this review on the first time I went here which was just... magical. Now, SF has its share of wonderful hole-in-the-walls... and Assab, to me, is one of those places where a hole-in-the-wall spot can be equally satisfying to a gourmet establishment. It is minimally decorated, but it's the food I want!! 

We ordered the zigni, kelwa, kelwa mix, lentils, okra, kantisha, and gored-gored. That was admittedly too much for three people, but everything sounded so delicious. AND IT WAS. ALL OF THEM WERE. Now, I've done this before -- a rookie mistake -- and eat so much of the injera before we eat the sopped-up injera infused with all the flavors on what's on top... that I leave no room at the end to enjoy that part. Womp womp. Make sure you do that! As the server said to us (and looking at our faces of simultaneous pleasure and regret from eating so much): "You didn't leave room for the best part!" I know. I know. We know. We know. You gotta come in sometime for this!
author: James Z.

description:
We ordered the meat platter. 3 injeras. Sambusas, tomato, I thought we had chicken but my friend who is from Eritrea
And knows the food...she cooks it herself,..corrected me and said it was lamb. The food was rooot starchy and we had more injeras than I requested as everything is eaten with our bread: food and eating utensils. A big platter. Yet I felt surprisingly under fed. She was full. Not a meal to enjoy in evening clothes. Your hand is in everything. The waiter was very friendly. I will return. My friend has left for Egypt but this restaurant will keep her memory alive. An that injera lift helps.
author: Bob R.

description:
Great little spot! I love Ethiopian / Eritrean food but don't know enough to tell the difference. Everything we had here was delicious, especially the bread but I cant remember any of the names. Not much for drinks or cocktails but there are bars nearby. 
 This place is in a nice part of the city. Low key neighborhood that feels safe. We went to the Ethiopian spot in the Loin but decided that the area was way too scary to get out of the car. So glad we found this spot.   
Parking can be tough but that's the city for you. Its near my fav movie theater that doesn't have screaming kids so Ill need to remember to eat here when we do movie night in the city.
author: Amy P.

description:
Main Points:
-Great Eritrean cuisine and service
-Good for small or large groups
-Unique dining experience (mainly because of type of cuisine)

Review:
I've had Ethiopian food, which is similar (I'd say Eritrean is spicier), but I have never had Eritrean food before this restaurant so I don't know how it ranks amongst other Eritrean restaurants, but I can say this was delicious cuisine.  We ordered both the vegetable and meat samplers, and all the items were good, most were great!  

For those not familiar with this type of food, the different mixtures are served on a large plate of injera which is a sourdough flatbread and they are eaten with your hands.  All the orders will be put on one plate, so if you are with a group of people just understand that each person's order will be on this one plate.  This makes for a unique dining experience where everyone can easily try all the different items and bond over the good cuisine and method of eating. Just don't lick your fingers! 

Finally, though I read some people had issues with service, we went as a group of 5 when the medium-sized restaurant was full and had no issues with wait time for our meal/order or service.  The staff was very friendly and checked on us frequently to make sure our food was good and our drinks were full. The only thing keeping it from being a 5 star joint is the very casual atmosphere, like a mom and pop shop. Overall definitely worth trying!
author: Puja C.

description: This place is FANTASTIC. My husband and I first came here in 2005. We came religiously for years. Any family or friends who came to visit us always ended up here with us. This was our first outing after we had a baby but eventually we had to move out of state. That was years ago and recently we got a chance to come back to the bay area for vacation and this was the first place on our list.  The food is as delicious as we remembered it and this time our 8 year old son loved it too just as much as we did and still do.  This place is a gem.  We always ordered the veg and meat combo plates so we can have just about everything possible to eat and all of it is delicious.  We miss living nearby.  Hope the locals know what they've got here.  Until next time Assab!
author: Sudha J.

description: Love this place, the food is really good and I love the kittfo. The service was slow but that's Ethiopian.
author: Nichoas S.

description: Food was great and creative twists to familiar dishes and still delicious. Service is ... hmm... hard to describe... just not pleasant- doesn't embrace the bay area spirit. Neither warm nor friendly ...
author: Rosa M.

description:
Came here on a whim with my roommate after grocery shopping at Trader Joe's. There was no wait and we were quickly seated upon arrival. We shared two entrees- VEGETARIAN ALICHA and SHIRO, which was served on a huge platter. Everything was delicious, and we were inhaling the plate with the injera, before the waiter came by and recommended we eat the injera beneath veggies, versus the one on the side first. I'm guessing because the injera in the platter will have the juices of the entrees? 

Overall, delicious food, reasonable prices, and friendly service!
author: Joanna H.

description:
Amazing food. Super friendly. Not packed. I had eaten Eritrean food before and didn't like it as much as this place. We ordered two dishes that came family style on one big platter over their signature injera bread. 

Eating with hands is fun but they have utensils if you want. Beer was good. We had a lamb dish, okra and beef in tomato sauce, and there were lentils and other yummy stuff. #7 and #8 - first time here and we will be back!!! REALLY GOOD!
author: Bing B.

description: This is the best Eritrean/Ethiopian place in the country!!!  Washington DC area has several great ones, but nothing this good.  Just don't come if you are in a hurry, everything is made to order and delicious.  Just sit back, relax, drink some tej (honey wine) and the wonderful hospitality that welcomes you by the entire staff (Dad, Mom, and their daughter).  Prices are very reasonable and quality is unmatched.
author: Dave G.

description: Adore this little gem . . . we actually will drive all the way to S.F. just to eat here, it makes for a cute date :-) Their injera 'bread' is everything and is almost identical to the identical dosa, which is fermented pancake of sorts, it's tangy, my favorite palate hit :-) Every single one of their entrees is fantastic, though I have a soft spot for their okra and lamb dishes. Their kelwa derho, chicken, is beautifully spiced and balanced and though they describe it as "spicy," is actually a gorgeous blend of flavors, especially when mixed with the yogurt, which I get more of as a side dish. My sister in law, who is more of a vegetarian, loves their kantisha and bersin, mushrooms and lentils of two different varieties. It's a ton of fun to sit on the floor and eat with hands, takes me back to my childhood when we had no cutlery, as Indian immigrants and that's what we did as an Indian family: eat with our hands, the first tools we were born with :-) Did I mention their service is super warm and friendly, the prices right, and the ambience perfect for the cuisine.
author: Ranjan P.

description:
I probably ate some of the Purell off my fingers along with all that goodness I picked up in the injera. If I ate this kind of food every day, I'd have five permanently smelly fingernails and one happy stomach. Not a bad trade-off, if you ask me. Actually, it nearly happened when I visited LA - some groceries there have Eritrean / Ethiopian premade and boxed.

Meanwhile, in SF, I've been to this restaurant at least three times over the years. It's always been with a group, and it's always been as much about sharing conversation as it's been about sharing food. The assortment we shared this time was lamb, raw beef, pork-something, meat combo (sampler of three set items), and okra. You know anywhere I see okra I have to order it.

It took a while between ordering and receiving our food. I think this was less about the amount of other diners present and more about fixing up the items for all five of us before being able to bring out the communal plate. My friends who had never eaten African food initially thought the servings looked small, but they were all stuffed before the plate was cleared.

All together, the 5 items, a bottle of Eritrean honey wine, and 4 beverages came out to just over $30 per person. But don't tell that to my exchange student friends - we divvied it up unequally to ease the cost on them.
author: Dan B.

description: Amazing! I legitimately crave this place now. Be prepared to eat with your hands though! I suggest ordering the samplers to try a little bit of everything. You can't go wrong that way.
author: Dayna Y.

description: My family and I were back in town visiting.  We were 4 adults and 3 children ages 4-13.  Some of us picky eaters and some of us with diet restrictions but ALL of us left exceptionally fulfilled and happy, even the kids which is such a bonus!  The quality of food & service is simply amazing!  You can taste every ingredient including all the herbs, the foods fresh and leaves you feeling really good.  Menu accommodates a range of diets.  Service is warm, friendly & highly attentive.  The owners are wonderful people. Thank you Assab!!
author: Emily S.

description:
I didn't eat hear so review isn't about their food, am African so when I saw the place while driving by I got so excited yucky found parking then ran inside the lady who welcomed me was unfriendly so I thought May be she is having a bad day she wasn't into answering any questions about the food or when I asked if they were still open she looked at me like" duh you fool" but I was thinking whatever so I sat and a  gentleman came to take my order I asked him about beans lol am African I love beans with a smile and at the same time coming off cold he said did you look at the menu that's what we have to be fair I hadn't looked at the menu I just wanted to talk to them , have a convo with other Africans 

Bottom line other positive reviews on this page tell me they treated me different cause am African , weird right !
author: Sam M.

description: My favorite restaurant! It always meets my cravings. Spicy or sour, it always fulfills me. All dishes are fresh and freshly made for you. My favorite is kantisha. Also love their lentil soup and homemade yogurt. I wish they have catering to have it in the office once in a while.
author: Nataliya K.

description: Awesome vegetarian options! Great service, tasty food, and smooth honey wine! Wonderful experience.
author: Rachael L.

description: This place came highly recommended by a friend. After an afternoon at the de young, we realized we were in the neighborhood and the restaurant was opening in a few minutes!! We parked and the minute we walked in, we were met with delicious smells of spices. I ordered a class of cab expecting the worst and it was good wine for less than $6 a glass! I knew I had a good feeling about this place. We decided to share 2 dishes spinach and chicken. The food came out beautifully presented on a large blue platter with so much injera goodness. We ate for what felt like forever. It was fun since we got to eat with our hands and feel the gooey texture of the injera. This was an extremely satisfying meal and I can't wait to come back!!! We had a lot of injera left over which we took with us and made the most delicious chicken quesadillas with the next day lol! This makes me want to make injera from scratch!!
author: Yin H.

description: For me this didn't live up to the hype at all. The bread tasted sour and the meats were really tough. They also charged our credit card twice. I didn't mind that my date and I shared because the portions are huge but I still didn't end up really eating much because the flavored were meh although I really did like the lentils. Those alone are great. Plating was nice and the restauraunt is definitely clean. If you're into this kind of food give it a try.
author: Paula P.

description:
These days most of the Yelp business's claim as 'Vegetarian go Nuts' and the reality is that you still have to dig through the menu to see what is vegetarian! You wont have that problem in Assab. This is a small place located on Geary Ave (Walking distance from my place). 

We started with the Vegetable Sambusa, it was perfectly spiced and it surprised me as it had green peas instead of potatoes. We ordered the Shiro (customized it by making it spicy), followed by Berson and Alicha. The spinach entree was perfect. Injera were fresh and hot.

I would recommend this place if you craving for Ethiopian food.
author: Shiven G.

description:
This is place is fantastic. Great place for carnivores, vegetarians, and vegans. 

I've been here before multiple times with small and large groups (6+) and it has been an incredibly pleasant and consistent experience. Great food and great welcoming warm atmosphere. 

I once arrived with 6+ people a 45 minutes before closing and felt really bad because they were already pretty busy and we didn't want to make them stay late just for us. Of course, we still tried our best to eat quickly and made sure to tip well because the server was so nice the entire time and ensured us to take our time throughout.

FOOD:
Full of flavor
Large Quantities
Comforting
Delicious
NOT greasy
NOT heavy on sodium

ATMOSPHERE:
Feel at home
Cozy
Gracious host
Good for small & larger parties

SERVICE:
Superb! 
Genuinely nice
Great sense of humor
Always on point

PRICE:
Can't complain. 
You're getting quantity & quality. 
That's hard to beat!

PARKING:
Street parking in front is metered but 2 Hour parking is available on the adjacent streets off of Geary or longer term parking up on Anza street. Not bad at all.
author: Calvin L.

description: This place is less than 1 block from my house.   Been wanting to try and finally just did.    I had a chicken dish that came with okra,  I think lentles,  and sweet potatoes  with a generous amount of all.    It sat atop a delicious and tasty  pancake like , for lack of a better word,  bread.   It was also  on top of dish.  Absolutely delicious !   The entire restaurant is so clean and the way they have the tables set up each one is very private.    They have their score from the health dept  displayed , as all restaurants are supposed to,   but only ones with good scores do.   It says on their website their score is 96 out of 100.    That must be an old score because all the recent ones are 100!   The family running it are all very friendly.    This is my new favorite restaurant in my hood.  Can t wait to bring some friends here to eat in.    Right next to the self-serve car wash on Geary And Collins.     Best Ethiopian food in Bay Area.
author: Denise L.

description:
I think the food at Assab is better than New Eritrea in the Sunset.  You can read my review on New Eritrea and I'll focus this review on Assab.

The food at Assab has bold flavors that awaken the palate, but it's not overwhelming.  My friends and I ordered chicken, beef and okra, and our plate was full of chickpeas, collard greens and other veggies on the side.  The injera bread is soft and moist.  It costs extra to order more, and you will definitely need at least one extra order.  But injera does fill up the belly pretty fast so I can't imagine ordering more than two..

The space is small, so my friends and I waited about an hour... There was no place to sit so we were getting impatient as our hunger grew.  Once we were seated, we ordered right away.  Service was friendly, and the patrons at this place are friendly too!  A couple moved to another table so that my party of 3 can have their bigger table.

The prices (at least for dinner, not sure if they use the same menu for lunch) are higher than New Eritrea, but I think it reflects the quality.  I hope they invest in outside space heaters so people can wait outside.  It was awkward waiting in the restaurant and looking at people while they were dining.
author: Vira P.

description:
I've been craving Ethiopian ever since leaving LA and the reknown Little Ethiopia. Now that Blue Nile is closed in Berkeley, I had to find another substitute. 

However, that did not take long as the unanimous recommendation was that I had to check out Assab. 

Ground beef-Has the concistency of Jack In the Box taco meat, just a million times tastier
Cubed beef raw-Ask for the beef served raw
Lamb with Potato-Likely the tastiest dish we had that night, with a wholesome flavor, not spicy at all
Chicken leg-Two braised chicken legs, braised in a brown sauce
Okra-To add a little green to the mix, braised in a red sauce
ingira

All of this was served on one of the biggest plates I've ever seen. 

Definitely worth going to for Ethiopian in the bay area.
author: Vince E.

description: I absolutely love this place!  Yes, if you come on a Friday or Saturday it is extremely crowded but the rest of the week the wait is minimal if any.  The food here is amazing.  I always get the Kitfo and Veggie Sampler.  Both are so tasty.  I live in Novato now and constantly crave the food from Assab.  I have to come into town at least once a month just for dinner here.  Believe me, you won't be disappointed!!
author: sarah w.

description:
This is the 4th time I have come here. The food's good and I always leave satisfied with my experience. 

-Friendly and attentive service
-Food is quite tasty
-good drink selection
-easy parking
author: Sam Y.

description:
Overall: 3 to 3.5 stars

Bottom line is this restaurant is overrated (too many 4 & 5 star reviews) but the food is good and tasty. I don't think it makes for a good date night as if it wasn't clear by now, Eritrean food is eaten with your hands and can be quite messy.

Food: 4 stars. Flavorful. We ordered both the meat and vegetarian sampler. All the dishes were good, I found each one to be well prepared, I suppose the lamb and okra dishes stood out. On the downside, the meal is very rich and salty. No acids to cut the oiliness, even the yogurt, while tasty was full fat and more like whipped cream.

Injera: 3 stars. The injera gets a separate review because it's such a staple of Eritrean cuisine. Like other people have mentioned, it's thinner and less sour than at other places. It has the consistency of a crepe. They serve the injera with the food on top and you also get a side of it. The problem is that the injera under the food is completely covered making it soggy and difficult to pick up. Other places tend to leave about 1/2 of the pancake exposed, without any food on top for this reason. The side of injera is nice, but there are no free refills and you only get one pancake. 

Service/Atmosphere: 2.5 stars. The decor, dishware and overall ambiance leaves a lot to be desired. It's has a very local, divey kind of vibe. Music playing was really bad. Service is sparse and lacks for conversation. No explanation of what was given to us.

Price: 2.5 stars. All of the dishes are over $12, we paid $14 and $16 for the samplers. This was too much. Yes, the portion sizes were big, but they were too big. There was enough food for 4. I would have liked to have seen a reduction in price and portion size by about 1/3, even 1/2. Eritrean food is not good take-home material so don't think you can make up for it by getting a doggy bag.

My final gripe and this may be all Eritrean restaurants, is if I'm going to eat with my hands, I'd really like to be given something to wash with after (and preferably before as well!). A hot cloth or bowl of lemon water would be a REALLY good idea don't you think? More napkins too please.

While the food was delicious, the price, atmosphere, service and other issues I mentioned add up to me not coming back. Really wanted to like this place as it's local and I love the cuisine.
author: Sam S.

description:
Place has Great food, Good Vibe, Reasonable. 
Even beer was good, 
Try it for sure.
author: Mike D.

description: Fantastic! I have to admit, I love Ethiopian food. And this place is one of the best. The food is delicious and they have a good variety of vegetarian options. Their okra was great! The service was good and the dining room has a nice, open layout. But, come for the food!
author: Greg C.

description:
I'm probably not the best person to rate this restaurant since I'm not really a big fan of spicy...and let me tell you, EVERYTHING is spicy here! Well, not everything, but mostly everything (considering we tried one of  everything on the menu). After 2 bites, my mouth was literally on fire. And I think I have a pretty high tolerance for somewhat spicy food. 

The spongy bread-like thing is what makes it less spicy, a long with the yogurt sauce. However, if you want more bread, they charge you. If you want more sauce, they charge you. Thankfully water is free, but they are not too good at refilling it.

Make sure you have clean hands too, because everyone you're with digs right in -- no utensils. 

It's a fun, unique experience. I have now eaten here twice. Will I be back? Probably not, unless I get talked into it like the past 2 times. It's not bad, it's just not my cup of tea.
author: Alysha K.

description:
Ethiopian food. It's a hit or a miss.  I've never tried this type of food before, but it reminds me of Indian food (which I love). No forks, spoons, or knifes.  Use your HANDS.  Make sure to wash em!

Came here around 9pm on a Saturday and this place was full with people waiting to get seated.  I kind of wish this place had some ventilation going on, it was really stuffy and the windows were getting foggy.

We eventually got seated, ordered the meat and vegetable combo platter, around ($15-18).  It's a good one to order if you never had Ethiopian food cause it gives you a taste of everything.  My favorite was this one spicy beef, the yogurt, potato, zucchini, okra, and chicken was also good too.  Not entirely know what the names are though. They were all full of delicious flavor.  BUT, the yogurt & spicy beef was my favorite for some reason. YUM YUM YUM. Goes hand in hand.

The one thing I didn't like was the injera (ethiopian bread).  I was NOT a fan of the injera.  It was too spongy to eat for me.  I wished I had something else than scooping the food with the injera.

Service = Ok. There was only one girl serving all the full tables there.  Give her credit for that.

India Pale Ale (IPA) = was really good and refreshing, go try it!

Despite my dislike of the injera, I loved all the flavors.  Go try it yourself! Everyone should try Ethiopian food, one time or another.
author: Jennifer K.

description: I've changed my eating habits to a vegan diet. I used to gorge on their meat sampler, now I gorge on the veggie sampler (without yogurt) still one of my favorite placed to eat. Eat with your hands peopel, its half the fun!
author: Fresh B.

description:
This place deserves its 4 star review! Don't let the shabby exterior of this place fool you! GREAT food, super friendly staff, reasonable prices, and great atmosphere. I'm lucky that this place is so close to my house!

Also, their to - go packaging is pretty damn great.

For the Richmond area, this place is a must try!
author: Patrick M.

description: Such an awesome place. The food was so good, the portions were huge, and the people who work there are so nice. It's a small place, wasn't too crowded when we went, and pretty affordable for SF. Get the vegetarian sampler as one of your entrees so that we can try a bunch of different things. And get ready to get your hands a bit dirty!
author: Andrew G.

description: I am only giving this place two stars because I feel it is a bit unfair to rate them without trying the food. However, the horrible atmosphere and service was terrible enough to make me write a review (and I hardly ever write reviews). We came in as a party of nine and was told all the large tables were reserved, so they would have to split us up. Now, this was not what annoyed me, the man's attitude was what annoyed me. We asked if we could move tables together and received nothing but bad attitude and all the reasons this would not be possible. So what did we do? We found another place that was willing to move their tables for us and had a great dinner in a hospitable environment.
author: Priya D.

description:
This place is perfect. If it's busy, expect to wait, cuz this is a mom n pop shop! Literally - mom came to our table and said they ran out of chicken. No problem; our party loves food so it wasn't difficult choosing something else. If you're an impatient person, either look somewhere else, or get a bottle of their delicious wine and talk to your party and relax. The food is guaranteed amazing! 

Warning - you might have to be rolled out of the restaurant from being so full!
author: Denise H.

description:
No smiles. No free injera, once you run out of bread (unlike all other habesha restaurants in the bay area) you must pay for each extra piece - that means you can't eat the rest of your food. And worse: they treated us with complete arrogance. 

Prices are too high! 

It's worth heading over to Oakland to the plethora of options and smiles. I'm so disappointed in this place. Food was alright. The customer service ruined our experience. Oh, and there are no Habesha customers in there; that speaks volumes.
author: Kaley B.

description: Went here with 7 friends to catch up. Ideal for bigger groups so you can try everything, share family style. Excellent mix of vegetable and meat dishes. Spicy but not too much so. Eating with your hands and Injera is fun and different, just have to trust the people you are with! Ethiopian beers were unique. No frills atmosphere, but authentic.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Its rare that food makes me feel as good as the food here does. It just makes me so HAPPY. As soon as I take the first bite I enter into some kind of state of...I don't even know what. It definitely releases endorphins. 
To be fair, I've only tried two dishes here, but one is the meat combo, which is made of several dishes. The meat combo includes includes Zigni, Tsebhi Derho, and Alicha Beggee. All of them are really good, and its a LOT of food. The menu says its for one, but for me its enough for 3-4 meals (keep in mind that I'm small). So delicious AND cost efficient. The second things I've tried is the Kitfo (raw). Some of the best Kitfo I've ever had. The texture, temperature, and spices were perfect. I also liked that they give options for how to have it cooked (raw, medium rare etc) which isn't always an options at other places. 
Only two downsides- the last couple of times I've tried to call ahead for take out they haven't answered the phone, but when I got there they were open. The other thing is that their Shiro is just good, not great. A little runnier than what I'm used. In my opinion Shiro is very, very important. So I give them 4.75, which isn't an option on Yelp and might as well be rounded up to 5 stars anyway, so yay 5 stars!!
author: Dana C.

description:
Berkeley is best known for their hearty Eritrean dishes. But this spot is the closest I've gotten to a worth while Eritrean Restaurant in SF. 

Ordered: Vegetarian and Meat Combo. 

Pros:
Yummy
Clean
Bigger servings than other places I've been
Kind servers 
Refilled water without having to ask
clean bathrooms 
Affordable 
Nice quite atmosphere 

Cons: 
Metered street parking
author: Monica M.

description:
It is a perfect example of "hidden gem".

This place has amazing food, especially their meet dishes are very tasteful. Overall very authentic African food experience.
author: Ambrish V.

description:
After a bit of playing tourist we headed to Assam with a tremendous appetite. 3 adults a toddler and a baby at 8:30 pm on a Saturday night. Both servers tried to ignore us hoping the other would attend to us - we got a table and quickly ordered our favorites. The guava juice and mango juice were Kern and the samosas were great. Lentil soup was ok, a little to heavy on salt. 
The 2 combos of meat and veggy wewre adequate. I think having had some amazing Ethiopian food at Zeni's and Walia in San Jose I wasn't particularly impressed.
author: M G.

description: Eating with your hands never tasted so good. Get the vegetable combo dish, maybe a chicken dish, lots of injira (bread) and prepare to leave stuffed.
author: Scott B.

description:
I've eaten here numerous times.

The food is delicious! After visiting Eritrean and Ethiopian restaurants in the Bay Area, Sacramento, and even little Ethiopia in Los Angeles, this place offers the most food in your plate, with varieties of vegetables, and not just a plate of meat. They even add traditional yogurt on the plate, something I've not seen at the other restaurants. 

If you like wine, try the Ethiopian Honey Wine.

Appetizers: If you like spice, try the vegetarian sambusas, as they're spicier and have more of a kick.

Relaxing ambience. Ethiopian imagery and decoration. It's not too loud, and you can actually hear yourselves talk without having to yell. Relaxing.

I've brought so many people here time and one again and they always love it. 

I hope this review gives you a good picture of what your experience would be.

You have to give it a chance though!

Yum yum yum!
author: Marcel S.

description:
My friend invited me out and thought it would be cool to make me try something new. Frankly, Eritrean food is quite different if you've never had it before.

When we arrived at the restaurant, I was surprised to see that some of the meat entrees could be prepared "raw". I normally don't get anything less cooked than a medium rare. To my horror, my friend ordered us RAW "Kitfo" to share. 

When the food arrived, it looked strangely appetizing and a little like baby food. However,  I was still a bit doubtful about its flavor. After witnessing my friend happily grab his first bite, I decided it couldn't be too bad. It was weird grabbing the meat (or anything else) with the piece of bread. Everything was cooked until it was very soft, even mushy. 

To my surprise, the first bite (of the meat) wasn't bad.. it was actually pretty good. I proceeded with a second bite of the next closest colorful pile of mush on the plate.. then the next.. then the next. The meat, the greens, as well as the curry-like paste.. the whole dish was delicious and packed with flavor! My only complaint was that it was quite spicy. It might be hard for some to cope with, though I'm sure you could request for it to be more mild. Serving size was great as well, the two of us couldn't finish all the food. Unfortunately we couldn't box anything. By the time we were finished, a decent amount of the foods had already soaked into the bread making it soggy. 

Service was also decent. I didn't experience the long wait time other reviewers mentioned, but maybe because it wasn't at all crowded in the restaurant.

Anyways, came in a bit surprised, but left with my stomach happy. Will definitely try this place again!
author: Kennie D.

description:
Food comes out piping hot and so flavorful. We got vegetarian chickpeas (which were amazing) and a meat dish, but the collard greens stole the show. The portion sizes are huge and two dishes are plenty, if not too much, for two people. 

If I have one gripe, the injera wasn't thick enough at the bottom of the dish and fell apart readily. 

Besides that, I'm a fan. Oh, we also ordered lentil soup as an appetizer which was really pleasant. Plenty of onions and shallots in the broth.
author: Michelle K.

description: Happens to be one of my favorite cuisines. Best i ve had and my benchmark was set by another eritrean place i ve loved and frequented in Boston(asmara in central square). Asaab can be a bit on the spicier side. Highly recommend their honey wine! Sweet and smooth.
author: Vasini G.

description:
I never had ertriean food before, so this was very interesting to try.  Eating with your hands is different but friends and I were all willing too try.

What we had:
Lamb
Chicken with bone
Beef
Spinach.

I had had say, I didn't like the spinach at all.  The spinach had a sour taste and didn't look nor tasted like the typical ones were used to having.   our perspective of normal green spinach must be different from theirs.  I almost thought it was for garnishing, to separate from each dish.  

This is a family owned restaurant, service is slower, but that's ok.
author: Anna W.

description:
Really friendly staff.
First time Ethiopian food eater.
Order 2 proteins + 1 veggie dish for 3 people.
Served Family style. 

Way too much food, had left over. 
Portions were ok, however the 'injera' crepe that they serve really fills you up.

The lamb was great, tender flavorful.
The lentils were really tasty.
The beef (#1) was ok, a bit tough.

Mango juice was pretty awesome too.
author: H T.

description:
Assab was my first foray into Ethiopian cuisine and based on my experience here, I will definitely be back for more. It's not that I was ever scared to try Ethiopian; instead, I'm blaming it on my own laziness and desires to stick to my 'comfort-foreign' foods like Thai or Indian. 

Assab is not fancy nor does it claim to be-- it definitely feels like a family-owned business. Busy but not overwhelmingly so, the crowd was a mix of ages and ethnicities, including several parties with small children, who were all welcomed. 

My boyfriend and I both started with glasses of honey wine and veggie sambusas. The wine tasted a bit foreign at first-- a bit dry but with a sweet, honeyed finish. The sambusas were similar to a samosa in concept and texture, but were flat little rectangles instead of puffy.

The two of us ordered three veggie entrees, which we had served 'family style' aka all of it was served on a giant plate. We had the Shiro (chickpeas), Kantisha (Mushrooms) and the veggie combo, which gave us okra, zucchini and alicha (potatoes/carrots). It was served with lentils on the plate, as well as some dollops of yogurt, and of course, our utensils: the injera bread. Slightly sour but very spongy, we were served the perfect amount of injera to scoop and sop up the various vegetables and stews. My favorite was the Shiro, as the chickpeas were mashed and served in a tangy tomato stew. The flavors were a nice mix of familiar yet new. Also, the serving plate is lined with a large piece of injera, so all of the stews soak into the bread. Our server told us it was the best part. A bit soggy, but yes, all of the flavors had indeed soaked into the injera. We were a bit too full to enjoy much of the bottom layer though.

The service here was great-- the food came out rather quick and several people asked us if we were enjoying the meal. While we definitely got plenty of food, most entrees are over $10 each. Added up with appetizer and honey wine, we easily spent over $80 for two people. Not overly expensive, but if you're coming in expecting to pay hole-in-the-wall type prices, you're mistaken. But in the end, you're rewarded with quality Ethiopian food and experiences, which will satisfy both first-timers and veterans alike.
author: Bryan B.

description: Everything was delicious and a great price! We got the #1, #4 and. #18 family style for four of us.
author: Jean G.

description:
This place is amazing. The food was excellent but the best part for me was that:
1. It's a local family run establishment.
2. The host and hostess (are also co-owners) are so nice. They treated us like family and were super welcoming.

I will definitely go to Assab again. The hot tea (any kind) is really good, because they give you spiced warm water instead of just regular hot water.
author: Mark G.

description: Only if they had rice. Nothing like a good slab of lamb with rice. Bread is ok. Food is not burning hot, but they accommodate that option. Next time will try the dessert.
author: Carlos G.

description: We had the lentil soup, veg sambusa, veg combo and spinach entree.  Enjoyed everything.  It felt like a family owned business where people value their customers and take pride in what they do.  We were the last people to leave and the owner never rushed us.  Great service , food and ambiance.  I only wish they'd add seafood to their menu.  Will be back
author: Nise c.

description: Recently visited and the food & service here are still outstanding and exceptional.  There's so much heart that goes into this place and the food is soo yummy but not fattening. very warm & inviting too :)
author: Tamika J.

description: My favorite Eritrean / Ethiopian in the city. The injera is slightly bitter which is ideal. The veggie combo has the typical lentil, carrots, potato but also okra, greens, mushrooms. Chicken on the bone is also really tender. Definitely get on the bone as it's more tender than boneless. The sambosa app is good too if you are really hungry. My only complaint is the recent lack of Harar beer, which imho is the best out of Ethiopia. Apparently the distributor has been having trouble or stopped importing altogether. Major bummer. I spent about 6 weeks in Eritrea and Ethiopia, so I can tell you, this stuff is some of the most authentic you'll get in the USA. It does get a bit more spicy back in Africa, and they use more goat, but adjusted for the American palate, this place is perfect.
author: Brian J.

description: Definitely a cute little gem in the Inner Richmond. Love the food. I ordered the kelwab mix (chicken) on the spicy and they did not disappoint. Seasoning was on point. The spicy level was perfect that it wasn't overwhelming but had a lasting taste. The little yogurt on the side was a nice touch as it played a little with the taste buds. They offer utensils, as Ethiopian food is normally eaten with the hands. I, personally believe, food taste better when eaten from the hands. For sure, will recommend. Side note, they also offer vegetarian meals as well. I will be returning in the near future.
author: Anthony H.

description:
I have only had Ethiopian food a few times, and before eating here, it was always home-made.  This place was up to snuff on all accounts, everything we ordered was so tasty, and the honey wine was delicious and sweet.

I was tempted to try the Kitfo as raw, but we decided to go with medium rare and i thought it was perfectly spiced with a fiery kick...maybe a little spicier than i would have liked, but i wasn't complaining =).

The Vegetable Combination was delicious as well, and it gave us a taste of a lot of different flavors--also quite spicy, but again, i wasn't complaining.

Overall, the food was delicious, the serving staff really friendly and helpful, and I can't wait to get back there very soon!

Happy SPICY eating!
author: Bradley H.

description: This was very good and authentic Ethiopian food at really good prices.  A key difference from other restaurants of the same type is you have the option of sharing one large injera bread with multiple dishes on it with others in your party or getting an individual one for yourself with the entree dish you choose.  Each entree dish comes with lentils, salad and homemade yogurt as accompaniments.  We had 6 of us and each had different dishes and all were full of great flavors and spices, with sizeable quantities of food and we each got an additional injera bread which we all needed to mop everything up.  The homemade yogurt was delicious and acted as a great digestive.  The deserts looked very good but we didn't have room to enjoy them.  All entrees were between 10 and 15 dollars and provided a very filling and tasty meal.  This is a great find if you like this type of food.
author: Shankar S.

description:
I use to live across the street from this place on Collins St and I'll admit that I ate here at least once a week! I've tried out a ton of other Eritrean places and I have to say this is by far my favorite in the city!

WHAT I ORDER:
I usually come with at least one other person so the regular dishes I order is:
- 1 Veggie Combo and 1 Meat Combo. 
- Sambusas are great and come in Veggie or Meat.
- When I'm really hungry and cold ... I also like to start with the lentil soup.
- To drink, their Ginger Beer is pretty awesome.

PRICE:
If you order the above (for 2 people) the bill will probably come to around $50, Give or take a few. 

LOCATION:
There's a bus stop right in front of the restaurant so you can easily get to it using MUNI (38 Geary). It is on the corner of Geary and Collins. The restaurant decor is fairly simple but very CLEAN!

SERVICE:
I think this place if family owned. Usually there's 2 servers walking around to sit people, take orders and bring food over. Its pretty hard to get their attention otherwise and sometimes they can come off a bit stand offish. The food will also take a while so be patient! But rest assured, it will be AMAZING!!

PLEASE NOTE: 
Though in the end you end up sharing all the food ... the owner is very adamant about people NOT sharing. He prefers everyone to order atleast 1 entree.
author: Hiyasmin D.

description:
Decent Ethiopian but not the best.

Good things:
Perfect Kitfo (raw beef)
Lamb dish is very tasty
Quick service

Bad Things:
Lentil soup too salty
Veggie dishes too watery
You only get 1 injera at a time (most places give you a plate of injera right away)
Slightly more expensive than most places with dishes at $14-16.

Try the honey wine- but beware of a hangover to sugar rush.
author: M S.

description:
This restaurant has a great homey feel to it. While it's not located on the main drag in Laurel Heights, this means it's easier to get parking. Still, it was a bit dark and isolated in the area. However, when you walk in, the service is extremely welcoming and warm. I wouldn't call the restaurant upscale, but more comfortable. There were clearly quite a few regulars inside - always a good sign.

We split a large vegetable combination platter, and asked if we could design our own second combination platter, including shiro, spinach and bersin. (Note - you cannot include mushrooms in any combination platter, it can only be ordered as its own dish). The platter came out quite fast (within 10-15 minutes), and was gigantic and delicious. So much flavor (and spice!) in every bite. My boyfriend commented he hadn't been able to find any Ethiopian food in the city that was this authentic/tasty. 

I wouldn't break down each piece of the platter (as the flavors meld together quite nicely with the combined way they serve them), but suffice it to say everything had quite a heat to it, while maintaining the purity of the vegetable - so you really knew what you were tasting in each bite (okra, spinach, potato, etc.). The yogurt they serve in the middle of the platter was a nice complement to all of the heat, really cooling nicely. The injera it was all served on was spongy and soft, yet held up nicely to all of the heavy sauces, which made it a great vessel for all of the food. We also ordered a side of the yogurt, and it was quite thick and tangy - exactly what you'd expect from a homemade version.

Overall, the meal was about $40, including tip, which I thought was quite a good deal for all of the food we got - we left quite full! We'll definitely be back.
author: Jackie W.

description:
First time having Eritrean food. I must say I liked the food itself. Very filling for the portion sizes. However, as other Yelpers have mentioned--the server that helped us did not explain any of the dishes...like at all...

We mentioned that it was our first time and asked for suggestions. He listed a couple of numbers..okay great..thanks...
Then, when he served us the food, he did not explain what was what on our plates! Also, we had no idea we were supposed to eat with our hands..a head's up would have been nice, just because it was our first time. haha. I have no problem with that, but I just did not know that was the protocol. Two of us got samplers so there were different things on our plate..which we just had to figure out on our own. haha. 

Other than that, the food was very flavorful and filling, and yeah, I'd go again, especially since I now know what the deal is. Haha.
author: Mariel A.

description: Years later, third update, this is still one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I live in LA now and once tried one of the supposedly best Ethiopian restaurants in Little Ethiopia here. In my opinion, said restaurant's food does not even come close to Assab. On a recent visit, I told these exact praises to the owner--he was extremely humble, explaining that he encourages people to explore different restaurants of the same cuisine, even if you're in love with a particular dish at one specific restaurant. i.e., I am in love with Assab's kantisha (mushrooms), but that shouldn't bar me from trying kantisha at another Eritrean restaurant (should they have it). I think the owner was basically saying that different places might have different renditions of Eritrean and Ethiopian food, but in a good way, so don't close yourself off to the possibilities. While I appreciated his modesty, I know a good thing when I taste it: Assab is still the best in my book, and probably always will be. Out of nowhere, I sometimes find myself craving Assab's spicy dishes and their mouth-poppingly delicious flavors soaked up in that soft, spongy injera (shoveled straight from plate to mouth with my own fingers, of course). And then I am sad, because I live so far away from Assab :(. At least  thisgives me something to dream about and works towards. I'll be back soon enough--that is a promise!
author: Kate V.

description:
This place is absolutely originally great! It was my first experience with Ethiopian cuisine & I loved it! I got the lamb complemented with their bread and all the sides. The spices were unbeatable. It was full of flavor and I absolutely loved loved loved the thin bread. It was sort of like the Ethiopian Naan (haha). 

Anyway, try this place out! It's a unique experience to have. The service is also very good - you can tell they appreciate their customers! & if you're a foodie, like myself, you'll appreciate every bite of this place!
author: Junel S.

description: This is the best habesha food spot in the city! Vegetarian friendly and the staff is awesome. My cousin and I love this place and come as often as we can. Also being Eritrean I am biased.
author: leba g.

description: This was my first time trying Ethiopian food. The food had good flavor, service was great, and I liked the portion and pricing.
author: Josie C.

description: Yay!  Assab's Eritrean food!  We really dig this place.  Only been there once, but we fully intend on making another trip soon.  Had the veggie platter which was adequate for two.  Compared to other Eritrean or Ethopian restaurants, I would describe their food as well-seasoned and mild.  Because my wife is Thai and I lived in Thailand so long, we tend to prefer food that has some kick, but we were both very happy eating at Assab's.  The folks who were serving were very nice as well.  Had a good family feeling to the restaurant.  Plus, prices were very affordable and that's saying a lot in San Francisco.  Go there.  We'll be back!
author: Joseph M.

description:
