I just finished eating here and I am still ridiculously full with the taste of honey wine still in my mouth...I had picked up a groupon a few weeks ago which included 2 entrees and 2 glasses of honey wine.  What a deal!

Ok, so I ate here maybe 5 years ago?  To be honest, I don't remember liking it whatsoever.  Mostly, i had issues with the injera (wasn't a fan of it back then). So...I never came back.  I saw the groupon and said hey, what the heck...let's give it another whirl.  And besides, wifey has never tried Eritrean food before.  

I made a reservation earlier today and was looking forward to eating with my hands.  Haha.  We walked in...got a table immediately...and the service was fantastic!  We ordered a chicken leg dish and the beef/okra dish.  Both were ah-mazing!  The chicken was our favorite...the sauce was super flavorful and I loved the addition of the boiled egg.  The beef was on the spicier side which I absolutely loved...and guess what, we even ordered an extra injera!  The injera was perfect this time...I'm not sure what happened...maybe my tastes have changed?  In any case, our meal was perfect...everything from the chicken to the lentils.  Yum!!!

And don't even get me started with the honey wine...there was such a great aftertaste with every sip.  But...I also got pretty tipsy from one glass.  High alcohol content?  Maybe.  Haha.  It was just GOOD.  

The lady who was the cook came out and asked how everything was...I thought that was a nice touch to our dining experience.  Our server was also super nice...I'm guessing they're husband and wife?  Not sure.  

Wifey loved it...I loved it.  What an experience...don't turn away just cause you have to eat with your hands.  Can't wait to come back again!!!
author: Jen W.

description:
My wife and I went to Assab yesterday night. One single qualificative: "awesome". We had the meat sampler (Zigni, Tsebhi Derho, and Alicha Beggee) and Bersin (lentils). I also tried the honey wine, it was so good that I had a second glass. We also appreciated the great sense of humour of the server. 
We went there on Friday evening and were very surprised to only find a partially filled restaurant with a lot of free tables.
We really recommend it.
author: Dominique B.

description:
I've never had Ethiopian food before and being my 1st time trying it this place isn't all that bad. Stumbled upon this place when my boyfriend suggested Ethiopian food. Found it on yelp and came here to give it a try based on yelp reviews. 

This place is tuck away next to Family billiards on Geary. It's a pretty small place with about dozen tables. When we arrived the place was pretty busy, they had 2 tables reserved so we waited maybe 5-10 minutes to get seated. The place is definitely lacking ambiance, there isn't much decor or anything; just tables and few photos handing on the wall.

The food here was pretty good, the portion is decent. If it's your 1st time trying Ethiopian food I would recommend getting the combination platter. I don't remember what number it was on the menu, but you will get a bit of all the meat. I love how the meat just falls off the chicken bone because it's so tender.
author: Jenny G.

description: The food is very good. I loved the berbere spice paste they use in Zigini, it added tremendous flavor to a simple meat dish. The injera is just the right level of sour, portions are good size and the service was really friendly. I will definitely go back.
author: Balu V.

description:
We went there as a group -- but we all were shocked at how the place does NOT look like the pictures on this site or any site. Some of us didn't even want to go inside and went to another restaurant down the street.

Very dirty outside. Even the restaurant signs and Window Awnings are sooo dirty! Bird poop and graffiti.
Just a little bit of soap and water would clean the whole building inside and outside. (can't help being next to a very dirty, old car wash). But please take some pride in your restaurant and food.
author: John G.

description:
For the last three years I've been told by people that SF has no good Ethiopian food. For some reason, instead of doing my own investigating, I believed them. But I am here to tell you that people are wrong! Assab was absolutely delicious. I would have given it four stars, but the quantities were pretty small for a fairly high price.

Two of us split:
#8 Alicha-Beggee ($12.95) - mild seasoned cubes of lamb mixed with potatoes, carrots, and bell peppers. This was really good, I wish there had been more of it.

#5 Kelwa-Derho ($12.95) - chunks of chicken breast sauteed with butter, hot peppers, jalapenos, onions, and tomatoes. This was OK, but compared to the lamb it was pretty boring. 

We also each ordered a glass of honey wine, which (surprise surprise) turned out to be too sweet for both of us.

Like all Ethiopian places, instead of forks, they gave each of us one piece of the injera to use as a vehicle for the food. One piece is definitely not enough unless you really ration your injera, but unfortunately they charge $.75 for every additional injera. 

Although Assab didn't blow my mind, it's definitely a solid choice if you're looking for Ethiopian/Eritrean food.
author: Talia G.

description:
After a long drive to San Francisco (after hours), I was starving and looking for a place to eat nearby and found this restaurant right around the corner. We were seated by 7:50PM. We looked at the menu and already knew what to get since I got a tip from yelp. Servers here don't smile. They looked tired and just doesn't like what they do. Finally, we were able to get the guy server's attention. He finally looked at us and saw how bored we looked, he then came by to take our order at 8:02pm. (12 minutes wait). By the way our food came at 8:43pm. 41 minutes waiting time, my stomach was growling really bad. 

Here are the following food we ordered:

1. Gored-Gored (beef) $16.75 ( really spicy )
2. Lentil soup $2.75 - very flavorful (not recommended for people who have kidney problems) but it is good. I finished it so fast. 
3. Meat combination which includes the beef, chicken and lamb for $16.75

Drinks:
Ethiopian house wine $5.75 (too strong. It's a white wine mixed with honey, I'm not a fan of it, and I couldn't finish it because of its strong taste)

I don't think I would come back here again unless I have a friend who wants to try it. But it's a good try for first timer. Make sure you are not too hungry when you come since the wait is long.
author: Sherry C.

description:
My go to place once every 2 months - food is delicious and the staff is decently good. Very accommodating in helping with changes in the menu the way we want it. My favorite Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant in the city.

CORRECTION - My ONLY Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant in San francisco.
author: Amit K.

description:
I have had food at this place before and it was not bad. There is a weird kinda smell always in this restaurant. 
Though my last visit to this place was horrible. The owner/manager was horribly rude, as if he was doing a favor by serving us. He has restrictions on how many minimum items we need to order even though the restaurant was completely empty. We were 4 ppl and it was past lunch time. So were ordering 2 entrees and 1 appetizer to which the owner said we need to order more. I was like we have already had lunch and we are here just for snacks.  He kept saying non sense stuff and we got so pissed at him that ended up leaving the restaurant without eating anything. 
It was a horrible experience and I am pretty sure I am never going back to this restaurant.
author: Namit R.

description:
Well-prepared food and a cool experience.

I'll start this review by saying that this is my first time eating in an African restaurant, let alone an Eritrean restaurant. With that said, my experience here was A-Okay. My friend and I had to wait about half an hour for a table. I didn't mind waiting but there wasn't a waiting area nor a hostess stand so the whole process was a little confusing. The food was reasonably priced and was very fresh. In some weird way, I felt at home here. Assab feels very much like a mom and pop shop.

All-in-all I found that I'm not a huge fan of Eritrean cuisine. It's nothing against Assab. I would recommend trying this place if you're in the mood for a new and exciting experience.
author: Adam K.

description:
When I was a kid, I hated getting my hands dirty, whether it was playing in the sandbox or eating greasy pizza.  I still actually hate getting my hands dirty, which leads me to believe that's the sole reason I don't like fried chicken.

The four stars just goes to show that despite my distaste for eating with my hands, Assab is THAT GOOD.  The flavors in the meat combination plate were absolutely amazing: spicy, savory, and delicious with the yogurt (which I wish they gave more of).  I wasn't a fan of the really thin bread that they give, not because it wasn't good (which it was), but because it was so porous that the oils and juices soaked through right away and got my hands dirty :(  Not that I wasn't expecting that.  But still.

The sambusas (we got the meat and the vegetable ones) were like thin, crispy hot pockets.  Definitely not what I was expecting, but they were beyond good.  You only get one per order, so we decided to order two of them to split the flavors, but in retrospect, it made us so full that we couldn't finish our main course.

If you're like me and hate getting your fingers dirty, you may want to bring a ton of wet wipes and scrub your hands immediately afterwards.  Just sayin'.
author: Tori S.

description:
Not gonna lie... I kiiiiinda wanted to ask for a fork or a spoon... or a spork, but my friends said they'd disaffiliate themselves immediately.

The place is small, make reservations! They were busy and it took over 30 min to get our food after waiting 30-40 min for a table for 4. Each person's meal was $18 after tip... which is not expensive but not quite as cheap as I expected.
author: Jess C.

description: Quality food. Their honey wine is delicious. Was the first time I have ever had Eritrean food and I will be coming back.
author: Tamara D.

description:
'Tis a'ight. Overall, the service was gracious, the wait time long, the portions small, and the food was bland.

Make a reservation! We came in after the first seating and waited 40 min to be seated & 20 min for the entree. The owner was very kind and apologized for the wait.

Veggie Sambusa: Delicious! Beware of the jalapeno oils - it's potent!

Meat Combo and Gored-Gored: To be fair, it came in a huge plate, which is probably why the portions look ridiculously small. Still, a photo comparison with other places will show that the side dishes have less variety and there's half the meat. The gored-gored was tough and the awaze spices didn't grab onto it very well. The lamb was tender and well flavored -- my favorite of the meat combo choices.

You get one piece of injera, albeit a large one. Most places provide a basket of injera that they refill as soon as it's empty. The injera is less sour here, which is perfect if you're introducing someone new to the cuisine. 

Assab grades behind places in the East Bay (my personal favorites are Finfine in Berkeley and Cafe Colucci in Oakland) not only because of it's dimmed down flavors, it's long wait (which I'll put less weight on since this is my first and only sample), but because of the value as well. It just doesn't feel good to walk away knowing that it costs less for twice the food (and better food!) a Bart ride away. But if my stomach says, "You want Eritrean, NOW," ... well.
author: Mimi X.

description: Best Ethiopian (actually Eritrean) food in San Francisco.  Great variety, awesome flavors and friendly service as it's a family run place.  The combos are awesome.
author: Mohit D.

description:
For someone who is Indonesian like me, eating with your hands is almost second nature, instinctive. Because it's just how we do it.... and also because a lot of people living in 3rd world countries can't afford silverware. But for many Americans it is an experience, so that's what makes eating here unique. Also for many people here, eating together from one bowl is kind of uncomfortable, like you're double dipping, or you're touching their personal space. Eating here, therefore, is not for those who is scared to get their nails dirty. 

I really like the Injera, their traditional equal to a tortilla. I love the texture, the taste, and they combination with meat/vegetable dishes. This is my first time eating here, and I love all their meat dishes. Granted, they do not put a lot of food, but I was truly satisfied, pairing it with the beer, which was pretty refreshing and more hoppy compared to Budweiser or Coors. 

Their dishes is almost like Indian food, IMO, using lot of spices and curry, and it's not dried food, although I'm sure they have barbeque or grilled food as well traditionally. The taste is not too overpowering, and I did not leave smelling like curry is oozing out of my body. I would definitely come back here for another experience, if my wallet is willing to afford it. They are not that cheap, but not outrageously expensive either. 

Verdict: Must TRY at least once, everyone!!
author: Andrew I.

description: Awesome food. Friendly family that runs the place. Always pretty full but not crazy hard to get a seat. Overall I'm a fan, but it was slightly overpriced and the service was fairly slow, hence the 4 stars.
author: Sheridan G.

description: We have dinner here whenever we are missing  East Africa, good food, welcoming atmosphere good prices.
author: Susan S.

description: I can only speak for the vegetarian options here, but dang, they're good. I normally don't like lentils, but their lentils are possibly my favorite thing on the menu. The okra and mushrooms are also totally bomb.
author: Nick V.

description:
Any idea where Eritrea is? If you're geographically challenged like me you'll be happy to know there is a map on the wall to help you out. As a recently minted vegan (read the China Study and you'll understand) I'm a fan, lots of veggie/vegan friendly options and the lentil soup is killer. There is something uniquely satisfying about eating with your hands... after a few meals here you'll realize that using a fork is like showering with a raincoat, you're not getting the full experience! 

The good people that run this operation are sweet... it's very Mom and Pop. Nice to have them in the neighborhood.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
When I made my reservation for 4 people over the phone, the owner asked me, "will it be 4 adults or 4 children?"  Thinking that he must have had a slip of words there, I quickly responded "4 adults".  My boyfriend, who could hear the conversation while sitting next to me, was baffled and said "4 children?!"  The owner heard that and then started randomly laughing out loud.  That pointless "you-had-to-have-been-there" story was an entertaining start to my experience with Assab.

The food was good.  My favorite item at any Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants is the raw kitfo, and it didn't disappoint here.

My group of 4 shared three entrees (which are meant to be 1 serving size) and two sambusa appetizers, and were nicely satisfied.

The honey wine wasn't the best I've had.  It had a slight bitter hoppy taste to it, which I didn't expect.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Assab is such a fun place to go and definitely a great choice for a first date! I wouldn't come to Assab if you're not open minded and willing to try new foods because the meal can get quite intimate very quickly.

My friend and I ordered Kewla Dehro (Spicy Chicken) and a meat combination sampler served on top of the giant pancake (sorry, forgot what that was called) and shared family style. The portions are very large so come with an empty stomach! The whole meal was fantastic; the meat was cooked properly, the flavors were bright and tasty however my only complaint was that it took WAY too long to get our tab and our food. I understand that you don't want to feel rushed but it is nice to carry on with your evening after wards, too. I came in at 7 PM (sharp) and left at 9 PM. 

My advice would be to show up before 7 as after wards it gets quite busy and the wait can be ridiculous. The bottled beer is also quite tasty as well (I'd recommend the lager).
author: Tommy C.

description:
I had never eaten, nor heard of Eritrean food until some friends of mine took me to Assab because they came here every few weeks, but it seems to be very similar to Ethiopian food. I have now been twice and it is a restaurant that I would recommend. This is not fine dining and is not an upscale place at all. It is simple food served in a very simple manner, but I have been very impressed with the quality.

Assab is a good place to go with a group of people because you can order a few different items and all share, as the food comes out on a single large platter. Germaphobes beware though since you eat with your hands.

The overall value is pretty good because, although the portions are on the smaller side, nothing on the menu is very expensive. I would suggest order 2-3 items for every 2 people in your party and start with a sambusa each.
author: Frank J.

description: The food was amazing!  It was wonderfully spiced and delicious.  I could've used a few more dishes in the sampler for the price,  but overall it was a wonderful meal! I'll be back.
author: Netta A.

description:
Wow. What an amazing introduction to East African food! I had been dying to try Ethiopian food for the LONGEST time, and randomly stumbled into this Eritrean restaurant before heading to the movies at the nearby Bridge Theatre.

We ordered the vegetarian platter to share, which is PLENTY of food for two people. We also tried the honey wine, which was a great accompaniment.

I'm definitely coming back here and introducing all of my friends to this type of cuisine! It's not only vegetarian-friendly, but there are many options for meat-lovers, as well.
author: Mansi A.

description:
before leaving the restaurant, i already knew that i wanted to come back.

to begin, our waiter was full of jokes.  my friend started off with some wine, her boyfriend ordered beer, and of course i ordered a delicious glass of guava juice like a big girl, andddddd then he asked for my ID.

okay i guess that that wasn't really that funny.  but i liked that he was light-hearted and not too intrusive.

i'm getting impatient so i'm going to bullet point:

- three of ordered the meat platter, veggie platter, and some rare shredded beef thing.  it was more than enough food!  i wouldn't over-order because i don't think it would taste could the next day as the food will probably make your injera soggy.

- it was my first time eating ethiopian?  eritrean?  food.  and i had no idea that you eat only with your hands.

- it's not that cheap.  it doesn't look THAT nice from the outside or on the inside, but i think our bill came out to about 25 a person? 

- also, MAKE A RESERVATION.  why the hell not?
author: Jennifer L.

description: Standard Ethiopian food but service is really slow. We waited over an hour for our food.
author: Miriam K.

description:
This is one of those places that I *always* take guests from out of town... even when they claim not to like Ethiopian/Eritrean food... this fixes them up pretty good. I tend to stick with the Vegitarian stuff - the Kantisha is Ka-delicious and the Veggie Alicha is ridiculous... I also like to start off with a veggie sambusa which gets my tummy in the mood. The ambiance isn't "fancy" or "nice restaurant" ish... but I think this is one of those places where you should take a date pretty early in the relationship.

The service has always been fantastic. It hasn't always been bubbly and what we would expect from a "western" restaurant experience, but the people are genuinely nice and fun. I have been trying to teach myself Amharic, and once got to chat a (very) little bit with the waitress (who happened to speak it, even though she told me the owners didn't speak it, but spoke only Tigrinya). 

The one "negative" that I will say is that the food isn't very consistent. Almost always ordering the same thing (and my partner DOES order the same thing), I can tell you that it varies in both spice leve and flavour profile from visit to visit. This doesn't really bother me because it varies from "Awesome" to "Amazing," but, just be prepared to have the same dish seem rather different from "last time we were here." Also, the honey wine IS rather sweet... it's good... but it's really sweet. Be prepared for that... 

All in all, this is a place that I LOVE to go and, honestly, it single-handedly converted my boyfriend who was vehemently opposed to the idea of Ethiopian/Eritrean food (he'd been told horror stories by his sisters who had a really bad experience in LA). Go here... you may not gush over it like I do, but I guarantee you won't be upset with your choice!
author: Joseph E.

description:
Only the best things require messy hands: finger painting. Rolling cookie dough. Tie dying. And...

Eating at Assab! 

My family and I went to this restaurant not really knowing what to expect, armed only with the good reviews we've heard from the newspaper.
We ended up getting a veggie sambusa and 2 entrees: the meat combo and the veggie combo! It was kind of embarrassing because when the giant plate with the injera and entrees came, we weren't really sure what to do. Our waitress was SO nice though and she explained to us that the dish is traditionally eaten with the hands. Rip off some injera (it's described as a "thin, soft bubbly bread"...almost like a crepe!) and just dip it into the entrees! Yummmm! Yes, your hands will get messy!! Nothing that a few licks and napkins can't clean up!

The veggie sambusa was good! Wish we had ordered the meat one too! The meat combo was great, as was the veggie combo! My family's not too good with spicy food, but it actually wasn't too bad! Just a heads up: the meat combo can NOT be made mild, but the veggie combo can.
Meat combo includes beef, chicken, and lamb. Veggie combo includes okra, zucchini, and a potato/carrot/bell pepper mix! Every entree comes with an extra side of the injera. The yogurt that came with the entree and extra injera definitely helped ease the spiciness!

We really enjoyed the unique Eritrean baskets, gourds, and pictures in the restaurant! There's an awesome coffee maker near the kitchen! :)
author: Kei H.

description:
So came here with a friend for dinner months ago and we ordered the meat combo. We were the only customers there so service was fast and courteous.  Two other patrons had only walked in after we got our bill. 

The injera was soft and fresh and went perfectly well with the entrees.  I had a glass of their honey wine and it was deliciously good. I love Ethiopian food and it taste just like Indian cuisine.  I loved the atmosphere because it was quiet and business was slow. We could eat away with our hands without any onlookers; but it being slow seemed kinda odd for a good restaurant in the city.    

Despite the lack of customers, I would come back for more of that honey wine :)
author: LC B.

description:
It was good, but just wasn't my thing. I enjoyed eating with my hands and the staff was super friendly but I wasn't into the food. I feel bad for giving a 3 because the presentation was appealing and the owner was so nice. 

The food is served over injera (ethiopian bread). After you eat all the food on top of the injera, the injera that is on the bottom soaks up all the juices from the food that was sitting on top. Although that wet bread is considered "the best part" I considered it soggy and mushy. Come here and try it for yourself! Don't let my 3 stars keep you away--I guess I'm not much of a Ethiopian food person. EVERYONE should try this place for the unique experience.

Ordered the veggie combo.
author: Logan N.

description:
The usual suspect dishes (vegetarian combination, meat combination) were okay.  Extremely filling.  Service was friendly. 

Entire restaurant smelled like smoke.
author: Di Yin L.

description:
I dropped in here for dinner on a Saturday evening after seeing a movie at The Bridge.  I was there on the early side (5:15pm) and only one other table had patrons when I walked in, but by 5:30pm almost all the tables were full.  That was a good sign because the outside of the restaurant was nondescript, so I knew it must be a destination place for people.

The dining room was a little sparse with the decorations and didn't have a lot of ambiance, but the food and service more than made up for it.  Since I was alone, I couldn't try a lot of things on the menu.  Fortunately, the entrees were all served with lentils and a little salad, so I was still able to experience several different tastes and textures.

I love spicy, so for my entree I chose Kelwa-Derho (chicken cubes sauteed with clarified butter, hot pepper, jalapenos, onion, and tomato).  In addition to the side salad and lentils, there was also a dollop of yogurt which was good for cooling down the spice.  The whole meal was served on top of injera, which is the spongy bread that you use to eat your food.

Oh, I did mention that you get to eat with your hands, right?  (They offered me a fork if I wanted it, but there was no way I'd pass up a chance to eat with my hands!)

I should also mention that I really liked the injera here.  I've been to some places where the injera was a little too sour for my taste and overwhelmed some of the flavors, but that wasn't the case here.

The prices were really reasonable.  I had a glass of Sauvignon Blanc for $5.25 and my main entree was only $13.95.

Another plus?  A MUNI stop right outside the front door.  Score!
author: Kimberly B.

description: Terrific food. If I lived here, I would be back often. Friendly and nice people and place. Try the Eritrean beer and the honey wine, too.
author: Nancy F.

description:
Haven't been there in a couple of years so I  decided to take a "virgin" for a taste of East Africa. Ordered the samosa's, which were crunchy and spicy just like I like them and two glasses of honey wine.

It was downhill from there. Doro tibsy, watered down and just bland. The yogurt is still good tho. My dinning partner ordered the gored gored and it was awful. She has a few bites but she did not know what to expect since it was her first time. 
We sat there starring at each other..hmm.. that's it?!! To make matters worse the server just dumps the food instead of asking us if we would like to take the food to go. SMH. 

I remember going there regularly a few years ago and it used to be good just like Mom's cooking. Highly dissapointed.
I will gladly take a ride to Oakland for good Eri/Ethio food.
author: Sofie Z.

description:
This place is such an excellent restaurant: unique, inviting, and most importantly offering up delicious food.

Call me ignorant, but I had to look on a map to know where Eritrea was located.  Short answer is it's on the east coast of Africa north of Ethiopia.  The influences from the area are quite readily apparent in the food comprising of a mixture of Middle Eastern and traditional African dishes.  This confluence of tastes and textures is fantastic.  Pair the exotic flavors with the unique experience of eating with your hands using an injera, a spongy pancake, to gather up the food, and what you get is a happily memorable food event.

Whenever I'm in San Francisco I have to make it to Assab. Simply awesome.
author: Graham O.

description: This family owned restaurant is definitely a awesome find. The food is fresh and amazing, if you like curry you will love this place. Depending on what you order it might take some time, I don't mind waiting because the food is really good.
author: Sobashi W.

description:
Food gets a five. Service is super friendly, polite, but just not efficient.
Got the meat sampler and vege sampler - both of which were superb.
Physical space is quite simple but clean.
They take credit card which I've found to be hit/miss in SF.
I'm definitely coming back!
author: Varun V.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of Ethiopian food but this restaurant has completely changed my opinion (and that is not an easy feat.)   Based on the name, I assume that the cuisine is Eritrean but everything on the menu seemed similar enough to Ethiopian that most dishes seemed familiar, including the spongy, sour flat bread.

This place is conveniently walking distance of The Bridge theater on Geary.   My friend and I came in from the rain and were warmly welcomed by the staff.  Throughout the night, the entire restaurant was served by one woman and she was always smiling and very helpful in helping us choose what dishes to order.   

Because of my intense hatred of cilantro, it is a habit of mine to always ask if it is used in any particular dishes or as a garnish.  Imagine my surprise and joy when she replied that the chef has an allergy to cilantro and it is NEVER used in their food.  "No Cilantro.  Ever."  is a mantra close to my heart and music to my ears; this restaurant has endeared itself to me forever. 

The food?  Very good. We chose to share the vegetarian sampler and also the potato dish. I am sensitive to very spicy food and was pleased that the food was mild yet intensely flavored.  For those looking to set your mouth on fire, this place might not be for you. I chose to drink beer (Anchor Steam, I think) so I can't comment on the beverage menu.  

Bottom line, if you are in throwing distance of the Bridge and would like to get dinner to round out your evening, the food and the service is well worth it and both are solid 4 stars.  I'm adding a 5th star for being awesomely cilantro-free.
author: Courtney Y.

description: It was my first time eating Eritrian food and it was interesting. There's tons of variety, which I love. Service is a bit slow but the food is worth it.
author: Leslie C.

description:
I must have passed by this spot countless times while driving along Geary, and finally I had my interest satisfied. Now being an idiot that I am, I cannot tell you if the difference between Ethiopian or Eritrean food; however, they seem similar in taste and presentation so comparison to Ethiopian food was how I based my review of their food. 

Our group of 6 all got an ordered an entrée and decided to get it family style, which consisted of a large bowl in the center of our table with a layer of Injera housing our entrée orders of salad, meats, yogurt, chickpeas/lentils and greens. I remind you that this is not a restaurant you want to surprise your group of friends to, because some may get persnickety about eating with your hands; you also want to be sure people wash their hands and get under their fingernails when eating family style. 

The injera is a soft and spongy flatbread in a usage similar to a tortilla or naan and a-bit sour to the palate. They give a decent size piece of injera on your plate and you are more than welcome to eat the one in the bowl as it sops up all the flavors of your entrees. 

The cubed skinless chicken breast were succulent and rich and was the most mild of the dishes even when it was paired with the sautéed peppers and jalapenos. The lamb was seasoned spicy and was flavorful with the injera sourness. The beef was also seasoned spicy but was a nice smooth texture paired with injera. 

Overall the selection for food we had was delicious and I would come back for that reason alone. The wait staff was not lenient in alteration of the menu when ordering and they were not too fluent in English, which made it difficult understanding the menu for my table companions. Food was generally spicy, so those with a sensitive palate may find themselves struggling; I only know I had an amazing meal. Luckily as a walk-in on a weekend late in the afternoon we were able to get a table immediately. 

With the other reviews on hand, I will be back and try the Honey Wine everyone is raving about.
author: Casey L.

description:
Was craving Ethiopian food. Well, actually, was craving indian food but had had indian the night before....welcome to my life....so wanted something lighter than indian food, hence... was craving Ethiopian food.

Tried this place for the first time per raves below, it was A-OK. the food wasn't too flavorful, the OMG ITS SO GOOD HONEY WINE was A-OK. just tasted like cheap white wine stirred w honey literally nothing too OMG THIS IS AMAZING.

Service was slow.
author: Ami Y.

description:
Our favorite in the neighborhood.... Love the food!! We keep going back again  n again n again.. never disappointed... An absolute gem in the area!!!

Will be 1st choice any day!
author: Neetha V.

description:
Isn't it weird how much you can build a place up in your head?  For me, Assab was just an "ok" experience. 

Family style is definitely the way to go when you're eating Ethiopian/Eritrean.  The two of us ordered a spicy chicken dish and a lamb dish family style.  The two entrees come out on a single platter just the way I like it, accompanied with beans, lentils, a dollop of yogurt, and a small salad.  The lamb tasted especially good. 

The cons of our experience - the entree portions were too small and there wasn't enough meat in each to make up for the $13 price.  Also, the entrees come with a set amount of injera, which was enough for me - but if you need more they charge extra. 

While this was a good experience (and the owner was really nice), the food and atmosphere did not compare to Cafe Colucci in Oakland.  For me, Colucci continues to set the standard as having the best injera, delicious meat entrees, and perfect accompanying side dishes.
author: Kimya P.

description:
I think this place is fun for a first time. 

We called to see if they take reservations or if we could put our name down. They told us no reservations on Friday. We got there, and there were two tables with "reserved" signs on them! ...???????

Took them 10 minutes to come to recognize us and ask them how long the wait would be. She said she'll give us an estimate when she can come up with one. 

ANYWAYS.. we waited for over 30 minutes. Then waited another 20 for our food. This was 8pm already

We ordered the Mushroom, a chicken dish, a beef and the lamb dish. I liked the lamb the best because the meat was tender and flavors were good. Chicken was good too but they give you TWO DRUMSTICKS and the item costs like 13$. Beef was wayyy overcooked. It was really hard but the only reason why it was okay was because everything else was mushy texture. 

OH another thing. I had NO idea what I was eating the whole time. Would've loved an explanation. And maybe a wet nap or something after the meal. 

Honey wine was tooooo sweet. I guess it was good with the food. but don't try to drink it by itself.


Overall I think this place needs to work on their service if they're gona charge people this much for food. I really don't think it's worth it.
author: Erica L.

description:
Disclaimer: This review is going to start with one of those "I had XYZ life experience(s) that thus makes me qualified to judge the quality and authenticity of this lesser-known ethnic cuisine". If you hate it when people say things like that, you might want to skip the intro to this review.

I haven't lived in Eritrea or Ethiopia but I have been enjoying the food from this region since I was a teen. (It's not hard when you grow up in what is arguably the most multicultural city in the world.) It is one of my favorite cuisines and I have eaten it in many of the major cities in North America. For the last few years, I've worked for a global non-profit that does humanitarian work in Ethiopia. Many of my colleagues were Ethiopian and, let's just say, if you're a foodie like me, you can't help but learn a lot about authentic Ethiopian/Eritrean food (and get to sample homemade stuff at company potlucks--mmmm!)

So there. My qualifications.

Assab Eritrean Restaurant is around 3.5 stars for food quality, but I gave it that extra half star for exceptional service (details to follow). My friend organized a group dinner here before her big trip to London so our party of 8 was the largest party in the restaurant. We started with meat sambusas, which are essentially fritters stuffed with seasoned ground beef. The shell was a nice crisp texture, but the meat was bland and dry. Definitely not enough seasoning. It was also incredibly oily so be careful when you're eating it.

For the main dinner, we ordered:

- Kitfo: Ground beef sauteed with clarified butter and seasoned hot peppers, topped with homemade cottage cheese. We got it medium because my friend didn't want to get food poisoning before her trip, but I highly recommend ordering this rare if you can.

- Zigni & Okra Mix: Cubed beef simmered with clarified butter, onions, tomatoes, and seasoned hot pepper, served with yogurt

- Alicha Beggee: Cubed, mildly-seasoned lamb shank simmered with potatoes, carrots and bell peppers

- Tsebhi Derho: Skinless chicken legs and or thighs on the bone simmered with clarified butter, onions, tomatoes, seasoned hot pepper and yogurt

The Kitfo was tasty but lacking in spices. The Zigni was delicious but there definitely wasn't enough okra. I loved the Alicha Beggee and the lamb jus over the vegetables, but this is definitely not a dish for those who don't like lamb because the seasoning does not even begin to cover up that taste. The Tsebhi Derho was fall-off-the-bone (literally) tender and the obvious favorite in our group. Our meal came with complimentary helpings of collard greens and lentils, conveniently placed in four spots along the injera so that everyone could reach some. The injera itself was generous in portion but a bit too soggy. I think they needed to use more teff.

OK, so the service. Initially, I was put off by our brusque, grumpy server. He was the only one working so service was very, very slow (the restaurant was mostly full). However, about 20 minutes into our dinner, in a fit of gesticulating excitement, I accidentally knocked over my nearly-full glass of honey wine (splashing some of it onto my poor boyfriend). Our waiter immediately appeared with napkins and cloths to wipe up the mess and cheerfully waved away my attempts to help, reassuring me in a light, jolly tone that it was okay and he'd take care of it. He left and re-appeared with another glass of honey wine. It was a very generous pour and easily twice as much as I had spilled. He left it with me with a joke that next time, if I didn't like it, I should just send it back instead of spilling it on my boyfriend. So....yeah. Service good.

Now, some words of advice for the uninitiated:

- Ethiopian/Eritrean food is always eaten with your hands so be prepared
- Injera is sour, spongey and soft. It's unlike any bread known to the Western world so please don't walk in expecting baguettes or naan or that soft, sweet Asian white bread
- Main dishes/stews served on injera are always packed with exotic spices so your hands will smell for hours after, no matter how many times you wash them
- Ethiopian/Eritrean food is NOT Indian food, it's NOT Moroccan food, it's NOT Bengali/Sri Lakan/Pakistani/Burmese/Nepalese food so please ignore anyone who tells you it is because they're wrong and if you believe them, you're just going to be disappointed. There are certainly culinary influences and shared spices, but it is very much its own unique cuisine
- Honey wine is delicious and the perfect complement, so definitely try it if you can (though I don't think Assab's is the best honey wine I've ever had)

Happy eating!
author: Josephine L.

description: Shared between three: two different beefs, one chicken, and a pile of mushrooms, plus one meat and one veggie sambusa...this feast was SO GOOD. Also had an Ethiopian amber ale.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Although the initial welcome wasn't that welcoming here, the food was fantastic. 

We walked in about 7pm on a Saturday and found the place lively but not packed.  A woman asked if we had a reservation, which was rather surprising since I didn't realize you needed a reservation here.  We said no and she seemed pissed.  She walked away, so we just stood there looking dumbfounded.  Eventually another woman asked us to come take a seat at an empty table she was preparing.  Important to note that there were in fact 3 or 4 other empty tables.  

This woman was MUCH nicer than the other one.  We ordered one of the cubed beef dishes (not sure which one), one of the lamb dishes (again, not sure) and the shiro (chickpeas) for the 3 of us to share. 

I never had Ethiopian food, but knew that it was served on bread and you eat with your hands.  It came out on a giant platter and everyone gets their own individual injera (the spongy bread).  

We dug in like the hungry pigs that we were and it was absolutely delicious and FUN to eat.  Yes, eating with ones hand is quite the novelty these days.  Make sure everyone at the table washes their hands, because this shit gets messy.  

The chickpeas, although really mushy, was my favorite.  It was super flavorful and blended well with the other items on the plate.  There were pickled veggies and other greens that I couldnt identify but tasted really good.  The beef was really tasty, although the lamb was a little too spicy for my taste.  

It may not seem like a ton of food, it really does fill you up.  I think the bread expands in your stomach, so be careful not to overeat or you'll feel like you're about to explode.  

Also, avoid the honey wine - its way too sweet.  Better offer getting a beer here.  Would definitely come back here again if in the area.  The food was awesome and the price was affordable.
author: Jaci H.

description:
Shared dinner with a couple others. Let's see, we got the meat combination, vegetable combination, kelwa derho, and another lamb dish. Decided to go family style so we could all try a little bit of something. 

Perks: Really enjoyed the bread (I believe its called injera) at this place. It wasn't too sour which was good.
Spinach, yogurt dip, and potatoes were all fantastic. Other food had excellent flavor, eritrean is at about the peak of my spice tolerance so some may not have been enjoyed as much as others.

The not so perky: service. We sat down and waited, waited, and then waited more. We kept looking at the server and tried to flag him down (which shouldn't have been difficult because he was only a few feet away), but it seemed like we waited a bunch more. One the order was taken, wait for food felt long, but wasn't quite as bad as the wait to get service. This was surprising because there wasn't a whole lot of action during the earlyish dinner hour either. Hmm...
author: Lily K.

description: A very solid experience. Family owned and operated and a great family style place. The good is always consistent and just outstanding. This is one of our favorites in SF!
author: Vivek S.

description:
A friend recommended coming here for my birthday, so I did and the food turned out amazing!!!

It was my first time having Ehtiopian food as well, and I must say I was more than just impressed. Even though we ended up coming late due to the terrible traffic, the owner/waiters still greeted us politely and had everybody seated promptly. They had a great variety of both savory and vegetarian dishes. I got to share a bit of everything with my friends (chicken, lamb, beef, mushroom) and I couldn't even find a reason to complain about the food. We all ended up pretty full!

When the bill came out, it was not really close to "heart-breaking", of which I'm grateful. I would have felt bad because I was "exempted" for being the birthday girl.
author: Miiiiei P.

description:
This is my absolute favorite restaurant. Of all time. Ever. 

I really could write a novel, but all the words in the world could never truly capture just how incredible this place is. My mouth starts watering when I even think about it. No joke.

Do yourself a favor and go. Don't be in a rush, but GO.
author: J B.

description: It's meh - the flavors were very mild and understated, which is strange for Ethiopian cuisine. I'm used to eating at Zeni's and Mudai and Walia in the South Bay. They blow Assab out of the water in terms of flavor and price. The entrees come with one injera, extra injera is $.75! I've never seen that before. Service was just OK. The place was empty at 7:30 on a Friday night - we were the only 5 people there.
author: Beni D.

description:
If it were possible to give zero stars I would not have even given Assab 1 star. I have never had such an experience at any restaurant.

My friends and I drove past this restaurant and immediately stopped because it looked like it would be just what we were craving, unfortunately we never even got a chance to try the food.

When we walked into the restaurant it took a few minutes for the staff to decide how to seat us, there were 5 and every table only sat 4. they were not accommodating at all and refused to put 2 tables together and instead suggested we sit apart. Shortly after the restaurant cleared out at once and we were able to get a larger table. 

Once seated we went over the menu and attempted to order. 2 of us just wanted soup and drinks, 1 wasn't eating and the other 2 ordered full entrees. The waiter (pretty sure he was also the owner) looked so clearly irritated with our order, rolled his eyes and flat out said that was unacceptable. He said it was a waste of their time to have a table that only had 2 entrees ordered. We were shocked and not at all understanding that he was trying to tell us to leave so a woman came up to explain it more clearly. The restaurant was 80% empty and yet they were still turning away our business, which still would have been at least $60. The woman said they were expecting larger parties and they would rather wait than serve us. For the record we are not riff-raff or young teens, we are grown adults that are clearly not homeless and would have been paying customers. 

I don't know if this is common practice for this restaurant or if for some reason they just didn't like our multi-cultural group either way I will never ever return and hope that other patrons do not support a business that operates in such a manner.
author: Michelle B.

description: My experience here was overall satisfying. The service was a bit slow but that was due to the mom and pop feel of the restaurant. The food was delicious I ordered the Kitfo beef and the Kelwa chicken. As my first time eating Ethiopian cuisine, I was pleasantly satisfied. I would definitely give this restaurant another try or get take out.
author: Hayley G.

description:
I have the fondest memories of this restaurant. I've been going here every year or so since I was about 13. I'm now 23 and still my mouth waters whenever I think about this place. Madias (I'm sure I'm spelling that wrong) the owners is the sweetest man and has always treated me and my family like VIPs.

I've tried MULTIPLE Eritrean restaurants in Chicago and Los Angeles and have not been able to find anything that even comes REMOTELY close to how delicious the food is at Assab.

My favorite: The meat Sambusa.

I promise you will not be disappointed.
author: Jillian A.

description: I came here with the recommendation of my ethiopian colleague, and was not disappointed. Kitfo (raw ground beef) with home made cottage cheese and mitmitaa (chilly powder) was excellent. Liked the okra main dish and sambusa appetizer as well. The rippasso (baby amerone) wine by glass at $7.50 was a steal.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I live in soma and my friends live in Potrero Hill. You know this place is pretty worth it when we drove across the city to eat here. A group of 8 came here on a weeknight for some awesome Ethiopian food. Family style is always the best way to share with friends.  Umm... as for what we actually ordered, I can't give you the actual names. But there is one dish that includes the 3 things on the menu and we ordered all 3 things separately so we could get more food.
The spicy chicken with the whole boiled egg has always been my favorite. The sauce is finger licking good and we nearly licked everything off the platter.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Assab is a wonderful, clean restaurant owned and run by a charming family who value great service. It's exactly what you can expect from Ethiopian food. It's a fresh, spicy, mixture of cool and hot lentils, spinach, and yogurt to dip injera in. Be carful though, the injera is very filling. 
We ordered the vegetable platter as well as a samosa. The samosa was fried crispy on the outside and filled with a spicy peas and starchy vegetables. The portions were huge and perfect to share. The servers were pleasant and the space was well cared for.
author: Nicole S.

description: I can't say enough about how good the food was and what a warm and welcoming vibe this place has. My friend and I came here on a weeknight for dinner. Everything I had tasted very good and the prices are reasonable. We split the veg and meat samplers and even that was way more than we could finish. I also tried the honey wine. It's nothing extravagant but also tasty and different for me. The restrooms were impressively clean and stocked. I'll go back here for sure.
author: Yolanda Y.

description: VERY friendly staff/owners.  Assab is definitely my favorite Ethiopian place in the city.
author: Daisy A.

description:
I LOVE this place. I wish they were open on Sundays, since we often like to eat out then. Their kitfo is perfect in spice and texture. Their injira is spongy and fits right with the flavors. 

This is the first Ethiopian place I ever tried. I am forever ruined. Trust me, I've tried.
author: Kristin N.

description: walked in, restaurant was essentially empty, stood at the door for about 2 minutes until the waitress's friend pointed out to her that I was standing there.  she seated me.  I sat for another 4-5 minutes and no one said a word or otherwise acknowledged my presence.  I got up and walked out. I don't think they noticed I left.  I realize that not all cultures treat the idea of time and by extension customer service the same.  but sheesh! never again.
author: Darren M.

description:
Food that we got was okayish but they ran out of the appetizers at 9 pm on a Saturday.

Also we ordered a veggie platter which included okra but since they were out of it they replaced with mushrooms without bothering us to inform about it.
author: Bhanik S.

description:
I came here with a party of 10 for my birthday.  Will never come back--the service was extremely rude.  The owner was very difficult to deal with, and the opposite of gracious.    We weren't being a pain, either.  Just don't recommend going for larger parties than, say, four.    
   That said, the food was pretty good.
author: Emily D.

description: OMG. one of the best food experiences! i love ethnic foods, and absolutely loved this place! food is absolutely delicious with lots of flavor and tons of options. i absolutely loved the lamb dish (forgot exactly what it was called), nad their "rare meat" dish was also amazing. would definitely definitely come back here at any day!!! loved it. oh and it was  also fun to be able to eat with hands.
author: Jenn S.

description:
No other Bay Area Eritrean place I've experienced measures up to Assab. This place has better, stronger, spicier flavors and better honey wine. And good tea!

I've eaten here four times over the last two or three years or so and each visit has been equally great, so points for consistency.

Bonus: My hands smell like Eritrean food for a couple hours afterward.

Double bonus: It makes me want to eat my hands, but I haven't -- yet.
author: Sean M.

description:
I don't know what it is about Eritrean food. Could it be the exotic flavors and spices? The family style meal? The person I choose to go on this culinary adventure with? Who knows, maybe I just like eating with my hands.

I would recommend ordering both the meat & veggie combination plates. The meat plate comes with delicious lamb, beef, and chicken. The veggie combo comes with potatoes, carrots, bell peppers, okra, and zucchini. There was also a little yogurt, salad, lentils, and spinach in there too. And all atop of an injera! The most unique bread around.

And no, the service wasn't speedy. But there is something to be said about authentic, homemade, fresh food. Not to mention a server that is all by himself. In a city that is going so fast all the time, it's sure nice to slow down and this is the perfect place to do that.
author: Briana F.

description:
It was good.  But I've had better.  The one in the Mission or on Haight St are better.  This place didn't have fish.  The veggie combo was lacking in the robust flavors that I usually find at other restaurants.  The potato and cauliflower were good.  The okra - eh.  The zuchini - ok.  The lentils - eh.

Service was really slow.  We had to constantly yell to get their attention even though there was hardly anyone in the restaurant.

Plus there was an unpleasant odor when u first walk in....like clorox plus spices.
author: C A.

description: As soon as I entered this restaurant my mouth started watering--and with good reason! The food is delicious and very reasonably priced. Going again tonight for the second time in a week!
author: Jenna C.

description:
It just gets better everytime I come here.


First of all, the waiter (not the waitress) is SO freaking sweet. I want to put him in my pocket. He is so helpful and adorable, I just love him.

We always come around 630-7 and there are plenty of seats around... which I find ridculous because people should be flocking to here to eat. Its SO GOOD!

Food:
#3 beef (Zigni): this is my number one, flavor and texture for the win
#4 chicken (Tsebhi Derho): number two, meat fell off the bone and I wanted to eat the bone too
#5 chicken (Kelwa Derho): it was better the first time I had it for some reason
#8 lamb: it just tastes like curried lamb, pretty darn good still

#13 Veg. Alicha: it's like curried potatoes. Very good!
#14 Okra: winner for the veggie dishes
#15 Zucchini: runner up for the veggies, so light and flavorful

Just the fact that I can really pig out and stuff my face with my hands makes this place amazing!!! Oh and try the honey wine and guava juice too! It will help you when you can't handle the spicy.
author: Emily T.

description:
This is one of the best Ethiopian food I've ever had and I am definitely going back. 

We ordered a combo meat platter and combo vegetarian platter. It was the perfect size for a group of four with extremely generous portions. Their bread was really good, not too sour and the okra and beef were the best things on the plate. I wish I had remembered what the beef was sauteed in, but jalapenos was one of them. The chicken was tender and very well cooked.

Our server was extremely nice, very attentive and explained everything really well. Its a nice family restaurant you can be loud in and no one is pretentious.
author: Analisa S.

description: Ok food and service is also very slow and at times to felt as if the server ( only one person, seems he is also the owner of the place) had forgotten us! I have much had better Ethiopian food in the bay area and with better ambiance and service.
author: Abhinav T.

description: I'm not an expert on Ethiopian food but have eaten it several times. This unassuming spot had delicious, light injera and a variety of good flavors in their veggie combo plate. The dollop of yogurt was a tasty contrast as well. We also tried a chicken dish that was tender and, though it was marked with a "spicy" asterisk, we did not find it so.
author: Nora B.

description:
Great food, but be prepared for judgement if planning on enjoying your meal alone...  

I'm pretty sure the waiters response to my "Just one please" was " Uggghhgh... "


I'll still go back. Haha
author: Cassie B.

description:
I would highly suggest coming on a week day night = less busy! 

I really love this place. The smells, the flavors: all on point! 

1. one order of chicken (light spicy)
2. one order of beef (light spicy)
3. two sambusas. one beef and one veggie

the beef sambusa was on point! that thing was like ... a spicy beefy taco pocket but BETTER, WAYYYY BETTER. 

and when that huge platter of food came out? i was so excited to down that food. It was all so good, perfectly seasoned food with a nice kick in the end. 

only downside? it's a bid of a wait for the food since they have to prepare it all individually.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Extremely mediocre.

Yelp definitely did me wrong. Lazy service. Frozen and precooked ingredients. Not coming back here. 

I love erhiopian food so im not turned off to the whole cuisine. If this is going to be your first try, theres lots of better places.
author: Kamille R.

description: Outstanding! If you know what to expect w/Etheopian I'd say you'll be plenty happy with the flavor and if you like good service you'll be pleasantly pleased in that department as well.
author: Patrick W.

description: I was finally convinced to come have eritrean after so many months if putting it off and I finally came. And I had a delicious meal. The Injera with the Meat combo and okra/lentil dips were so goid. I had never had it before and I was blown away by the tenderness of the meat and its alot of fun to eat with your hands. The place was busy when we came and got our food in 20 minutes. A tad expensive but worth it for the luxury of tasting another culture. Its an adventure in itself! ^_^
author: Adam T.

description:
This place was definitely a surprise. I've been living in the Inner Richmond for 6 years and until yesterday, I had no idea what I was missing.

Service could've been better (we went at a pretty low-traffic time and sometimes had to work for their attention), but their food definitely made up for it. My friend and I shared a huge platter with veggies, ground beef, chicken, lamb, and pork, and it was all good. The dollop of yogurt was invaluable considering how spicy it was.

For the price (around 14-19 depending on the dish your order), the portions and quality are good.

If you're not used to eating with just your hands, get ready. If you're not into it, then this place probably isn't for you.

I definitely want to come back and try some of their other dishes. I wouldn't come by myself; definitely recommend coming here as a group.
author: Raymond B.

description: I enjoyed this place a lot. be proactive when looking for a table, because you will be ignored for quite a while. but other than than, it was great. oh - don't go if you're in a rush, either. it was a while ago i went, so i can't give specifics, but i'm definitely going back, if that helps.
author: ian s.

description:
Reasons why your quest for Ethiopian food is now over:

1. OUTSTANDING SERVICE! 
The charming owner was attentive without being intrusive, our waters were refilled by the half cup watermark, and our dinner was served within 15 minutes after placing our order.

2. MOUTH WATERING FOOD!
The accompanying injera is a spongy cross between a crepe and sourdough bread,  and perfectly complimented the entrees.
I sampled the lamb and beef, both flavorful and not spicy. The deliciously seasoned sides of lentils and spinach melt in your mouth, and even the yogurt is heavenly, creamy with a slight tanginess. The honey wine is the nectar that will consummate your dining experience.

3. PRICE..
$13-17 per item.
Appetizers are $3-8. Maybe pricier than other places, but the entire experience is worth every dollar. Trust.
author: Gabriella C.

description:
I'll make this short...

Con: Service is slow but worth it. Suggestion... only come here if you are up for waiting. Go with some friends who can hold a conversation, order some wine, and relax while they conjure up some delicious food for you.

If you haven't tried Ethiopian food, try it! If you have, and are looking for a great place in SF, come here! The food here is great.. mouth watering just thinking about what to order great. I make it a point to come here every time I am in the area and looking for a hearty meal.
author: Emma C.

description:
I actually thought this was a vegetarian place due to the giant awards banner for vegetarian food. But fear not my carnivorous friends, you can enjoy your meats here.

The food is basically some sauces / beans / veggies / meats served on a bed of this really spongy bread. You're supposed to tear off pieces of the bread and use it to scoop up the foodstuffs and then shove it into your mouth. It's really fun finger food and the sauces are all very good and flavorful.

Remember, yogurt is to cut the spicy if you can't handle it!

Expect everything to be dirty by the end.
author: Ethan R.

description:
Still feeling the loss of Massawa on Haight, I decided to fill the void by finding another Eritrean Restaurant and I I've driving by this place several times but never thought to try it.  Well now the opportunity has presented itself and my sis and I went there this past Friday on a a date.

I loved the decor, feels authentic and homey. Another plus is the tables are not sandwiched, so you don't feel like you're having dinner with the table next to you.  This is definitely a good place for a date, not too loud or fancy.  Only drawback is its PRICEY.  Which is unfortunate because I would like to come here just as much as I went to Massawa, but I cannot  afford it.  $15 for the vegetable platter is a bit steep, $12-13 is plenty.

Another, pitfall was the injera was little on the thin side which made it hard to eat with my hands...which is the whole point, NO SPOONS PLEASE.  If you come here try to do it how they do in their country...I'm just saying.

Flavors were good and I left quite full!  Overall, I recommend this place and I will be back eventually...maybe I can get someone to take me on a date here ;-)
author: Molly M.

description:
Best Eritrean food I've had. The honey wine is great too. Easy to get to on the 38 bus lines, so very convenient even if you don't live nearby.
They're closed on Sundays though!! :-(
author: Ariana L.

description:
Food is decent, that's why I gave it two stars. 

Service is awful. Perhaps it's because we're a bunch of 20 year olds walking into the restaurant. The waiter did not serve us until 10+ minutes later, he served everyone else first. Wouldn't bring out our water until we asked him, food wasn't even that great.   I suggest you try a different place.
author: Jenny N.

description:
We ordered the vegetable combo (zucchini, okra, and some other thing) and the meat combo (lamb, chicken leg, and something else) arranged onto one giant plate. The food is arranged as many small glops on a large injera (a thin, spongy bread). The injera, having the structural fortitude of a fragile crepe, was difficult to use as a scooping instrument, but the taste went well with the various kinds of glop. The meat sampler was good but the other things left me underwhelmed, although I'm not omitting the possibility that perhaps my years as a vegan have left me with a reluctance towards stewed lentils. However, everything was quite edible.  It was the kind of food that you would most enjoy if you're really hungry, and not just out to nibble and sample exotic viands.
Also, hilarious: the absence of napkins.
author: Caralee N.

description:
As I understand it there is a little East Bay/SF rivalry regarding Eritrean food. Some say the East Bay is the best but this little gem can hold its own. Located on Geary in Laural Heights. 

Service is fast and friendly. We ordered the vegetarian combo family style it was not as spicy as I like and asked for some additional spice. The owner hesitated and said he didn't have any additional spice and then came back with a bright red chile paste. That did the trick. I smeared it on the injera like butter and then scooped up the food, problem solved. 

Having said all that, I live in Sacramento and our Queen of Sheeba still has my top Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurant.
author: Coral H.

description:
Really bad experience. We were very hungry and desperate and I actually had a great memory of the only other time I had Ethiopian food which was in Cambridge, MA 's Central Square so we went in here with three other friends. 

They tried Honey Wine and they all hated it. I only decided to have the vegetarian platter that had all their 5 veg dishes in there. Not that I am a fan of Ethiopian bread but this was really bad and sour. The food was too spicy and my friends who had the meat versions got sick at night and the next day they spent a good portion of day in the bathroom.

The Service: was really bad. They didn't greet us when we entered. They didn't even give us table. The waitress with her eyes at the counter indicated that we could choose our seats. 

The menu was confusing. It was clear that platters were only for vegetarian food and not the others.

Price: for what they gave us was way too expensive!! Seriously .. bad food, bad service and Vegetarian food was $8-9 each and Meat food was $13 each!
author: T I.

description:
Ethopian food is my NEW FAVOURITE FOOD

When you grew up with your parents telling--sorry, YELLING--"hold your knife correctly, dammit!"

This is the absolute perfect place to do the proverbial flip off and eat with your hands. The chicken and brown/red lentil dish was fricking AWESOME on all these levels of awesome you just can't imagine. Eating ineja, which tastes like the inside of sourdough bread (the best part), is even better. I can't imagine wanting to eat anywhere else.

Unless, of course, you asked me to go with you and paid for it.

That's right. I'm cheap.

Also, honey wine=wonderful dessert wine. YUM! Seriously? Go here. Fuck Mel's diner (the place I went in this 'hood the last time I hungover-ly walked my ass for however long), I want Ethopian food from Assab!

And I really have to quote Matt R., now. "I'd say it's "right" as long as it's not stuck into one of your dining companions.  And that's not always wrong, either."

Yes, yes it is. Just don't go with someone you'd like to stab. You'll be wholly disappointed you would have to do it with your hands.
author: Jaime L.

description: Yummmmm! This place is the best. After trying Ethiopian food in Chicago, New York and Detroit, I can say that this is hands down the best I've had. The vegetarian sampler platter is just the best! I do wish that the food was a touch spicier, but maybe that is not traditional? Either way, it is super delicious. The service is lovely and they have Anchor Steam on the menu- perfection.
author: Lauren F.

description: This relatively inexpensive restaurant serves the best Kitfo (rare beef/beef tartar) that I have ever had.  The portions are substantial, which is the norm for ethiopian, and each dish comes with few side orders including lentils, spinach, and goat cheese.  One entree per person will suffice.  This is a great little place with a really great vibe for a mellow date night.  The owner operator is wonderful, and treats each costumer with warm welcome.
author: john b.

description:
This review is not about the food, neither is it about the lack of service, which is poor at the least. I visit this place every-time I am in SF, been there about half a dozen times. I am usually very difficult to upset. I can put up with a lot of nonsense without being flustered. Poor service by a servers rarely upsets me-they are people and they have their bad days and I always give them benefit of doubt. This time at Assab was different.
On all previous occasions, the service was slow and the servers indifferent, unhelpful and often plain rude- I accepted it as an eccentricity of this restaurant. 
Yesterday, I called in for a table for 9 at 6.15 PM. We reached at 6.20PM per my watch, and about 6.17 per Assabs clock. (I am very particular about time). A lady came up to us, in a no-happy mood, and yelled that since we didn't make it by 6.15, she gave the table to another family. She was upset at us on not making it on time. Now, given their casual and slow service, clearly this family arrived before 6.15 and were seated on a table that we were promised.
At any other restaurant or service, I would expect an apology and an effort to find an alternative. Not here friends. I was indifferently told to pick any two disjoint tables. There was one with 7 seats, I asked. Nope, that's reserved for a 7PM, she said. How about another one, there? Nope not available. She would not put together two tables! And this at a time where there were only two sets of customers, the restaurant was screaming empty!
She clearly did not want us in the restaurant. While I was standing disillusioned, my wife lost it and made it know to the lady, that any other restaurant would allow for a 10 minute grace (and here we have a empty restaurant). That pissed her off even more. I walked to the counter and asked  to speak to the supervisor. It happens that our 'friendly' lady was the owner, lol. The mom of this mom-pop joint. On a note, the table was offered to someone of an African descent. I am a south Asian. I have never experienced racism in 14 years in this country, and I am now questioning if this was one instance.

There was new server (never seen her before) who apologized and tried to mend things, but as I mentioned, we were not wanted. Needless to say we walked away, and thanks to yelp, went down to Oscars café, about a mile away. We were not disappointed. 
Assab, if you happen to read this: treat people with respect, good food can take you only so far. No one is indispensable, and there are alternatives.
And to the nice young lady server, run away from this joint-you do not want to become like your bosses!
As of food, after a while, it tastes the same across the restaurants-Zenis, Mudai, Gumbo in south bay, Assab, oscars in SF.
author: Kalpendu P.

description:
I love this place! It's worth a drive to the city!

Two dishes: veggie combo and kelwa derho!

I love this place and the owner is very nice. I am not a big fan of the daughter, but he is always nice!
author: Gitanjali K.

description: I brought my bf here to try ethiopian food for the first time. The food was not the best that I've had but it was pretty good. The service here was great. I've noticed at other ethiopian restaurants that the service was kind of slow, but not here. The only thing that I didn't really like was that they didn't give you much injera and you have to pay for more. Other than that everything was great. Our waitress was super sweet! Would definitely go back. Since they serve two or more entrees family style, its great for families, dates, and friends..... who you know to have clean hands lol
author: Lana P.

description:
YUMMMMMY! Saucy food I can eat with my hands? It just doesn't get any better than that!

Portions are definitely HUGE so bring your A game you fellow fatties! (see pic of food in my pix album)

Beef sambusas: Tender flakey outside, delicious curry-ish flavored beef filling. 

Kantisha mushrooms: I could've eaten a whole giantic plate of these. Super saucy and flavorful with a nice kick to them. Had a really subtle sweet underlying flavor. Oh gawd... you HAVE to order them!

Zigni beef: Tender and spicy! Wrap a lotta mushrooms and a piece of this with a drop of yogurt on it in the inerja bread... you'll be dreaming about it for days! 

Lentils: I'm not a fan of lentils buuuut... I have to admit, theirs we really good! Both had their own distinct flavor and were different but both tasty!

Sidenote: Ask for extra yogurt. It's the perfect sour/tart combo with the spicy food!
author: Beverly T.

description:
Assab is such a little gem of a restaurant! It's places like this that make me even more proud to be a native San Franciscan. Start your meal off with a sambusa of some sort - they're cheap, and always come piping hot and filled with a super flavorful meat or veggie, depending on which you get. 

Eating with your hands does take a little while to get used to, but their bread/pancake, injera, is surprisingly solid enough to hold your food and makes for a great experience. Order a side of injera per person also, and you're bound to be stuffed! I swear it expands in your stomach after your meal, so even if you're wary of how small your meal looks - don't worry. We always get the meat combo, which comes with tender lamb, beef and chicken and dollops of yogurt. The veggie combo is also very good, and the mushroom platter is by far my favorite. Get everything family style so you can share and taste a little bit everything. If you're not a fan of spicy food or have a low tolerance for it, ask for a milder version and it's just as tasty.

I've never really had a better food first experience than I have at Assab, and the burst of flavor that everything is accompanied with really blew my mind. Keep in mind, the injera is fermented so it's sour - but also the perfect balance of fluffy and filling. The only tiny downside is that the service isn't very fast - but the family who owns the restaurant and the staff are always so pleasant and sweet natured, it's hard to mind. Come here with good company, time to kill and ready to eat a fabulous meal.
author: Betty W.

description: The food here was good, but not as awesome as some other spots in the south and east bay.  overall very satisfying tho. Friendly staff. Missed my fav red lentil dish & not thrilled with the extra charge for more injera :(
author: Coco J.

description:
let me start off with the fact that i NEVER had eritrean food before. but after my dinner here, i am a big fan. here's the lowdown:

the service was great- they accommodated my large group of 14 guests without a hitch. the waiter (i think he owns the place actually) was super nice to us. he seems so happy all the time- i can totally see him doing a jig in pharrell's happy video and dancing and taking our orders at the same time.

the food was delish- like i said, it's my first time trying eritrean food so i don't have anything to compare it to but my stomach was super content and i can totally see myself coming back another time. on the other hand, the honey wine was just amazeballs. i am not much of a wine fan- i prefer to stick with whiskeys but the honey wine was THAT good- we demolished 2 bottles within a few minutes.

to top it off, we had to eat with our hands- way cool. it really added to the dining experience- the spongy bread was fun to play with! solid thumbs up.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
RAW GROUND BEEF!

Yes.  Raw.  After having 10 taxis grabbed from me and allowing 5 38 busses to pass because next bus kept promising me that the 38L will be there in 4..3..2..4..3..2 minutes and 15 minutes later when finally getting on said bus being stopped at Powel because the bus driver had to call the police on an unruly rider and have an argument, no fight with another 38L driver blocking traffic down Geary for several minutes more and then after bailing the bus and being rejected by the next cab and then getting what was probably the angriest cab driver in the entire bay area who insisted on driving fast enough to get air born passing Laguna surrounded by frightened drivers while he yelled at the top of his lungs in his thick accent at someone on his cellphone I figured I must be immortal and cursed and only by taking the greatest risk presented would I end the suffering I was destined to endure and atone for the guilt of being over an hour late for my dinner date with one of my best friends, Angelo.

I was happily surprised but not completely surprised when my plans failed miserably and I was served what could only be one of the finest meals I have ever had the pleasure to dig my bare hands in to (which I did wash thoroughly since we were eating family style from the same plate).  I have nothing to compare this meal to since this was my first taste of Eritrean food but let me just say the food was amazing as was the experience.

The flavors seemed to me to be some wonderful marriage of indian and Mediterranean flavors, heavily but skillfully applied. We started with the vegetable and meat sambusa, a filled fried pastry that reminded me of a cross between a samosa and a fried russian meat filled crepe I used to get regularly from the Russian Bakery near Geary and 20th.  The pastry was lightly flaky and the meat filling was russian and Mediterranean in flavor.  The vegetable filling which I liked more than the meat sang of fresh faba beans and was delightfully flavored.

For the main corse we ordered two dishes.  The first, Kifto, a lean ground beef simmered with clarified butter, seasoned hot pepper and topped with homemade cottage cheese which reminded me more of a dry fresh mexican cheese in flavor.  We opted to have it prepared traditional "Raw" style. The flavor and texture was amazing.

The second dish, kel wa-beggee was cubed lamb cooked in clarified butter and seasoned with jalapenos, onions and tomatoes and served with a little yogurt.  

We had our meal served family style which means all of the dishes are served on a large round plate with high walls on top of injera, a spongy crepe like bread.  We each got a 2nd plate with more injera which we used by tearing pieces of it to scoop up the food and eat it.

The food and experience was wonder albeit a little bit messy and the wine we ordered complimented the food well.  By the end I had completely forgotten about my mass transit fiasco and sat in a happy wine and food coma induced haze.

The only thing killed by the raw meat was my stress and fear of this cuisine I had waited so long to try.

At the end of our evening as I walked out of the pig and whistle next door and crossed the street a 38 bus arrived at the stop next to the cross walk and I quickly decided to hop on it and take it the three blocks I was going to walk home.  My bus Karma had returned.

I am a big fan.
author: Theron L.

description:
What an experience!  I am not very adventurous when it comes to trying different kinds of food.  I have to force myself not choose the same dish whenever I'm at a familiar restaurant, so East African food was a big step for me, but the reviews on Yelp made it a happy and eager step, like it was going to be the beginning of a whole frolicking in the prairie hippie moment.

You don't use utensils here.  The flat bread they give you is your utensil.  I was not fond of the sour taste of the bread but the actual main courses weren't bad.  We ordered two dishes and it was served on one platter.  Both dishes seemed to have been cooked with the same spices.. just different ingredients.  Basically, the whole thing just tasted the same.

I don't like it enough to come back.  It was just okay, but I don't regret the experience.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Ever since I had amazing Ethiopian food at Ras Kassa in Boulder, CO, I've been trying to find a place that matches it in flavor, a little closer to home. Alas Assab Eritrean Restaurant is NOT it, but it's still pretty good. It's slightly better than Zeni's in San Jose. 

The injera is much thinner than Zeni's and you also have to pay extra if you want more injera. Other than that, the vegetables were all tasty. The jalapenos in the mushroom dish (that I had to order separately from the veggie combo platter) added a nice zest to the whole plate. 

Go to this place only when you're not in a hurry, as service is extremely slow (but they do serve you with a smile)!
author: Chinmayi B.

description:
