This place is great!  Definitely the best Eritrean Restaurant in the area.  Every time I come, they're extremely accommodating and patient.  We came in recently and wanted to reserve places for 13 people and a baby.  They tried to accomodate our schedule and even called their other existing reservations behind us, so that we wouldn't feel rushed.  

The honey wine is a must.  The kitfo must be served rare to raw.  And the vegetarian options are delicious!  I've been coming here for 5 years, and can see myself coming here for another 5 years or more.
author: Tiffany K.

description: Vegie combo and the meat combo! Absolutely delicious and reasonably priced too! Order honey wine! It's delicious and manufactured in Oakland!
author: Pele T.

description:
Hrrrm. This doesn't beat my Ethiopian food eating experience in Berkeley but it puts up a good fight. (Admittedly, this wasn't Ethiopian food either so maybe I'm comparing apples to oranges?)

First I will say, if based on the service alone, Assab would receive 5 stars. It was warm, hospitable, friendly and encouraging. I love when you try new food and the people serving you act like they actually want you to enjoy the food of their culture. Our waiter was a smiley man with the cutest teeth. He was great about telling us his opinion between the lamb and chicken entrees as well as giving us fair warning about spice levels. And LORD do they know spicy!

Unfortunately, though I feel compelled by the 300+ 4 star reviews to be more generous, I can't do it. The lamb I ordered was way too tough and I wasn't fully convinced that I should be paying $14 for my entree. I was also running out of injera before I was done eating but I knew an extra order would cost me. 

The bill for our party of six left a pretty deep dent on the wallet ($14 x 6 plus honey wine and beer!) but for those of us who had never experienced food from this region of the world, it surely was a treat. Plus each of us were starving so the large portions suited us well! 

Although I've had better, I'd recommend it to those looking for Eritrean food in SF. The service alone should send you home with a smile.
author: liz c.

description: Have been here a couple times, this is a great place and an excellent place to go with a group. The food lends itself well to that. The staff are very friendly and welcoming.. Although I have not visited Eritrea or Ethiopia, I have eaten at the home of some Ethiopian and Eritrean friends and tried many Eritrean and Ethiopian places around the country, and the food here is good!!! Try the Eritrean beer too!!
author: Mark N.

description:
My interaction with Ethiopian food has been entirely with restaurants in San Francisco, and I'm absolutely certain that this is the best of them.  The service is friendly and very good, the drink options are also good as are the prices.

The food though, the quality and variety of flavors is unmatched.  Best Ethiopian I've ever had by a long shot, I prefer this to Indian now.  Great restaurant!
author: Scott S.

description:
I went here on a recent trip back home to the City. It was suggested by an old grade school friend, as she frequents this place quite a bit. I had never heard of Eritrean cuisine, let alone tried it... I didn't know what to expect.

Well... I absolutely LOVED it. The food & the service were excellent. I ordered the Kelwa Mix. It's a large plate of chicken breast chunks marinated in a spicy broth. Served on top of spongy & delish injera bread. Also on the plate were lentils, yogurt, beans to go with the chicken. The food was a total surprise hit with me. I don't normally do spicy food but they can tone the heat down a little bit and they did so upon my request... I really enjoyed my dinner there. Our party also ordered a bottle of honey wine which was also very good and I feel went well with the spiciness of the meal.

It appeared to me that this was a family run restaurant. It's a small place but I saw a large party at a big table so they can accommodate more than 10 people in that area. Went there on a late Saturday night, about an hour before closing and the place was still packed. We got the last table... They even added extra injera bread to my leftovers because they said that was the only way to thoroughly enjoy the food. Thank you Assab... I'm sold!!!
author: Chuck D.

description:
Pros:
1. Great food, everything I have had here has been amazing.  Most of the traditional recipes are very spicy, but they also have more moderate options 
2. Food is eaten with the hands by using some doughy bread they provide, this adds a lot to the experience and is very fun.
3. Great small restaurant environment. Very clean and well decorated.  
Cons:
1. The last time I went the place was rather crowded and service was very slow.  Service was always very friendly, helpful, and polite.  However, the service was very slow to take new requests and to refill drinks (which can be quite important since many of the entries are rather spicy.
author: Jason H.

description:
Absolutely delicious.  The service is great, and the portions are huge.  Don't make the mistake of ordering two dishes for two people.  One is more than enough to satisfy you and your date.

For those of you who haven't tried Ethiopian food before, be prepared for some spicy food.  You will be eating with your hands.  Various vegetables, curries, and meats are served on a giant piece of sponge bread.  The flavor is sensational.

Be sure to clean your plate!  The owner will tell you that you have more to eat, if you don't eat everything.  In Ethiopia, you don't waste food.  So if you can't finish, be sure to ask for the rest to go.
author: Jackson W.

description:
I love this place with a deep passion. The family owners are extremely nice people and they do their best to make sure you feel at home.
You can expect a remarkable experience no matter what you order. Meals traditionally come family style to share with others on one giant plate eaten with your hands and the spongy bread. You can request otherwise though. I lived 3 blocks away and would eat here when I could and it never got old. You really must eat here at least once.
author: E.N. C.

description:
First time experience with Ethiopian food- Amazing.
So so good. I didn't know what to expect but I'm glad this is the first place I tried. Had a spicy chicken dish, a veggies dish and they were both equally good. Although, the chicken dish has a kick to it which was awesome. I would definitely recommend this place. SUPER nice service, as well as helpful.
author: Pam S.

description:
I went to Assab for the first time on last Friday. The wait was long, and there is no area for it so we ended up standing with other parties in the middle of the dining area. 

But the food was great. For those unfamiliar, the flavorful hot dishes are served up on a massive platter with a layer of spongy bread that looks a little like a foot burdened by pitted keratolysis.

This platter is so massive that it makes me both feel like less of a man and question the existence of God.

You eat with your hands, which can be fun if you trust that everyone at your table has washed their hands.

If you don't trust your hands, you can request an "Eritrean shame wand" which is a simple metal device with four tines on the end. 

Don't be an SOB, eat at Assab!
author: Nik D.

description:
Delicious! My friends and I went for a casual dinner out on a Friday night; the wait was a bit long for a table and for our food, but it was well worth it. I think there are just a couple people working in the entire restaurant, so they are working hard to get the food out and people seated.

We got the lamb (#7), beef (#2 - well done) and the mushrooms. We got one another beef dish, though I can't recall which one it was. I loved all of them, though the #2 and #7 were the best. Meat was tender and full of flavor. Beware, the spicy lamb really is spicy but incredibly tasty. The portions are pretty big, and the three of us definitely over ordered...but we devoured all of it anyway. 

The entrees are incredibly reasonable (~$12 for each entree) as are the beers. If it was closer, this would definitely be my takeout spot.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Excellent food - spicy, savory, full of flavors
Do not miss - Honey Wine, family style plates, lentils, sambusa
Could improve - Ambiance.
author: Sudeep M.

description:
The one star is for the rude service i received last week when dining with my partner.  The food was oily and runny, something was off with the lentil soup, too, It was missing the other half portion that the soup used to be.  My waiter, the owner, was very rude to us when we ordered.  

He literally flailed his hands and breathed, in like he was about to have an anxiety attack.  AND we were the ONLY people in the restaurant!  Why was he having a hissy-fit!?  Where was his daughter?  His daughters are the only friendly waiters at Assab - dad should not be serving customers!!  

If you are serving ethiopian food to americans that may have never had it before - you should be way more patient and understanding to your patrons.  

I won't be back, there are plenty of better ehtiopian food establishments out there.
author: Ed F.

description:
Excellent Eritrean / Ethiopian food!  (I assume the two cuisines are similar, although I am not entirely sure).  

I like exploring more of the neighborhood that is so close to pac heights to the west--these places only take 5 minutes to get to from the northern parts of the city, but yet people who don't live there rarely head westward.

I ordered the spicy lamb (don't ask me to remember how to spell the name).  It seemed like a pretty basic 4x2 matrix:  [Chicken, Beef, Lamb, or Vegetarian] combined with [Spicy, Not-Spicy].  I would recommend spicy, and then just pick your meat or go veg. 

Also lentil soup and vegetable sambusa/samosa was good.

I'll be back.
author: Mike G.

description:
Fabulous.

Ambiance is quiet and simple.
The owners/staff are very friendly and attentive.
And the food.  MMM.  Don't let your eyes get ahead of your stomach.  If you've never had this cuisine, it can be deceptive.  It might not look like much, but it's filling.
author: Ken B.

description:
I had a meal here with some friends of which one happened to be Eritrean, so I think my experience was better due to that.  Otherwise, I would have been VERY lost here. Food is very flavorful and on the spicy side. Service is friendly and good. 

This place is not for everyone though. If you are the type that can't eat with your hands or are not int trying new things that are out of the norm for you... go elsewhere, but if you are ready to try tasty eats from the other side of the globe... this is your place. Be adventurous!  And eat up... yum yum!
author: Amelia M.

description:
Assab is excellent. 

So first and foremost don't be scared at the giant huge plates, the meals are 1 serving each and quite reasonable. This place is best with a large group of friends though, so that you can try a little bit of everything. I recommend getting group size - 1 servings since each order comes with sides. We had a bit too much leftover with 5 people and 5 servings.

The best thing I had there was the spicy raw meat, I forgot the name but it was quite delicious. 

I also recommend trying the honey wine, it's not really like wine though, it's more of a sweet drink. The best description I can think of is a thicker alcoholic juice to describe it. 

If you have a large group, I recommend calling for a reservation in advance. The place is small so it can get crowded and full pretty quick.
author: Rohan D.

description:
We have been following the owners of this restaurant since the days when they ran Massawa on Haight St., to Assab on Ocean Ave. and now to Geary St. The food is consistantly good and it keeps getting better. Just don't run out of Shiro. OK! Tonight, as usual, everything was great. 

This is, after all the years, my first review of Assab. I have to say that I am surprised by some of the comments here. One in particular from "live to eat C." regarding the sugar incident. You forgot to mention that your small child was also on top of the table dancing. Did you know that the table top is glass or if the kid fell the owners would/could be held responsible? Are you at all responsible? Yeah, I was there. Cry baby whiner.  Am I allowed to say that?

Anyway. Highly recommend this place. Too bad they are not open for lunch.
author: Robert H.

description: I have never had Ethiopian/Eritrean cuisine before even though I am from Los Angeles where they have a Little Ethiopia. We tried Assab because my husband bought a Groupon here. This place seems to be very popular. I ordered the vegetarian combo and my husband had the Kelwa-Derho. The food was really good. The spices weren't too overpowering and the injera really filled us up. We ordered the honey wine, but we did not like it at all. It was way too sweet. I would definitely come back and try some of the other dishes. It's a fun experience if you have a large group of people.
author: Caroline L.

description:
Yummy!!!!!!!!!!!

I have been here twice and each time had an amazing flavorful meal. 

They say one dish per person - no way. one dish to share is plenty. Get extra 'bread' = inerja. I highly recommend the meat combo and veggie combo, which is perfect for 3 hungry people or 2 starving people, or 4 hungry-ish people. 

The spicy dish is VERY spicy - watch out!

The older lady isnt very nice but hey the food is good and the place is popular. I believe it is family run because I see the same people working each time.

Oh and while there try the Eritrean beer!!! The stout is better than the lager.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This has become a weekly tradition, contrary to my original post!

As soon as I walk out, I want to go back. I just can't stop wanting more!
author: Marissa D.

description:
We had the 3 meet combo, lamb, beef & chicken and the chickpea mash. (sorry I don't know the exact name)

It was really good and we ate everything up. 

The samosa is a flat piece, not that great I think.

Order the Meta Beer, that was really good.

Yes service is slow, there were two people here serving 7 tables.
author: Louise G.

description: Went here after work one day and wanting to try ethiopean food. The place on the outside might look a little shady but the inside is inviting. It's run like a family owned restaurant. Nothing too fancy but the food was good. I tried the vegetarian and meat combo. The lamb was a little much but still really good. The vegetarian had a bit too much potatoe portion and not too crazy about the yogurt. Overall the food was really good though and filling. Worth a try.
author: Linda H.

description: We went here on week night and there was no waiting time.The lady was extremely sweet and friendly. The place had a very nice, home-like feel. I ordered the vegetarian platter and my friend ordered the meat platter. They were both delicious and plentiful. I loved the different flavors of the vegetables. The injera was amazing. I highly recommend this place.
author: Maddy K.

description: Great little place came with a buddy from Eritrea , Sambusa was great! Injera is amazing spongy type flat bread and honey wine was good, this is a totally different sharing of food type place then your used to. We had beef chicken and lamb for meats and i think the beed tasted beat, May want to ask for it to be mild much of the stuff is very spicy!
author: Michael S.

description: This place needs to be experienced.  The owner and his wife served not only INCREDIBLE food but life stories we will remember for a very long time.
author: Kat M.

description: My search for Ethiopian food led me here, and I was certainly not let down. Assab has all the meats, veggies and fixings that you could possibly want to scoop up with some injera. When we are in the area, we definitely stop in.
author: Mark A.

description:
I love this place.  If this restaurant was a person, I would hug them.  Then watch as they awkwardly stared at me.  Then I would hug them again.

The Injera bread is mouth-wateringly good, and the meat-combo made it even better.  I am seriously salivating all over my keyboard as we speak.

Never had Eritrean food before?  COME HERE.  You eat with your hands.  Get over it.  You can ask for a fork if you want, but most likely, all the patrons will point at you and laugh.  Then hug you.

Bottom line:  Food = delicious.  Try the honey wine too.
author: David S.

description:
The vegetarian sambusas ($2.25) were mindblowingly delicious (great mixture of spices that would make a carnivore think twice). The lamb and beef in the meat combo ($15.95) and the potato dish in the vegetarian combo ($13.95) were quite good. The homemade yogurt is a wonderful surprise in it's tangy creaminess.
The best Eritrean food I've had in the bay area...and perhaps DC...
author: Tracee E.

description:
I visited this place again after a long while. The food is OK, prices are average. The place is quiet - which is a nice change from most of the SF restaurants.

However, one bummer was that the the combo plates have only three items and the choices aren't great - the veggie combo had potatoes/carrots plus okra plus zucchini ? You can substitute one of them as long as it's not the mushrooms.

They do have Hakim Stout.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description:
I'd like to start by apologizing to all Ethiopian food I've shunned for the past 6.5 years. Thats when I first tried Ethiopian food.
At that time I was not a fan of the Injera (the thin crepe-like bread you eat all your food with).

I'm so glad I came to Assab. The Kitfo was amazing. I cant wait to make up with all the Ethiopian restaurants in the bay area. Give this place a try!
author: Norman P.

description: My sister and I had the veggie combination platter and loved it. The taste and spices of the food made my mouth explode with flavor.  The injera (bread it comes with) was good, but a little thin so it fell apart at times.  It was also a little pricey, but overall the service was good and the interior decorations were authentic.  This place is definitely worth checking out.  Great for family, but maybe not so great for a first date because it can get messy.  Enjoy!
author: Megan M.

description:
I created this account because I thought this place was so good and wanted everyone to know.

we tried 9 dishes and the mead, everything was delicious! we've been looking for a good Ethiopian restaurant, we found it!  we use to go to Addis in Oakland, this place is equal or better!

favorite dish was either the kilwa beef or, the gored gored (*spelling?). but all else barley fell short.
author: Aaron U.

description:
I've never really been fond of Ethiopian/Eritrean food.Though I like the flavors, I always get waaay too full because each bite must be driven into your mouth by a hunk of spongy bread rather than a utensil. By the end of the meal, my stomach is filled with a big mess of bread, but I don't feel at all nourished. 
This all changed when I came to Assab and was offered a  FORK. I always thought it rude to eat Eritrean with a fork, but apparently it is perfectly acceptable. At least it is at Assab :) And what a difference it makes to get a good bite of Tsebhi Dhero or Veggie Alicha sans bread!! 
The spices here are incredible. The waitstaff always friendly and as a bonus, my husband can't get enough of this place. Good thing, since it's literally right outside our door. Assab has completely won my heart!
author: Michelle D.

description:
This place was my first run in with Eritrean food a few years back when I first moved to the city...wow, what a great introduction.  This place is completely family run, and you feel it right when you enter.  The atmosphere is so warm, and inviting, you feel like you're a part of the family.  

We were promptly greeted by the man of the house, who sat us down, and gave us some time to browse our menu.  After looking over the menu, we decided on a vegetable combination, which was tasty, and I distinctly remember the potatoes being oh so awesome, while the other vegetables weren't that memorable, but good.  We also ordered the lamb dish, which came with more potatoes (awesome!), and the braised lamb was very tender, and very well seasoned.  Actually, all the food was full of flavors that I normally dont have, which was great.  I love the family style meals, and was happy to support a local family business.  Oh, I almost forgot to mention that oh so interesting texture bread, better known as injera.  While at first I was a bit intimidated, I was pleasantly surprised by its fluffy texture. Overall, a great meal with great service.  

One more thing, I wouldn't recommend the Eritrean beer, and maybe it's just been a while, but I remember it tasting like pooh.  Anyways, drink at your own risk, but dont say you werent warned.
author: David M.

description:
Having just moved to this neighborhood from North Beach, I have been disappointed in the restaurant choices (and especially disappointed with the lack of quality coffee).  I have been using Yelp to navigate food choices, and wasn't sorry I read the great reviews for Assab.  This is truly a great, friendly, reasonably-priced little gem.  The Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've had before has been either in the Mission or Berkeley, and I was unsure if Assab would be as good, but it was possibly better.

There were two of us and, heeding the warning of others here about quantity, we ordered two entrees:  meat combination and vegetarian combination.  This was a perfect way to sample a little bit of lots of food.  It was delicious!  The beef and the okra were our two favorites.  The waitress (daughter) was absolutely charming and chatted with us about other restaurants in the city.

I will absolutely return to Assab, and intend to graze my way through the whole menu.  Yummy!
author: Barbara C.

description:
Best in San Francisco!  

Get a veggie combo platter + meat combo platter and order extra injera. 

Start taking your children when they are old enough to say "Doro Wat"...they will love eating without utensils!
author: Mo M.

description: Vegetarians love this place, lentils and okra are great. I like the everything here. we tried veg alicha, shiro, kelwa dehro and okra ... I like the concept of dinning too family style in one big plate. You can order extra injira though..
author: Astha S.

description: I like the food here better than New Eritrea on Irving.  I find the food here more flavorful and the setting a lot nicer.  Service was very slow, they only had 2 servers working that night (saturday) and took about 10 mins to get the attention of one of the servers. Their honey wine was refreshing and sweet but also strong!
author: Jessica N.

description: Food was good (my first time eating Ethiopian food!), but service was too slow :( Took 40 minutes to get our food!
author: Emily C.

description:
Good Ethiopian/Eritrean food and not as hot as we have come to expect from previous experiences in similar restaurants. Some like it hot; we prefer spicy cuisines that allow us to focus on the taste rather than the burn. The balance here was perfect. The space is casual; the service good. We tried the honey wine. Lana did not care for it and I found it boring but not bad. Ask for a taste before you spring for a glass.

Assab is some way out from the center of town on Geary but it is easily reached via the #39 bus which runs along Market as well as Geary.
author: Lana G.

description: One of my favorite restaurants ever. It is simple yet extraordinary. I went here before a concert in SF and got an enormous amount of food. The family that owns this is very hardworking, traditional and nice. I still can't stop thinking of the collard greens. The chicken, meat and lamb dishes are all top notch. It makes your stomach feel happy. I can't wait to come here again.
author: Victoria C.

description:
PERFECTION.

Delicious Eritrean food and at a reasonable price.  Pleases both vegetarians and meat eaters and the injera is exactly the right flavor and consistency.  Authentic enough to please my friends and I who have spent time in Africa but also universally tasty enough for my picky-eater friends.  

The couple that owns the place is very friendly and will gladly answer questions about the food if asked.  

The veggie samosas are yummy (spicy, though!), the honey wine is sweet,  and the vegetarian sample platter comes with okra, lentils, buttery potatoes........aaaaaaah, I have to stop, I'm working myself up.  

GO.
author: Katy K.

description: Sweet and friendly owners in this family owned restaurant.  It was very welcoming with fast and enjoyable service. The vegetarian sampler was great, however, the star of the show was the vegetable sambusa.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
This is hands down the BEST Eritrean / Ethiopian restaurant I've ever been to.  My wife and I will go here late on a week night and it's such a treat.  It's a great quick cheap meal ($20 total between the two of us) and we're in an out in 35 minutes.  There are times you want to have a leisurely 3 hr dinner and there are times you just need to eat and get back to what you're doing.  For the latter, this is a great place.  Everything we've eaten here has been amazing.  We particularly like the beef appetizer. 

My only complaint about this place is that they are closed on Sundays.  I know you guys need a night off, but what am I supposed to do when I want Eritrean on a Sunday??? Waahhhhhh!

Ok, I'll stop whining.  But seriously, you guys are da bomb!
author: Sutha K.

description: Super nice, friendly, great people here. Food is consistent. My usual is the veggie combo with yogurt.
author: Tina L.

description: Amazing, that was the only word I could say after eating at Assab. We had a veggie combo, a meat combo and two glasses of honey wine. Everything was amazing, the meat was tender, the veggies had great flavor, and the bread was perfect (but for the life of me I can't remember how to spell the proper name of the bread). If you're in the mood for something a little different you really can't go wrong at Assab.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Great food similar to Blue Nile in Berkeley.

I would order the meat dish and vegetable combination platter (the lamb stew, the vegetarian lentil, the banaut (a stew-like mixture of the bread and meats).  It is pretty large and easily feeds up to four people.  The injera bread here is pungent and a bit sweeter than the bread served at the Blue Nile.  For something different, try the Honey Wine.  It is an interesting addition to the already different spiced dishes.

The interior is pretty cozy and provides a good backdrop for friends just catching up over good Eritrean cuisine.  Seating was quick and service even faster.  Plus, it was nice on our wallets.
author: Miika M.

description:
Went there and ordered two vegetarian dishes, #17 & #18, to share.   Everything was absolutely delicious.  Couldn't have asked for the food to be any better.   The Hakim beer nicely washed it down.

The only thing that could have been better was a little quicker service with respect to taking our order.   However, once the order was taken, the delivery of everything was quick, and all of the employees were very courteous and friendly and seemed to be genuinely pleased that we were enjoying their food so much.
author: Marc P.

description:
The last time I had Ethiopian/Eritrean food was when I was 7 with my dad and his Ethiopian work buddies. So I hardly remember what the flavors are like, I only remember having such a great time! My sister and I got such a kick out of eating mouse pads (injera). My dad's a computer programmer so naturally that's what he told us it was.

Now trying it again nearly 20 years later, I still found myself having a good time. Our server was cute. The dishes were flavorful and filling (we had sambusas, chicken, lamb and a veggie combo). The honey wine was extremely sweet (maybe a little too sweet), but the aftertaste was great. And my mouse pad was as mouse paddy as ever.

My bf says it's not the best he's had, but I don't really have too much to compare it by. It was pretty good to me!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Dear Ethiopian restaurant that is not Assab-
We've been hooking up for like 6 years now and it's been good, and it's even been hot at times. . . but babe, and as much as I hate to be a superficial pig, you just aren't hot enough for me.   

Dear Assab- 
Yes, yes you are currently the hottest Ethiopian I've been able to find.  That alone will make you a regular date. But please keep the above average beer list stocked and for christ sakes turn down the lights . . . while my date looked great under the artificial sun both of us would have felt better under a less clinical lighting environ.
author: Carlos C.

description:
Eh. It's no Sheba Lounge, that's fo' sho'. 

I met one of my gal pals for a really, really early dinner (read: 5pm) before an event at USF. We have a standing monthly girls' night and usually go to Sheba for our favorite Ethiopian. Of course, I'm all about eating my way through the city, so I'm always up for trying new Ethiopian or any other places. 

Assab was OK. It wasn't awful, but it certainly was in the lower tier of Ethiopian food I've had. The injera was just off, the veggie combo was skimpy, and the food itself was kind of oily and runny. 

It's also much more expensive than other (and better) places. The veggie combo only came with 3 things with limited substitutions and you have to pay for extra injera. 

I'm glad I tried it, but I won't be back.
author: Amy B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Ethiopian restaruants and have eaten at a number of them across the bay area - and Assab is one of the best. While the decor might not be posh and I think they could use an extra waiter, this place is always packed and that crowd is well deserved. 

My fiance and I are huge fans of the Kitfo and vegetarian combo - but we've also had the lamb and the chicken and they did not disappoint, either. The only negative to the food, in my opinion, is due to the fact that Assab is a bit stingy with the Injera. I don't like eating a ton of the "plate" because it's overly soggy with the sauce from the food, but you only get one piece of Injera per person, which isn't quite enough to finish the meal. You can ask for more, but it costs extra - which I think is a shame, given that most other places I go give you free refills. Despite this, Assab is now my go-to place because it's close to my house and legitimately delicious.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
This place is fantastic! It was my first time trying Ethiopian food. I wasn't sure if I would like it, but I am a pretty adventurous eater. I got a chicken dish and it came with several sides, all of which were delicious. It came on the Injera (?) that was the soft spongy bread. You get a ton of food spread out on a big round board.

The owner is really nice and didn't mind that we used a fork..
author: Cathy S.

description: It was very so so. We had chicken and two different beef dishes. Both beef tasted exactly the same... Very nice service but food was very average and not worth the money you pay
author: Gosia R.

description: We (couple) went there for dinner and the food was really tasty. We enjoyed eating with our bare hands (of course). The service was so friendly, simply amazing.
author: Michael P.

description: The honey wine is okay but the actual food is pretty good.  I recommend sharing the combination, great way to sample dishes.  My cousin and I stuffed ourselves and our waitress told us she was very impressed.  :0)
author: Madeline W.

description: Food tasted great, service was fantastic each time. Unfortunately we both got food poisoning this last visit! Never going back :(
author: Rachel D.

description: I love this place! The prices are reasonable and the food is so tasty! I have been craving their food for several weeks and just got it to go, and it seems the portions are even larger than when you are eating at the restaurant. Their to go food holds up well too! I love the meat combo and veggie combo as well as the kelwa mix and mushrooms. Yummy!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Five years of expectations have been running on this one meal, talk about pressure. 

I was guided here by the best SF yelper around, Patrick. 
Three buses and a couple of blisters later we arrived to Assab, unfortunately, we had forgotten to check the time- it was not open until 4pm, we were an hour early. 
So off we went to buy some socks a couple of blocks away, waited at the park for time to pass while I was explained the difference between Ethiopian and Eritrean food, (basically none), and returned to Assab. 

Walking back my shoes were starting to kill me, but the thought of giving up on trying this restaurant was inconceivable. I could see the small green entrance from two blocks away. 
We were met up by a non-yelper friend of mine who had reservations as to what in the world I was making her eat.
Once inside, we chose a table close to the window. First customers of the night. We were given a menu and our drink orders were taken.
 
Neither of us were hungry so we asked for several appetizers and one large plate to share. 
"No, we cannot do that" said the waitress.
Cannot do what? give us food? Turns out they cannot let three people share one large plate of food and two appetizers. We eventually gave in and ordered a second full plate of food.

We ordered Vegetable Sambusa and Meat Sambusa for appetizers, the Meat Combination plate ($15.95) and the TSEBHI-DERHO (chicken) ($12.95).

Our appetizers were beyond fantastic. They were like a thin empanada (for Miami yelp...) with lots of spicy goodness. 

When our large plate of food got to the table, my friend was not given an extra plate. We were dumbfounded, and offended we even had to ask for one. There was certainly more than enough food. When we asked for the plate, the waitress brought exactly that, one plate, without the bred/crepe/fluffy dough thing. We could not believe it. Patrick ended up giving her his plate. I mean, how much can one crepe cost them? $0.10? less? My friend barely ate anything anyway. *sigh* I hate when crappy service interferes with such a great experience.

Once we got past the terrible service, we took the first bite out of this delicious sampling of flavors. I could not believe what I was eating. This is the most fantastic, beyond delicious food I have ever had. Nothing can compare to this. 

The experience of sharing your food is also an experience. Kind of like saying "what's mine is yours." 
All three of us loved the food and even if it was spicier than we had anticipated, we would have asked for seconds if we were still hungry. 

I am hooked and will look forward to another Eritrean dinner for more years to come. 

The four stars is strictly based on my horrible experience with the service, had it not been for that, I would have given five. The service was so bad, in fact, that I will try other Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants before ever returning to Assab in hopes that I find one with better service and equally incredible food.
Unfortunately for me, this is one of those places where you have to choose between good food or good service.

*disclaimer*
I did get sick on my plane-ride back, but it's because i'm not used to the spices. Those who are trying this food for the first time and are not used to spice cannot overdo-it like I did. It will not sit well in your tummy. Have some pepto handy. :D
author: Laura G.

description:
YUM.

We went here for a dinner for four.  We ordered the meat combo, the vegetarian combo, a chicken dish and a lamb dish.  It was all tasty.

My friend commented that she was surprised I ordered a vegetarian dish even though I was a meat eater.  I answered "Gerl, because its damn good."

Indeed it was.  Everything was delicious.  We also got a bottle of honey wine, which was very sweet but perfect for the spiciness of the food.

The service here was excellent, our server was very nice and patient and the food came out promptly. The decor is really cute and open and not claustrophobic at all. 

I love this place, I can't wait to go back.  My suggestion is to go here with a group, because you can try more dishes since it's all served family style.
author: Mena A.

description:
This is the place that as you are driving down Geary and are frantically trying to go into or not go into the Masonic tunnel that you think "hhm, Eritrean food, that sounds interesting"  (or even "I wonder where that is) but then when it comes to actually going there for dinner, you never quite make it there.

I made the effort to check it out  a few months ago and I'm glad I did.
I'd never been to an African restaurant (this is PC, no?) outside of Africa so it was my first time in the US acceptably eating sans utensils and I was excited!!

A friend and I went to Assab on a weeknight and were taken aback by the aromas the moment we walked in-always a good indication for how your meal is going to taste I figure. We were seated immediately and greeted by our friendly server. I got the sampler vegetarian plate and was delighted. The portion was great and I left feeling stuffed. There was definitely enough for leftovers, but as is my style, I scraped the plate.

Wash cloths or the like to wash hands before and/or after would have been a great touch. Also ambiance is a little diner like... dim the lights maybe? Swap out the chairs? Consider a little carpet ?? And voila- 5 stars.

I have been singing Assab's praises and I'll return for some finger licking grub!
author: Ash E.

description:
I love Ethiopian food so I was eager to try this place. It's Eritrean, but it's very similar to Ethiopian (look at a map... but not a history book). Like Ethiopian food, the meal centers on a large plate of injera, a thin, spongy, tangy bread, and you order dishes that are served on top. You eat with your hands by taking a piece of the injera - starting with the portion they give you on the side and ending with the messy but tasty serving dish - and using it to scoop up the various toppings.

I always like to get the vegetarian combo so that you get lots of variety, plus one meat dish; that's enough for two. For the meat dish we chose a chicken with spicy peppers, onions, and (very obviously) butter. Both were great. The veggie combo wasn't quite as diverse as at Ethiopian places I've been to, and the chicken was a tad greasier, but the meal overall definitely met my high expectations for great Ethiopian (yeah, Eritrian) restaurants.

Standard preparatory instructions for those not familiar with this style of food: wash your hands first, be prepared to share, be open minded, and be prepared to smell like (delicious!) onions, garlic, and exotic spices for the rest of the evening.
author: Adam B.

description:
I've heard for a long time from people that I would like Ethiopian food - but up until a little while ago, I had never gotten the opportunity to try it.

I make it a point to try any and all cuisines at least twice before I vow it off forever.  I mean, if I were a man, I'd be Andrew Zimmern - only I don't have texture issues like he does, and I have a bit more hair and a few less pounds.  (He is adorable though.)

We found this place and headed over one night.  It was only when I got there that I noticed the name - -  Assab Eritrean Restaurant.

Now I have never been a guru when it comes to geography.  For a girl, I have a pretty amazing sense of direction - but geography, not my strongest suit.  With all the travel I do - you'd think I'd have at least HEARD of most countries, but apparently not.

First, I had no idea what "Eritrean" was - most likely because I had no idea - not a single CLUE - that "Eritrea" was a country in Africa.  I assumed it was an adjective for all things Ethiopian or something.  I stand corrected.  A tiny little country in Africa - who knew?

No really - who knew?  Did you know?  

Well - I enjoyed my meal here a lot.

First, we walked in where there was only one table left - meaning we were destined to be the last customers of the evening, and we arrived perhaps 5 minutes before last seating.  The owner who greeted us never flinched and welcomed us.  He was so patient and friendly with all of my questions - what "injera" is and how it's made, and how one eats certain dishes, as well as geographic and cultural information about Eritrea and Ethiopia.  

Both Robbie-boy and I picked a couple of dishes and asked which he recommended - and abided by his recommendations.

We ordered an appetizer - an Eritrean deep-fried quesadilla of sorts with ground beef.  While I have forgotten what it was called, it was delicious!

The food presented before us was on huge platters.  It was slightly reminsicent of Indian dishes with the use of lentils and herbs, but without the strong flavors of Indian food.  More subtle, if you will.  The meats were braised nicely and 

For those of you who don't know - you don't actually have to put hand to food to mouth as I thought it meant when I was told one must eat by hand.  I was willing to do it, in spite of being a big believer in utensils.  You simply tear off a piece injera, the spongy "bread" that is actually more like a tortilla, and take THAT and grab your food with it.  It takes some talent and practice to not get any food on your hands.  Midway through the meal, I did ask for a fork only so I could scoop up the goodies and pile in on top of the injera and then eat it by hand.

One appetizer, two dishes and 3 beers cost a little over $45 prior to tip - which in terms of Rob's and my dinners, is incredibly reasonable.  Furthermore, it was an informal but exotic dinner experience at a reasonable cost.  If I had to pick one small bone, it's that with more exotic, foreign cuisine, I think the owner should make the ambiance of the place a bit more suitable for the experience instead of a plain restaurant setting.  Perhaps some booths or partitions to make it a bit more private, tablecloths, dim the lights a LOT, and in general, make it more intimate.  Eating with one's hands in an intimate setting is more enticing and appealing than eating w/ one's hands in a wide open, bright restaurant.   This restaurant would have made my date list if not for the ambiance.

We walked out a bit more "edu-ma-cated" than before, tummies full, and happy for minimal cost.  All in all, Assab was great, and we'll be back.  The food was tasty, and while I have nothing to compare it to, it was not too heavy but filling, subtle but distinct.

If you haven't tried food from this region, I daresay Assab is a good starting point!
author: Grace K.

description: Great staff. Complete menu. Perfectly spiced, enjoyed by the spicy-phobic as well. Veggie dishes very filling. Nice music. Con: absolutely no alternatives for adults or kids that don't want Eritrean foods.
author: Michael S.

description: First time here.  The owner is irrational about reservations. We waited for 10 mins, asked how long it would take to get seated and came back within the time allotted.  He gave our table away.  Oddly there were multiple tables in this small establishment "reserved" for the entire night with no guests on them.  When I brought up the reserved tables that were unoccupied for 25+ minutes he refused us those tables as well.
author: A K.

description: Yes, the servers aren't exactly the most friendly people, but yet the food is quite good, I enjoyed the beef dish I had here with the gera it was actually quite delicious and the portions was quite large that I had enough for lunch the next day
author: Rachel N.

description:
I've been here 10-20 times so far and have tried just about every entree on the menu.  The food has always been delicious.

I only wish the spiciness was more consistent (some days an entree will only be mildly spicy, and other days it will be wildly hot).  I also wish they gave out hot hand towels or something at the start so I didn't have to wash my hands every time I got there- granted, I've never been to an Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant that did that, but I think a lot of people would appreciate it.
author: Rego S.

description:
Assab is the best!!

If you enjoy Habesha food then you have to check out Assab.  I stopped by after listening to a friend rave about the spot for several months ..... I had my doubts,  but the food was delicious and I was instantly hooked. 

I usually get the doro tibs and the vegetarian combo.  The chicken is always just right and the injera is always fresh.

The prices are reasonable and the service is great.
author: ct e.

description: the owner has a lot off attitude !!! we had a guest coming from out of town and wanted him to try the food here. We waited for 15 minutes for the restaurant to open, just to find that he wont let us order one dish and a honey wine between 3 of us. we had to take the food to go, and it was in a plastic container, with the gravy spilling out, and the container was not even insulated, so could not eat from it , unless we keep it on a solid surface.
author: venu p.

description:
This place is delicious.  As a fan of Ethiopian food, Assab does not disappoint.  I went here last week with my girlfriends, and we got a great mix of lamb, chicken, beef and veggie.  The samosas were amazing, and I oddly liked the veggie one more than the meat.  The house made cottage cheese is also a delicious touch.

The lamb and beef were super tender (I'm not a  chicken fan in life); I think the lamb was by far my favorite.  Also, the food is served family style, which is really the way to go.  We got this huge platter of food, all on top of sponge bread along with wine and our personal sponge bread.  

I usually don't like eating with my hands, but obviously I like food more and got over that real quick.  Teensy problem though, there wasn't dessert on the menu.  They use to have tiramisu but the day we went it was crossed off the menu.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Laura H.

description:
Assab has become one of my favorite restaurants in SF! I've been 3 times in the past few months and have had a great experience with the staff, the service, and most importantly the food each time. It is reasonably-priced, and the portions are big. Lots of flavor and spices, and the honey wine goes well with the food.

My favorite dishes to order - the chickpeas and the veggie combo! The meat combo is also a great choice although I always happen to go when I'm with a vegetarian!
author: Buster B.

description:
This is the best Eritrean/Ethiopean food in SF. Hands down. I think you just have to try it for yourself. I'm not going to give you any recommendations because then it will sound like the other stuff sucks. 

But here's the deal:
Food-great.
Service-even better.
Prices-great, definitely worth splurging a couple of $s on cab if you are not close.
Decor-a bit cold, linoleum floors are not the hippest thing these days.

The best part is that you can literally tell them something like: "I can't decided what I want today. I'm feeling like something light, with some lamb, not too spicy but still spicy, maybe some lentils but not too dry" And the guy will just say: "Oh I know what you want!" and come back with a mind blowing concoction.

Tasty, fast, friendly, cheap! What else.
author: Marko J.

description: Assab is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I would go here a lot more often than I do if I could afford it. The food is spicy, so if you can't take the heat, this is not the place for you. Personally, I love spicy food. There is something for both vegans and meat eaters alike here. My favorite is the kitfo- basically, raw or rare hamburger meat seasoned with clarified butter and Eritrean seasonings. Its very spicy, but very yummy. The staff is always nice here. The prices are a little out of my budget, which is why I don't come here often. But whenever I go have the money, Assab is always the restaurant I want to go to.
author: Elyse B.

description:
We went here for the S.O.'s birthday and it was my first time eating Eritrean food, so I was a little unsure how to feel about the eating with your hands bit (especially after hopping of the 38 Geary!) But after a good hand washing and a glass of honey wine I was ready to dive in. Now they should really warn you that your stomach is smaller than your eyes because we ordered way, way too much food, and very quickly realized that we would get no help from the picky 8 year old at the table. But everything was soo delicious. We ordered almost everything of the vegetarian menu and were delightfully surprised with the variety of food presented to us.

I would recommend this place to anyone wanting to adventure out into some delicious ethnic cuisine, although be warned it is abit spicy and not for picky eaters.
author: Allyson S.

description:
If you are in a hurry for your meal, not your place.
If you want really cheap food, not your place.

If you want a welcoming atmosphere,
great food, great value, you are in the right place.
Often it takes a while for your food to arrive (30-60 min).
Often your food tastes Eritrean.
If this bothers you, don't let the door hit your butt on the way out.
If you loive good food and good hosts, you are home.
See you there.
author: D G.

description:
I love this place, it is family owned and the food is the best... I reccomend the tea or honey wine as the flavors suit the food... though they have an eclectic list of beers too.

Sambusa... try both the meat and the vegetable... order your dinner and please wash your hands as they do give you silverware only if you ask... indira (spellcheck) is a soft crepe style bread you use to eat the foods with... OMG the foods are heaven... spiced for those who love spice... I have seen a few people sweat up an endorphin storm there... funny but gotta love the masochism of the tender tonge types... I feel the spice is inviogorating but be warned ok.

tzigni is deliciosly prepared beef in a brown sauce and the vegetable medly (three types of dishes) suit the meal just fine... share this plate with one and add additional foods for more people. it is served family style on a platter and again wash you hands... we used to laugh that I'd wear a white shirt on the days we would go to Assab, so i could get a singular drop on it... I know better now... but it was true for years... try it you will love the home town feeling the warm personalities of the staff, the food is what it is all about. We first got curios about the sign, went there to investigate, and have gone back now for years... hope you do too.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My second visit to Assab last night. Food is great, cozy ambiance..... most of all bathroom is very clean. It is very important for me see bathroom to be very clean, it shows about the rest of the restaurant.
Eating with hand can be fun too. One of my favorite African food!
author: Annie K.

description:
A bit pricey: a little over $35 for two (with just 2 entrees, no drinks, no desserts), and the injera isn't free and unlimited!! Every ethiopian place I've ever gone to has free and unlimited injera; here they give you one thing of injera each and for 75c you get one more thing of injera--WTF? I think it is because they don't want people splitting an entree and filling up on injera, which is the best part of ethiopian places because then you can pay $10 each including tip and all. Also the honey wine was $5.25 for a glass and $22 for a bottle, which is also pricier than most places.


That said, the "curries" were all very well spiced; I loved the mushroom vegetarian curry I got and also the meat curries. Also, with all the entrees they gave 3 small vegetarian curries, which was nice.

The food is good, but I have had just as good for a better deal (that was in Berkeley though)
author: Shauna T.

description:
We love this place. The food is consistently good, not good, actually delicious. Very low key place, great for groups. Lot's of options.
The service is a little slow, but it is actually not a major concern. I highly recommend getting the Vegetarian special and the Meat special (if you eat meat), this way you can try a little bit of everything! You cannot go wrong.
author: Pokimonkey S.

description:
I was pretty disappointed with this place after reading the other favorable reviews. I came here on a Wednesday night for dinner. First we ordered the lentil soup (which was really good) and then two entrees (one lamb, one chicken).

The service was very slow. It took about 40 minutes to get our lentil soup, which is the appetizer. Then we got the entrees. The meat was poor quality.

Overall, I would not return to Assab and recommend others to try other Ethiopian restaurants in the city.
author: Irina I.

description:
This is going to sound harsh, but I honestly think that people like the whole idea of eating Eritrean food more than they like the actual food itself. In fact, a quick scan of the diners in this restaurant and I immediately noticed at least 2 or 3 people with the same expression on their faces: "Look at me! I'm eating food that most people haven't tried yet and I'm using my hands. I'm so cultural!"

Unfortunately, the cuisine failed to leave me inspired. The beef sambusa was pretty good, but the other dishes we tasted were below standard fare. Unaccentuated flavors (I prefer Indian food, where the flavors are bold and less subtle), soggy/overly yeasty dough-bread, and inattentive service. Plus, where is there ever a wet nap when I need one?!

Bottom line: I really wanted to like this place, but it simply failed to deliver. Beyond the hype and the notion of trying new cuisines is a menu of uninspiring dishes and an overall mediocre dining experience. "A" for effort, "D" for food (and for the tummy ache a couple hours later!).
author: Joseph F.

description:
I came here last night with the three of my roommates and really enjoyed the eating experience. 

We had the okra, beef, chicken, and chickpea dishes and they were prepared so that they all fit on one huge plate. It also came with an extra piece of injera bread on the side :]

Although intimidating at first, we dove in only to be told by our very kind waitress that that the plate of injera was extra and that we should use the one on the larger plate on which the food was served on! Haha, obviously this was our first time. 

Having broken our Eritrean food virginity, we ate until our stomachs were full. I really enjoyed my chickpeas (shiro) and had a sampling of the others which were really delicious and also spicy! The injera bread is spongy and has a sour taste to it. 

The wait staff was really nice and always kept our waters filled. 

I'm looking forward to eating here again and trying everything else Assab has to offer!
author: Angela A.

description:
We usually get a veggie combo and the doro tibs (chicken).  Very nice.

The mushrooms are yummy!

Nice spot for Ethiopian in the city.
author: .caroline. ..

description:
What kind of food?  From what country?  Doesn't matter one bit, this place is tasty.

I went with a group of six - called ahead and they had a table ready for us.  I disagree on the pricey point - we each paid around $25/person, which seams reasonable for one entree a piece and a couple bottles of wine shared among the group (including the tip).  Our waitress was super friendly, too!

All of the food was delicious.  We had a lamb, chicken and beef dish along with three veggie sides.  The chickpeas were outstanding and the chicken was very, very flavorful.  And, because you can't review an Ethiopian restaurant without talking about the bread, let me just say it was sour for all that's great about sour.  

The only reason there are four stars instead of five is ambiance - it wasn't very cozy here.  Bright lights and hard tables - dimming the lights and adding some table cloths could put it over the edge.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
AMAZING AMAZING AMAZING!

You will fall in love with this place and the wonderful owners who make sure you are enjoying your meal.

It's a great place to take a date or a group of friends to catch-up and re-connect over a shared meal of zesty Eritrean / Ethiopian food. 

The ambiance is calm so you can easily have a great conversation, but beware: the food is so good that it's probably all you'll talk about!! 

Don't come here if you're not ready to be WOW'ed!!
author: Nikki H.

description:
I'd never had Ethiopian food before, I love eating with my hands, and mushy spicy goodness just sounds so tasty, so I'd been wanting to try Assab for awhile.  Finally went the other night with two friends and although I wasn't blown away by the flavors as I expected, I still thought everything was delicious and would gladly return.  

First order of business: quantities.  We settled on 2 sambusa appetizers and 3 main course options to share.  Thank goodness.  We cleaned our plate, so 2 entrees definitely wouldn't have filled us up. 

Second order of business: what to order.  We settled on 1 veg option with chickpeas, 1 beef option, and 1 lamb and potato option.  My favorite in terms of flavor was actually the veg option.  Though they were all good.  One of my friends declared the lamb to be her favorite, so it's not like there was a single standout.  The beef was the only really spicy one, but they were good about keeping our water glasses full.  Also, I was afraid a single piece of spongy crepe-like bread wouldn't be enough to sop up all the food, but it was perfect and there was a little spongy bread left over from the serving platter.  

Third order of business: experience.  The service was good, though our waiter seemed cold.  Towards the end of our meal he smiled more, so I left feeling good about him, but don't come here expecting a chatty server.  But most importantly, a giant plate of scoopable deliciousness to share = big win, satisfying dinner, and a desire to come back.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
made a reservation over the phone, rather hurried and kinda rushed feeling...but then again i guess all reservations over the phone are kinda like that. 

my german friend said service was pretty "german" aka emphasis wasn't really on service, but we both agreed the food was pretty good. 

we ordered the lamb and mushroom dish. both a bit spicy for my friend but i thought it was just right! 

overall, it's the only eritrean spot in sf, so if I wanted eritrean food again, i would be coming back.
author: Jen L.

description: We've been going to Assab for years and always love the place.  The family that runs it is always so warm and inviting, and we've loved seeing the place blossom and thrive over the years (when so many other restaurants are tanking).  And I love Ethiopian food in general, and they do it up well, with rich spicing and beautiful presentation.  Highly recommended!
author: Lynn C.

description:
Do you LOVE good food? How about FUN food with TONS of flavor? If so, then this is the place to get your grub on.

Assab, I've seen you day after day driving down on Geary over the past 28 years, and never ventured in. Well, it won't be another 28 years before I return again. The food was GREAT.

I went with 2 girlfriends...we ordered family style...1 meat dish (chicken breast with mixed veggies, etc), and 1 veggie dish (alisha)...both very tasty, perfect portions, delicious spongy bread...and we each had a sambosa to start. The pinotage was the perfect accompaniment. 

YUM YUM!

$23 per person. Not bad.
author: Misha F.

description:
This being my third go at eritrean/ethiopian food, i'm by far no expert. that said, it was a pleasant meal. the most amazing part of my meal was trying the stumptown cherry/wheat beer for the first time. that is one tasty brew. GD, i have to find a store that carries that yummylicious booze. when ladies refer to men as a tall drink of water, that hunky score may be likened to this brilliant beer. (go with it)

the food itself was pretty tasty, and from all the meals i've had, the veg half is way better than the meat half. great food, slow but nice service, fantastico beer
author: Jade L.

description:
Assab is such a unique experience. Great food eaten with your hands. Don't ask for a fork because that's what all the newbies do. I also enjoyed my Ethiopian Stout. It had a great taste as well. My date said she was nervous as we sat down, but she loved it!

Beware: Some of the entrees can be pretty spicey, but the taste is delicious.
author: Brett W.

description:
Not all that impressed.  This place pales in comparison to New Eritrea on Irving.

The veggie sambusas were all peas, and with no spicy paste for dipping.  The wrapper on mine even had some uncooked parts.

We shared the meat combo and the famous mushroom dish, but neither one thrilled me.  The lamb was too gamey and tough, the chicken wasn't all that tender and was a chore to pry off the bone.  The injera was thin and dry, unlike the supple stuff I am accustomed to at New Eritrea, and the pieces under our entrees turned to gruel in the sauce, which shouldn't happen.  Soft and soggy, yes, but not disintegrated.  The mushrooms were mostly onions, and the flavors were fine, but nothing special.

The service was friendly, but painfully slow, taking ten minutes to come to our table, another ten to get our appetizers, and we had to ask again for our drinks when the entree arrived, while their Eritrean friends (who coincidentally happened to be friends of mine) at the next table got excellent, speedy service, and their drinks arrived  20 minutes before ours, even though we arrived at the restaurant 20 minutes before they did.  

I don't see any reason to return to Assab now that New Eritrea will be open Mondays starting in March, which is why we weren't there last night.  

Based on the reviews, Assab was a major disappointment.
author: Quinn S.

description: Zigini, Tsebhi Derho, Alicha Beggee,             FIRE!!!  This place is hella good
author: Sonny S.

description:
had been wanting to try their food for a long time, but they were always closed whenever i passed by, i could never understand why.  but aha! i now know it's because they open at 4!

food was delicious- they got some really good veggie options. i had plate with potatoes & lentils.  we we're the only ones there at the time, so didn't have to wait long for the food to come out.  prices were good & the portions are big too! the staff was super friendly and cool to talk too. i think it's a family, so it's a nice family style vibe in there.  

yes, i'd deff come back again, and also recommend it to anyone who wants to have a filling, authentic Eritrean meal at a decent price.
author: Delilah B.

description:
Very nice dining experience. Went here for an early Christmas dinner. Made reservations, though did not seem completely necessary. I would still recommend it if you are going to be a large group. There were 6 of us and we ate family style. We had 6 dishes (must have the kitfo rare) and sambusas (veggie and meat). Everything was amazing. I ate so much. I could barely walk. The prices were pretty average, I think to feed us was about $130 or $140 with drinks. The decoration is colourful and authentic. The staff is really nice and helpful. 

All in all it was a very nice meal and we'll probably go back.
author: Andrew Y.

description: I felt bad using a groupon here tonight cause it was such a steal.  I ate like a king and we felt so guilty getting it all on the cheap, make sure you tip tip tip when eating Assab on a dime.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: Their honey wine is very unique. I've had better Eritrean and Ethiopian food on the East Coast... the sauces are a bit flat and could use more meat content.
author: Amy M.

description: We went to Sfo downtown last weekend. After a long day we decided to enjoy Ethiopian food for dinner.  This place has awesome vegetarian options.  Also the taste and food portion are damm good.
author: Pankaj A.

description:
So so so so good. I went here with my Evolution class and professor and I had a great time.

The food looks like mush and you might think....hey how do I eat this? Well, you take the bread foamy wrap and rip it, grab the mush with it, and then eat it. Sounds great right?

They have a combination of meats and vegetarian plates from spicy to not so spicy. These meals aren't for the weak. 

I hate to generalize but if you like Ethiopian food + Indian food, then you'll enjoy this place.
author: Carissa E.

description:
One of the best Eritrean food I have ever had.  Both the vegetarian and meat options are to die for, and cooked and spiced to perfection.  

Also, the staff is incredibly nice and friendly. What a wonderful place!
author: Irina P.

description:
I hadn't had Eritrean food since the summertime, so coming to Assab was a real treat. Since I go out every week with my friend to sample different cuisines, and since I am heading back to the East Coast for the holidays, I figured, "Hey, why not do Eritrean before I leave SF for vacation?"

We were deciding between Assab and Bamboo Village. Eritrean vs. Indonesian; my friend was craving Indonesian food more since he was under the impression that "Ethiopian food is too healthy-sounding for me tonight." But, we decided we would make our final decision if we got the chance to look at both menus. Assab didn't have a menu outside, so my friend wanted us to walk down to Bamboo Village (just a block away) to check them out first. Ah, but upon approaching Bamboo Village...the place was packed. It looked like there was a big party dinner, so the whole restaurant was full (the place wasn't so big anyway). So, by default, we went back to Assab (I really wanted Assab in the first place, so this was my victory).

Assab wasn't so busy at around 7pm; we sat by the window (bad idea on a cold night in SF!); we ordered the Vegetable Sambusa (fritter), the Meat Combo and the Vegetable Combo. It was my friend's first time to try Eritrean food, so he certainly was not aware that there were no silverware involved. When the main course came out (on a HUGE platter), my friend panicked a little at the thought of using his hands to grab the food. "It's not...sanitary?" he said. Meanwhile, I was fine with the idea and was already tearing away at the injera and dipping it into the food.

At first, my friend was eating the injera and meat/veg reluctantly with his hands. Then, he summoned our server and this conversation ensued:

Friend: "May I...have a spoon?"
Server smiles, shakes head "NO" and makes my friend gasp in astonishment. I knew he already felt embarrassed.
Server: "We don't have any spoons here, but I can go downtown and buy one for you if you want."
Friend: "Uh...uh...no, that's okay."
Server: "Are you sure?"
Friend: "Yes...yes, I'm sorry, I didn't know."

So my friend really believed that there were no spoons available, and settled for using his hands. He said he was "getting used to the idea" when the server came back and actually handed him a spoon. Then, my friend used the spoon the rest of the time we were eating.

Anyway, that was a fun/funny experience in itself. But onto the actual review--

Food: Great; I loved the spices/seasonings. I'm not quite educated in Eritrean food just yet, but I liked what I ate at Assab. The meat and veggie combos are great for those who aren't familiar with the different dishes yet.

Prices: Average for dinnertime; of course not as cheap as Chinese/Thai/Vietnamese places, but I'm under the impression that the prices at Eritrean places are a little more expensive ($10-$15) due to the experience and to the exotic nature of the food (please pardon me if I am wrong).

Service: The server and the cook were both very nice. Food arrived relatively quickly, and the server made sure to check up on us from time to time. Also, I liked his sense of humor.

Atmosphere: Not as dreamy/intimate as New Eritrea in the Sunset, but still a nice place for dinner. Seemed to accomodate groups okay; the place itself is smaller than New Eritrea though. 

Location: Extra props for being super accessible from the Geary bus stops.

Overall, I really like Assab, and hope to be back in the New Year.
author: Helene K.

description: If they delivered, I would be Jabba the Hutt fat. The Gored-gored beef is my favorite dish... I HAVE to get it everytime.
author: Maggie T.

description:
I came here on a Monday night with two other people. The tables were half occupied so we didn't have any problems getting a table. The decor is nothing to brag about but your here for the food, right? 

Here's what we ordered: 

Vegetable Sambusa -- came out steaming and were crispy 
Meat Sambusa -- was tastier than the vegetable one 

Vegetable Combination -- the potatoes (Vegetable Alicha) were quite good. The okra and zucchini were edible. 

Kelwa Beggee (Lamb) -- this dish had a great kick. The lamb was a little tough but overall a good choice. 

We also ordered Malbec from the wine list that wasn't too bad. 

I'd say it's a good middle of the road Eritrean restaurant. For from this part of the world I prefer Axum or the Blue Nile in Berkeley.
author: Thang H.

description: we've eaten here a few times and they are consistently delicious. super nice staff, too. highly recommend.
author: Ben M.

description:
I never tried Ethiopian food before but by someone's recommendation, I tried it with my friends. Make sure you bring friends to share the food with!

The food is delish but if you're not into trying unique food and hate yogurt, this is NOT the place for you. Again, I repeat, this is NOT a place for yogurt haters, non-lamb eaters (cause the lamb is goooo-d), greeddddy people (who don't like to share......)
author: Cliff T.

description:
One of my girlfriends and I have a monthly "ethnic" dinner night, where we try cuisine we've never had before. In February it was "Eritrean". 

Given I spent 3 years in DC with friends with Eritrean neighbors in their 'hood, this was a great opportunity to try the cuisine of this small-ish African country. Of course we kept almost making the mistake of comparing Eritrean to Ethiopian cuisine whilst at dinner, but learned from our dinner companions that this is a definite no-no, given the civil war that had ensued. All this history aside, we were happy to finally have the chance to eat with our hands. And who knew we would be so full afterwards! 

The bread (similar to naan) is surprisingly filling. We ordered a variety of dishes - all recommendations from our server - and we were pleased with them all. We also ordered the honey wine, and sadly, all 6 of us would advise you to not try that. I mean, do it for the experience, but the 6 of us are sticking with wine from grapes. :)

All in all - from the busy ambiance, to the long wait, it was very clear that this was a popular restaurant. And once we were eating, we understood why. It was so delicious, we all decided we wanted to return again soon ourselves!
author: Sally M.

description:
Great Ethiopian/Eritrean food.  Very friendly service.  Expect to wait about 20-30 minutes for your meal.  If you are buying for 2, get the meat platter.  It will save you money and will end up spending less than $10 per person.  
Try their honey wine!  If you're not a huge fan of their beer (Harrar) mix it with some sprite!  Taste great!
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I always take my friends from out-of-town here because where else are you encouraged to eat with your hands in a nice-ish restaurant?  Now, let's go over the highlights.

The Yay:
+  Um,  it's Eritrean food!  One point just for the diversity factor!  Even in ultra-diverse SF, there's some things that you can't get on every street corner. 
+ It's fun!  Imagine sitting in front of a giant platter of colorful food with all your friends, and you're all grabbing the foods with your hands.  Who cares about table manners or holding back?  It's a food that's meant to be enjoyed with company.  I like that.
+ Visual flare!  Look at the pictures!
+ Flavaaa!  I'd suggest you get the meat combination platter, since it lets you try the beef, chicken, and lamb.  Lamb= the best.  Add the mushroom entree to your platter too; it's really smooth and I tell myself that it balances out all the heavy meats.  The main foods come on a bed of sour tortilla-ish bread (injera), with dollops of yogurt.  What I like best about this cuisine is the way all the different flavors - the sourness of the injera bread, the cooling taste of the yogurt, the spice of the meats - blend together.  Nice complements!

The Nay:
- They take their sweet-a$$ time.  I came here once with my parents, and after we ordered, I sat in there and read several chapters of a book while they walked over to Trader Joe's for a stroll.  When they came back 45 minutes later, the food still wasn't served.  Same thing happened the other few times I came here.  I am impatient, so making me wait = terribad.  Another reason why it's a good idea to come here with a good group of people to pass the time with. 

Just a note on Eritrean etiquette:  Eat with your right hand.  Left hand is for wiping your....

Anyway.  Happy eating!
author: Vivian C.

description:
Savoring their fare, it becomes so clear why there were spice wars in the world. On one plate I have never tasted such variety in flavors. The depth of spicy, savory and tart is surprising and unique to this type of cuisine. And a special tip for you carnivores: the kitfo (rare) is in a league of its own.

There is something inexplicably satisfying about digging into a pile of hot something with hands, and shoveling it into my mouth. As shown by my Balinese friends, there are far more graceful ways to consume, especially aided by bread (and Assab's injera is ideal in its sourness and spongeyness) but I think that'd take half the fun out of it.

At Assab they don't make you feel badly for diving right in. The staff is warm and friendly, and environment casual if not a bit plain. If your main objective is to impress perhaps there's a better alternative, but for a meal out with good friends, you're bound to enjoy!
author: Ligaya T.

description:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian/Eritrean food, and I was delighted. Tasty food and good service. Thanks to our server for helping us out with menu choices.

Also thanks to my fellow Yelpers for reviewing this place. I did a little research via Yelp before I went, so I was prepared for the part where you eat with your hands :).

In summary: YUM. I wanted to go back the next day for more.
author: Mariah N.

description:
When I was in training I had to go through "Courtesies and Customs" course. Translated that means I had to have someone evaluate me on how I sat in a chair with a straight back and used my forks and knives. WTF! Am I a solider or some fruitcake eating at Chez Francois? You bet that every chance I get to eat with my freaking hands I go for it. And with Eritrean food.. it's time to get down to business. 

I'm not going to school anyone about what Eritrean food is. All I know is that it's damn good. I've always ordered the combo meat meal which is where you get to sample 3 different plates. It's so damn good. It's fun eating it too. You just break off a piece of the "bread" and eat with the meat. The spices and sauces and excellent. They have a few vegetarian dishes that my friend likes which means that it's one of the few restaurants that we both have never walked out disappointed. 

The staff is really nice too. They are helpful and make great recommendations for people like me who are not familiar with the food. I was here late one night and they were very patient with the people who came in near closing. Personally, I would have kicked them out of the joint. 

It's only street parking but it's not hard to find in the area. 

I think overall it's a fun place with good food. I love it when everyone gets to eat with their hands. Eat that Ms. Manners.. If you ever visit I'll be the guy in the corner with food drooling down my mouth and meat sauce all over my hands and shirt. I may look like crap but trust me.. I'll be the damn smiling fool.
author: Dan T.

description:
FXXX Man! 
This is hard for me to say but I admit.
No, I DIDN"T like it because ......
I think I wasn't ready.
I didn't know better.
I wasn't old enough.
I was immature.
I was such a dumb ass.
I was eating Sushi too much.
I thought it's Ethiopian.
I didn't even know the country.
I didn't know the difference between Eriitean & Ethiopian
What an idiot I was.
And Yes, I was a small minded person!

I was with my 2 boys in here few times already and they insist me to re consider to change my review for the place.
I usually don't do it but they saw me eating the Eritrean food like a pig in mud.
Yes, it's a great spicy food.
I think 100% Eriitean.
People are so nice here.
So, I gotto say OUT LOUD,
I LIKE ASSAB!!!!!
But, I say "Asabu" all the time.

I have learned, but why always hard way?
author: Nobu K.

description:
This is Eritrean food, similar to Ethiopian, with the principle difference being that Eritrea was colonized by Italy where Ethiopia was not, so a few dishes have an italian flair, and they serve italian desserts and coffee drinks.  Another difference is that eritrean food is served with yogurt where ethiopian is not.  

This is a very pleasant if not crowded restaurant, simply appointed but with a heavily aromatic feel to it, fragrant of berbere, a dry spice blend concocted from dried red chilies, ginger, turmeric, shallots, fenugreek, allspice, black pepper, cardamom, cloves, hot peppers, cumin and sometimes other ingredients. 

My dining companion and I ordered a meat and a veggie combination and shared them family-style, which is the way to go with East African food because you will always get to try more dishes.  The base ingredient for many of the wats (ethiopian stews) is called awaze, a paste made from the berbere.  The meat dishes, doro wat (chicken), zigni (beef) and yebeg wat (lamb) were all very flavorful and the meats tender.  The vegetarian dishes weren't as good, but the lentils and spinach were good accompaniments.  The best part of any good ethiopian/eritrean meal is the spongy injera bread, especially the layer that lines the bottom of the platter soaking up all the flavorful exotic sauces.

Service was attentive and friendly, and the owner gracious in explaining the preparations, spices and origins of the food.  This place is cheap too: one entree is $7.25, the three item combo, $9.75.  The entire lunch was under $20.

Update 6/10/06: Full Eritrea-Ethiopia history lesson today.
author: Rick H.

description:
I went with some friends to Assab, just on a lark.  I don't know much about Ethiopian/Eritrean food (and yes, I know the two countries don't like to be lumped together like that, and yes, I know there's what you might call a bit of a war on, but just breathe in, breathe out, and let it go for the purposes of this review).  In fact, I don't really know much beyond what almost anyone would know: it's served in a big bread platter, and you eat it all with your hands, and it's spicy and lentily.

Why do desert countries always have the hot and spicy food?  In a logical universe, the spiciest food in the world would be Eskimo food, and food from the topics and deserts would be bland and cool (if cool is a taste).  I mean, you already don't have any water, so why pile on the spicy food?  Madness!
