[P.S.: I know why.  I know spicy food makes you sweat, which cools you down in warm climates.  And I know water only makes the burn worse, and what you want is milk.  But what I said was funnier.  Put the smug PM down and just focus on the review.]

The service was really good--a middle-aged guy who was appropriately friendly.  The family of one of my friends spent a long time in Ethiopia back in the day, so he pretty much did the ordering for us.  I'm not sure everything we had was on the menu, but everything we had was wonderful.  I just wish there had been more food, but I guess that goes with the territory when you're eating Ethiopian food.  (rimshot)

I did experience a bit (well, more than a bit) of Za Haqle's (Google it) revenge afterwards.  Apparently, my Wyoming heritage didn't prepare me for Ethiopian food.  Who knew?
author: Ben P.

description:
When I told my mother that I was taking my brother to eat Eritrean/Ethiopian food, she said with a laugh, "What do you eat at Ethiopian? Dinosaur?" Aghast at my mom's ignorance but also bemused at her strange sense of humor (maybe that's where I get it from?), I tried to explain the wonders of this complex, yet humble cuisine. There is something very primally satisfying about eating with your hands, with the injera serving more as a sponge for all the delightfully seasoned sauces than as a utensil. Ordinary meats like beef, chicken, and lamb are taken to a level most Western or Eastern palates have not experienced. At least, that's what *good* Eritrean/Ethiopean food is like...and Assab most definitely delivers with a delectable dining endeavor.

On this trip, we ordered:

- Vegetable Sambusa: started out with this nicely sized fried envelope stuffed with green peas, carrots and spices. It was a little messy to eat, and I was surprised that it wasn't served with some kind of sauce. Not bad for $2.

- Shiro: pureed chick peas, whose consistency conjured up thoughts of something between baby food and whipped mashed potatoes. I'm on the fence whether that's a good or bad thing. The flavor fares more positively, well seasoned and cooked with onions, tomatoes, and pepper.

- Meat combination: which included small portions of the:
#3 Zigni: small pieces of beef cooked with onions, tomato, butter, and an added kick of hot pepper. This was quite good, though the beef was a little chewier than I would have liked and the butter flavor was not as strong as at New Eritrea.

#4. Tsebhi - Derho: we got one chicken leg on the bone (though you can also get thighs), cooked in a sauce similar to the Zigni. I really wish that there was more meat to this...will definitely have to try it as a full entree and not as part of the meat combo next time.

# 8. Alicha-beggee: cubes of lamb mixed with potatoes, carrots and bell peppers. The flavor was strong, without being overpoweringly "lamby." I believe Michael Bauer has used that exact term.

- Vegetable combination: a sampling of three standby Ethiopean vegetable dishes:
#13. Veg alicha: Potatoes, carrots, bell peppers, cabbage are subtly seasoned and melt in your mouth. Toss up between this and New Eritrea.

#14. Okra: delicious stew of okra that does a good job of riding the line of texture for okra; not too firm, and not too slimy.

#15. Zucchini: probably the weakest link, similar in seasoning to the okra. I am not a huge zuchini fan, so meh.

The injera that Assab uses is very good, though I do think that New Eritrea wins in this category. Assab's injera seems to be structurally a bit too thin. If you look at the structure of the surface of the injera, you'll see that it is very "holey." I think that this is why the injera falls apart so easily while handling the food.  The taste is also a bit on the mild side for me and could have used a bit more tang. Another bummer is that they only give you one piece of injera per person; New Eritrea gives you two. An extra only costs $0.75, so it's not a huge deal but something to note. Assab also has super cheap drinks - a bottle of honey wine is $19, by the glass is $5. Imported beers are no more than $3.75, and fruit juices are good as well. As far as the service, I think that our waitress secretly hated us because we took forever to decide. We also thought it was strange that they didn't give us small plates when we ordered our appetizer.

Overall, I'd say that the seasoning of the food at Assab is some of the best I've had of Ethiopian/Eritrean in SF (on par with New Eritra). I would highly suggest this place to introduce someone to this exotic cuisine (and dispel any misconceptions about dinosaur meat...). Since the combination samplings are so small, I recommend picking a few full entrees if you are sharing with a group of people. That way there will be more to go around and more chances to determine if you like it or not. This is a very social cuisine, so be sure to wash your hands, dig in, and have fun!
author: Steph P.

description:
Food: Among the all time best in SF.  Holy flavors! And a lot of it, too - the next morning, 12 hours later I was still full. The food is a bit spicy, so those of you with sensitive tongues beware.  Lentil soup is possibly the best I have ever had.

Service: Kinda slow, long time between soup and main course which always drives me nuts.  There were only 2 servers working the place on a Friday night. Missed important details of our order, like keeping egg-containing items on a separate plate from an egg-allergic diner.  Minus one star.
author: Madeline D.

description:
Admittedly, I have not been a fan of Ethiopian or Eritrean food in the past.  A few times trying this cuisine over many years had failed to make a fan out of me, so I just kind of crossed those restaurants off of my list, as well as any new prospects.

Thank goodness for Green Bunny - she brought me to Assab, and I am so glad I tried it again!  My experience there was very, very good - and even my most feared part of the meal (big soggy sour spongy pancake called Injera) tasted good.  I don't LOVE the big pancake, but I liked it enough to eat more than I ever dreamt possible.  And just so you know, the pancake is all that you get as far as a utensil, so it's either pancake, or no dinner for you.  To be correct, eat with your right hand, and put your left hand in your lap.  I learned to do this in India so it is second nature for me.  Due to this way of eating, your right hand will smell like your dinner for hours afterwards unless you are an expert at not letting any of the sauces touch your fingers.

As far as the food...what is on top of the pancake is magically delicious.  I decided to go for the meat sampler, which included lamb, beef and chicken, with sides of lentils, salad and yogurt.  The presentation is great - it comes on a big platter all for you! and it's fragrant and colorful and tastes great, with just enough spice but not too much that your head is on fire.  The chicken was my favorite - a leg piece with falling-off-of-the-bone tender meat, with excellent flavor.

A glass of honey wine is like sunshine in your mouth, as bright as the gold-toothed smile of our server and just as warming.

The atmosphere is a little sparse, but neat and clean.  The prices are very reasonable (around $8-11 per entree).

So, Eritrean food has joined the ranks of "foods from around the world that I love to eat", and I will be sure to visit Assab again soon.
author: Liz S.

description:
Running around triple booked multitasking - still hadn't eaten lunch at 430p and picked up my Mac at Total Mac and yelped for something new.  

(Quick and sweet just get to the meat - this aint no blog, or even a tweet.)  First of all, hat fantastic SMELL when you go in.  There was nothing at all from top to toe on this menu that wasn't outstanding.  We ordered like hogs (2 meat plates and one veggie plate for 2 of us) and both the meat and veggie sambusa.  Everything extraordinary.  Total about $50, a little steep for a huge lunch, but when you spend a little more as long as you get A TON more for your money, I'm good.  Can't wait to come back.  

The couple that owned were EXTREMELY accomodating.
author: Enzo L.

description:
Assab Eritrean Cuisine sounded interesting when we saw it on Groupon so we went for it, on a Thursday evening.  The Groupon was for two dinners with wine included. We didn't fully understand how the "two dinners" bit would work but we were told there was about a $16.50 price limit on the main entrees we could order so we were not able to order the dishes we initially wanted. In the end that was no big deal because what we did have was really delicious.

We started with a veggie sambusa (much like a Samosa) that was perfectly seasoned and very tasty.

For main dishes we had #6 Kelwa-Mix (chicken & veggies in a nice sauce) and #7 Kelwa-Beggee (tasty lamb cubes in a spicy pepper sauce). Naturally the full meal also included other items:  lentils, nicely spiced chopped spinach, some lettuce, tomatoes, jalapeño on the side and an extra injira each.

The food was extremely good, fresh and we were served just the right amount. There was nothing left on our plate, but we were plenty full and couldn't have eaten dessert.

Initially the server was a bit stern as we were ordering, probably because of our not understanding the price limit on the Groupon. However, once we ordered and started receiving our food she warmed up and ultimately the service was excellent.

We had gone early and there was only one server and a gentleman seating guests but later another woman arrived too. I spoke with her about other Ethiopian and Eritrean food we had had previously and found her too was most delightful. When I mentioned coming back on a weekend she suggested making reservations, which I appreciated.

All around a very good experience that instilled in us a desire to go back.
author: Dennis B.

description:
'nother yelp find, if ya gots a car, aren't too particular for ambiance, it's darn tasty and low $.

Mom and Pop shop that one had one person serving on a sorta crowded Monday night (thanks for blowin' this on up on the interwebs).

We kinda felt bad for the guy, running around and practically asked for the check when we ordered cuz everyone wanted his attention.

They only gave you one napkin and the skin like dough to scoop it up with (served on another piece of same dough).
I guess that's traditional

Not a big fan of finger forkin' , maybe if I was sitting in the dirt at Burning Man,,,, so I asked for silverware, got a gold plated smile and a tablespoon.

If you love Indian curry or spicy food you will love the new wrinkle this place provides.

Bottom line, we will be back.
author: G K.

description:
Thinking back on my many encounters with Eritrean cuisine, I realize that it's helped me mark some significant memories. I think my FIRST Eritrean meal was also my FIRST dinner in New York during my FIRST visit to New York. So I guess Eritrean food brings back some fond memories.

On this visit to Assab, we established one more FIRST: my children's first experience with Eritrean cuisine. And those of you who've had the pleasure, know what I mean when I say, "boy did I pick something that's quite a departure from our everyday fare of Chinese and American food." 

But hold on, let's think about this. Eritrean food is really just an assortment of meat and vegetable stews. It's served with a spongy flat bread that doubles as an eating utensil (you pick the food up with pieces of the bread), so you never use silverware. There's nothing more primitive and strangely comforting than eating with your hands...and kids love that. They do it regardless of whether it's supposed to be done or not, because it's just plain natural. I think that's part of the appeal of eating fried chicken, hamburgers and hot dogs. 

Speaking of natural...we like to challenge our kids and their natural instinct to avoid what isn't "normal" to their everyday lives. Teaching them about other cultures through food and giving them a bit of historical and current information regarding the country is a great way to broaden their horizons. I had mentioned to another parent that we were going to take them to Eritrean food, and he grimaced as if he'd tried and didn't care for it. But you know, he's never even laid eyes on the cuisine, so I don't know how you can knock something that you know nothing about. 

So back to the food. I've been to a lot of Eritrean restaurants. The best so far is still the Blue Nile in New York City; but since that one is closed, this one is my new favorite. There's a big emphasis on spicy foods, but most of the entrees can be made mild. And if you've never done Eritrean, there's nothing weird about it. Like I said, it's mostly stews and the sambusas are excellent starters. The flavors, though unique, aren't so strong or wildly different from our usual American fare; so even newcomers to the cuisine should be able to find something they like. 

By the way...the kids really enjoyed their first experience; they even saw a game on display at the restaurant that they had played before...now they know where it came from and what that culture eats. Who woulda thought I could turn my food obsession into something productive?   :-)
author: Virg Y.

description:
Best Eritrean/Ethiopian I've had in the city.. "hands" down. 

And I eat a lot of it. A lot.

No atmosphere to speak of -- I like the lively neighborhoody vibe at Axum better -- but foodwise it was off-the-charts good. Maybe it was a good night, I don't know, but I've walked into so many bad nights at other joints that it was refreshing to eat a complete plate with nary an overstewed vegetable nor chewy morsel of meat in sight. If you get down like I do with the Ethiopian/Eritrean then you know exactly what I'm talking about.
author: Tom L.

description:
If you're scared by this whole "Ethiopian" concept because all you've grown up with is South Park and you expect people from any east African country to make clicks when they speak, let me tell you something. South Park is wrong! That's only Somalia. 

The food here was so tasty. We ordered some of the honey wine. I know people really seem to like it, but it kind of reminded me of a honey-flavored version of Manischewitz. But then again, those countries are pretty close so perhaps they share their wine-making tips.

We ended up ordering 1 meat and 1 vegetarian dish: the Tsebhi-Derho (which was chicken with peppers and onions) and the Vegetarian Alicha (which had potatoes). It comes on a large plate with lots of lentils and beans all on a giant injera (a pancake-like tortilla). We each got our own injera with the meal and went through it in about, oh, 2 minutes. 

There are no utensils as a part of this meal so if you've ever wanted to truly be yourself on a first date, come here. Use your fingers to grab that piece of chicken you missed and swipe some lentils with your pinky. 

The prices are really reasonable and the decor is enjoyable while managing to be in a very simple location. 

Assab from the little tv against the wall that kept distracting me from my friend's pearls of wisdom, I thought this place was a really good find. You  won't see the last of me!
author: Jared S.

description:
This place NEVER disappoints. 

I'm not so sure that it's authentic--I've never really had Eritrean food in Eritrea--but it's great. If I had to classify the food taste in terms of what I'm familiar, it would have to be a more intense version of indian food.  I love that I have to eat with my hands out of an enourmous family style "thali".

YUM

I just found out that my friend's family owns this place! YEAH I love supporting family owned establishments--and you should too!
author: Ruchita P.

description:
Word to the wise: ration the injera.  It looks small, but it WILL expand in your stomach while you're too busy wolfing up the amazing food on the huge platter and leave you with the agony of being entirely too full.  

Portions are huge and the service is very friendly.  Good value all around.
author: Kyla B.

description:
...wow, this place is awesome!!! 

a friend took us here to share some of her favorite foods from her culture with us and i was so stoked... 

i love to travel and experience other peoples way of life... 

...eating with your hands is a wonderful experience and 
to tell you the truth, i dont know the names of the dishes we ordered because she did all of the ordering in the native language from Eritrean... 
..it was the 3 meat combo with lamb, chicken and beef!!! 
all you need to know is that the food was absolutely delish!!! ... i even drank a couple of beers from Ethiopia!!! 

what a great way to experience a new culture with out buying a plane ticket... 

this is a must try if you would like to consider yourself a foodie!!!
author: Nic M.

description:
I didn't care much for Ethiopian food until my pregnant wife started having cravings for it. You know what you do when a pregnant woman has a craving? That's right, you do whatever the hell she wants! But you know, I really like it now. I even like it that I get prune fingers from eating with my hands. I'm big on eating with my hands.

The food's good and the portions are pretty hefty. The staff is always super friendly, bordering on desperate. It's nice, makes me feel appreciated.

Damn, I got a craving for some zigni now.
author: Josua P.

description:
So my roomate and I came here after our 4 mile run to Ocean Beach.... and boy were we starving... since we live just around the corner we always talked about trying this place out. I did hear that it was pretty good and you eat with your hands... and i love new things.......so...

Prepare yourselves because the food was amazing!! We had the kelwa-derho( lamb) and  the kelwa-beggee.(chicken)... Please don't be intimidated by eating with your hands because trust me... it makes the food taste better and you can eat faster. We literally finished the food in 3 minutes... The owner came over because he thought we had a question... and when he saw our plate was wiped clean... he started laughing and clapping his hands.... yeah...we...all we said while we were eating  was "this is so good... omg it's so good!"
 it was that good! so if you like good food come here! the food is spiced perfectly.. it's not oily... and it wasn't too spicy... it was perfectly spicy... :D I highly recommend this place and the owner is so nice and cute( in a little old man way)
author: Regina L.

description:
Don't fool yourself with things like honey wine or beer that's from Ethiopia.  These are just gimmicks that people who enjoy things like olaliberry wine or fried twinkies will tell you to enjoy.  It's about the food.  Go to BevMo if you want to be wowed by flavorings in liquids.

Anyways, the food.  Other Ethiopian places pale in comparison to this place.  The food is just excellent.  I can't say more because there is nothing more to say.  Also I haven't been there in a while.

Check out the pub that's on the same block, they have a great selection of whiskeys and scotch's.
author: Pouria Y.

description:
Great food, great service, great environment.
The only problem I experience was they ran out of some of the items on the menu when they were really busy  (and they are really busy often).

One of my favorite places to eat
author: Nathan G.

description:
I'm so full I wouldn't bend over right now if god dropped a diamond in front of me.

My mom and i go in here on a Friday all sulky and grumpy.  We order alcohol, which was a good start.  Nice server. We order #7 and 8 family style.  We got these bc you they can make them less spicy. Be aware: most of their stuff is spicy! They bring out what look like crepes at first, but I think they were jellyfish intestines or sea-towels... you will see what i mean.  Then comes our order served on a huge platter. It was great fun to dig in and get messy with these dishes. This is were the giggles kicked in. I learned that in the former USSR as a med school requirment you had to pluck onions and potatoes for a month or more during the summer......more alcohol.....and you were only allowed 2 showers a week..."thank you for bringing me to america mama and buying me stew in an african restaurant that i am supposed to eat with sea-towels."  

I was stuffed, so we ordered the sambusa too.  Kinda like a russian "piroshki" a little zesty and really good.  At this point my mom and I are hysterical and innovative, as a result stay tuned for a great product from the mind of my very own mother: iBalls.  A product that will teach men how to be men and have balls....interesting things happen when 2 girls from odessa eat and drink ourselves silly.
author: Aristocles P.

description: Delicious. We ordered four dishes for four people and had a lot of leftovers. The shiro was pretty different from what I've had before - it was a lot more tomato-y and less chickpea-ish, but still very tasty. The bersin (lentils) were great. I found the veg alicha was bland, but everything was nicely cooked. I liked the tsebhi derho a lot, although I prefer other versions with more berbere. We also had a ground beef dish, I believe kitfo, which we had cooked. Normally I don't go for ground beef dishes, but this one was really nice, especially with the cottage cheese. We had to get extra injera for everyone, which was fine. The vegetable sambusas were a little plain but good. Overall I thought everything was pretty great, but not as heavily spiced as I would have liked. I prefer New Eritrea a bit but would definitely go back here if I were in the area. The service was really friendly and attentive, and it definitely got crowded on a Sat. night by 8.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I must confess: I didn't want to tell y'all this. However, sharing is caring. This is my favorite place for my favorite cuisine, ever, period.

For a very long time, Massawa was my favorite East African joint around. I looked around the Bay, from Oakland to San Jose, but never found anything close to the deliciousness of that place. I ate there once a week. I told everyone I knew about it. And then one day, the owners sold it (to another family member, I think), and things there changed subtly. Sure, the notoriously slow service at Massawa got faster... but something got left behind in the bargain. Freshness? Heat? I'm not sure what. Massawa is still very good, but it's a shadow of its former self.

Imagine my delight when I moved to the Richmond last summer, and not only discovered Assab in my neighborhood... but also reunited with the former owners of Massawa. Yes, the service is slow as it ever was when you go during peak hours, but good lord I just don't care when I get there -- I want sambusas and injera and zigni and kelwa dehro in my mouth, and I'll be good and patient, and I'll quietly wait until it's time for my mush.

So, in conclusion: just eat here all the time, okay?
author: Arsenio S.

description:
Assab, 

I love you so much! Every week I crave to lather my tongue with your delicoius and delicate gravies, dip into your cooling yogurt sauce, and sink my teeth into your pull-off-the-bone meat. Sometimes I wait to see you, and think I can just see you on Sunday, but you're always closed on that day! I think, ' gosh, you're just that hot' you can just brush everyone off and make them wait a little more. And then, when I actually do see you, you make me wait soooo long, even after you take my order, that when I get my dish, I just want to devour you, and eat every last bit. 
But even if I can't eat anymore, even if I was ripping at the seams, I can just take you home for some delicious leftovers (and eat with sour cream). I wouldn't dare waste a bite. 

I love you so much, that I would come to you hungover. 
I would come to you starved and wait forever.
I would stand there in front of everyone staring back at me, right by that door, and wait for my freakin' table. 

I love you Assab. 

I'll wait forever. I've crossed oceans of restaurants to find you...

All the Best & Forever, 
Danielly

P.S. My boyfriend Rich thinks the same about you, he can't stop licking his fingers ;)
author: Danielly A.

description: We popped in last night for an early dinner (they open at 4 pm). I've been wanting to try Assab for quite a while as I am a fan of Ethiopian food and had heard that Eritrean food is similar. We picked the meat sampler, lentils (half red, half brown), Ethiopian stout, and Ethiopian honey wine. The injera here seems to be more whole grain than what I've had before and I must say I prefer this. The beef was nicely spiced and moderately spicy. The yogurt took the slight heat off the tongue nicely. The lamb and chicken were less spicy but still flavorful. The meat was not quite "falling off the bone" tender but was still tender enough. In addition to the lentils there was a small portion of cooked greens and a little green salad. The stout and honey wine were tasty as well. Service was nice and friendly. We left very happy and very stuffed.
author: Roberta B.

description:
The best Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurant I've found since moving from DC!!  

We got the kitfo (spiced raw ground beef), the meat combo, and the veggie combo.  It was all delicious, especially the kitfo.  I am used to more spice in DC, but this was still very flavorful and it was preferred by some of my friends who are spice wusses - I mean, less into super spicy food.

The injera is a little thin on the sides, but nice and spongey in the middle.  I like a little more tang in my injera, but it was still pretty good all in all.  I am looking forward to going back!
author: Leslie L.

description:
I don't pretend to be an expert in this ethnicity.  I've eaten at about 5 restaurants in this style.  But this is the best I've ever had.  The portions, taste, fragrance, and price make it one of my favorite recommendations to friends.

The atmosphere is simple and free of snobbery.  The proprietors are friendly people who will serve you with quiet graciousness.  I recommend either of the two lamb dishes and the vegetable sampler.
author: Eric X.

description: First, you need to remember that good things come to those who wait. This restaurant has slow service because one person greets you, takes your orders, clears tables, handles your bill and says good bye. He owns the restaurant and cares! But, know that the wait is worth it! The food is amazing- meat and veggie combos are a must. Once you get past eating with your fingers, you will truly enjoy the experince.
author: Jen F.

description:
My friend was spending his last few days in San Francisco and suddenly had a desire to eat Ethiopian Food. We found this one and decided to give a try. 

Food 2 Stars. I saw the menu and the first thing which struck me was the 'Sambusa'. We have a snack called 'Samosa' in India and the Eritrean / Ethiopian 'Sambusa' sounded interesting. It turned out to be something similar!!! We ordered a Lentil Soup and a Vegetarian Combo. The soup was average. The combo turned out to be 4 -5 different dishes on a large plate. We also got side orders of crepes which tasted like 'Appams' from my native state Kerala, in Southern India. The dishes on the combo itself tasted very Indian. I wonder whether the chef is Indian or they really serve such food in Eritrea. Not sure which part of Africa would  have food which tasted Indian!! Somehow i felt some concerns about the cleanliness of the place

Ambiance 2 Stars. Nothing great about the ambiance. Pretty chilly in there. Seemed to  have turned off the heater

Service 2 Stars. They did not bring us even hand tissues until we asked. The restaurant was crowded but they seem to take forever to bring the food.

Overall a two. You Can try once to get a taste of Eritrea
author: Sankar B.

description:
Wow, you know this place is as good as people say.  Yes, Yes, i know you hear that "other" people have their ideas about "good", but this one is spot on.

Tables: VERY clean
Dishes: HUGE
Spice: full flavor with a kick
Oily: none in sight!

I would try the combination platters and followed up by their Ethiopian Stout beer.  The cost is actually quite cheap ($15.50) which can be shared with two people.

So, hit this place up for a cozy din din or with a group looking for laughs and giggles.  As for me next time i am going after the sautéed raw lamb cubes with a "few" bottles of stout.
author: Jai D.

description: Order the lamb stew, the vegetarian lentil, oh and the the banaut (a stew-like mixture of the bread and meats) is amazing on a cold day. This is a great place to bring people from out of town.
author: M R.

description:
One of the better Eritrean restaurants in the city. The portions are large,the price is cheap and the service is great. The owners have been in the business in the city for the last 20yrs at different locations including Massawa in the upper haight.

I highly recommend the vegetarian combo or the chicken dish.
author: Teddy d.

description: I like this place a lot.  Delicious food, good prices, friendly staff and you eat with your hands! Yay!
author: Julienne G.

description: Went back to Assab with the younger daughter again recently. It is a nice friendly place with good service. We had the veggie and meat samplers and loved it as usual. The chicken and beef zigni are out of this world. The best place I've found in the city for Ethiopian/Eritrean food by far.
author: Sam P.

description:
What a treat! Zara, the owner at Cafe International, is Eritrean, and she tipped me off to this place after asking her for a recommendation for good Eritrean food in the city.

We arrived just after 1pm on a Saturday afternoon and found the place almost empty. The owner, his name is escaping me, was adorable and extremely attentive.

Since it was our first time eating there we ordered both the meat and veggie samplers, just to give some different dishes a try. The meat sampler came with beef, lamb, and chicken dishes. All of them were WONDERFUL. The sweet and spicy sauces were beautifully complimented by the sour and tangy injera. When this all was topped with a cooling dollop of their homemade yogurt, the combination of flavors was like an explosion in my mouth. Amazing!

We enjoyed the veggie sampler, too, but not nearly as much. This plate included some yellow curry potatoes, an okra stew, and a zucchini stew. Both samplers also came with lentils and spinach. We loved the lentils and spinach, but other veggie dishes weren't nearly as amazing as the meat dishes.

Next time, it's MEAT MEAT MEAT.

Definitely give Assab a try, it's a delicious hidden gem.
author: Jill M.

description:
I literally have dreams about eating here if I do not get my Assab fix!

Excellent veggie dishes...
author: sally y.

description: This has been my favorite restaurant in San Francisco for the past year. I always order the shiro which is a flavorful ground chickpea dish when I'm alone or I share the vegetarian sampler dish when I bring a friend. Another essential part of this delicious food for me, considering I love spice is asking for the spicy paste they can give you. It definitely adds a kick! I go here about three times a month on a college student's budget which says a lot.
author: Jamie C.

description:
ah, finally!! i pass by this place all the damn time (even when it used to be an italian restaurant) and i never went there to eat until last night. we got there at a good time (7-8ish) because by the time we left, the place was packed. All the menu items were delicious sounding (for someone like me, it is heaven to see words like "butter", "jalapeno", "yogurt") and we ended up ordering a meat sambusa, lentil soup, kitfo (raw--the traditional way) and the veggie sampler (okra, potatoes/cabbage, zucchini). i loved the the lentil soup and their kitfo, it was decently spicy (not as hot as i was expecting) but definitely made my nose run and the yogurt was delicious. the crepe-like injera bread looks deceptively insufficient but by the end of my meal, i still had a third left--it's really filling! everything was tasty and smelled incredible. perfect hearty fare for a cold wet evening. 

i want to go back just because it's so close to home, inexpensive and i want to try their honey wine. plus, i loved the service--very gracious and polite.
author: kristin e.

description:
Four of us who know food ate here last week. We all feel that this was the biggest rip off in SF!  The food tasted like strained hospital food. What was on our plates could not have cost (total) $2 each and we were charged close to $100.  I would not recommend anyone to this place.

We cannot understand how this place got any good ratings! I think it has to do with the current fad of Eritrean food and the very ignorant your people who may think it cool to eat Eritrean. I would say, if you have to eat here save your money get some strained baby food or go tot he nearest hospital cafeteria!  Phil
author: phil s.

description:
The best finger food you will ever have.

We got various beef, lamb, chicken, and vegetable wat (stew) and they all tasted great. The stew is similar to Indian stews and curries, but with a lighter and sweeter flavor.

If you order 3 or more entrees, it is served in a huge bowl that with an injera (spongy flat bread) layer on the bottom.

Injera is awesome! You tear off a little piece of it and use it to scoop up the delicious stew in the bowl.

Go now!
author: Jeff D.

description:
We had an awesome time at Assab.  There were four of us (two couples) and we shared the meat sambusa, the veggie sambusa, the meat platter, and the vegetable platter.  Oh, and a bottle of delicious Ethiopian honey wine (which, incidentally, you can purchase at Rainbow Grocery for $8).  

I wasn't a big fan of the meat sambusa (the filling was a little dry), but LOVED the veggie sambusa and vegetable sampler platter.  They really do a great job with the veggies there; such great flavor and everything we ordered was distinguishable from the other.  We asked for extra injera, because I love the taste and texture of tart Ethiopian sponge bread.  

The service was great, too.
author: Diana Y.

description:
Not to hype this place up or anything, but I took a friend here recently and she said, "This is the best meal I've ever had in the city."

I'm just sayin'.

(I love the kantisha, the okra, and the Hakim stout myself.  Now, give me some points for usefulness plz, k thx)
author: Dwigt S.

description:
I spent two hours on yelp and looking at random websites to find the perfect place for my birthday dinner. I've never eaten at Assab before but I was not disappointed. In fact, I was impressed by how amazing the food was. Nicely spiced, just the right amount of spicy, and so much flavor! Loved the veggie sambusas! We had two family platters of the veggie combo, meat combo, and the chickpea, which easily fed the 8 of us. I love eating with my hands, and dinner was just fun since everyone has to chill out and just dig in. And if you're not already comfortable, I hear the Ethiopian Harar beers are tasty. It was definitely a good crowd that night and I can't wait to go back. 

Thank you Yelp and fellow yelpers for helping me pick Assab.
author: Faye P.

description: Assab has the best red and brown lentils I've ever had!  However, I've only ever been to four other ethiopian restaurants 3 in Berkeley and 1 in the city.  Not a huge fan of the chicken as it was quite a bit dry.  Otherwise, go for the vegetarian goodness at Assab!  Didn't try the lamb or beef.  Will definitely be back for the lentils!
author: k t.

description:
This place was a lot of fun to dine at on a friday night. It was definitely busy and food came out slow, but it was good.

Their light ethiopian beer is so tasty.
The samosalike appetizer was unique- my boy and I shared it. 
We each got a mixed platter, he of the meat me of the vegetarian. 
Everything was delicious and very filling.

Great Food, Great experience.

Be prepared for a unique array of spices, also its very warm and comforting food. But you have to be in the mood for it.

If I come here with veggie friends we can share a plate for a more family style eating option.
author: Sari G.

description:
Thought it was excellent; I used to go to Cafe Colucci all the time in Oakland, and thought Assab was just as good. The service was fine, and the honey wine extremely potent! 

Tip: make reservations in advance - I called 2 days ahead and the latest we could get in on a Saturday night was 6:30pm.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Love Ethiopian food (still don't know the difference between Ethiopian and Eritrean cusine), so I was looking forward to this meal. Wasn't disappointed at all. 

We ordered the vege. platter and selected about 10 items. The only complaint was that when they served the platter, they didn't explain which items were what...had to figure it out ourselves...good use of our deductive skills. 

Other than that, the service was friendly, and it seemed like a very good place for a nice dinner.
author: SG D.

description:
I like this place.  The owner used to have a little hole-in-the-wall over by City College, and when he closed down, I thought to myself, "ah, well that's it for Eritrean Food."  But lo and behold, a scant year or so later, I discovered that he'd opened a new place - and IN MY NEIGHBORHOOD, no less!  

The food is fantastic.  I mean, finger-lickin' good (with all apologies to the Colonel).  I love the little lamb dishes, and I love the vegetable combo - yes, you read that right - I love the VEGETABLE combo.  Now, I know some of you will say, "what's the big deal with lentils?"  To which I reply, "go to Assab, and you'll see!"  

A couple of minor drawbacks, decor is not so hot, so if you address any in your party as "Lord..." or "Lady...."  then they may be dissatisfied with the ambience.  Also, if you order anything particularly pungeant, you may have to wash your hands a few times to relieve yourself of the fragrance.

Put succinctly, great food, fun to eat.
author: Daniel O.

description:
Not much in the way of atmosphere but I like this place it is a good place the food is good the ownerwaiter is cool. 

I had the Kelwa-Mix (chicken, njera bread, veg, yogurt), tangylicious. Just the right amount of heat. IPA available. 

You will not find a burrito on the menu. This is Eritrean food.
author: Mark G.

description:
Group dinners, first-timers to eating with hands. Spice is the flavor here, incredible! and have some honey wine.. 

A colorful time and sweet staff, yes slow. But that's the pace you have to get down with here. 

I was introduced to it through people from Eritria - Not a bad sign!
author: devin s.

description:
Assab? Yeah, you're okay. I'd give you 3.5 if I could. But I can't, so I'm going with the 3.

I LOVE Ethiopian and Eritrean food. And I have spent a lot of time in the Horn of Africa, so this isn't just some trendy love of the food. 

I feel like this was not the best, unfortunately. I mean, if you live in the neighborhood, and you're craving some shiro or tibs or whatnot, it's okay. But it's not excellent. The portions are big, but the food tastes hastily thrown together, and not as though it were cooked with love. 

If you've not eaten a lot of food from the region, I think you'll like it, though. Not too spicey, not generally bad, just nothing to write home about either.
author: Jen B.

description: Love this place.  I think it's the best Ethiopian/Eritrean in San Francisco proper.  Also impressed by the friendly & personable service.
author: coco c.

description:
This place is absolutely delicious! They have meat and vegetarian dishes, all of which are great. The honey wine is way too sweet for my taste. It is a great experience for larger groups of people when you order food family style, which comes on a massive plate and you eat with your hands, although you can ask for a fork. 

The only drawback is that the service is pretty slow since there is only two people working there at a time, a father-daughter team. But when the food comes it makes up for it.

Go here! The food is soooooo good.
author: JC C.

description:
I made reservations at Assab for my girlfriend and I at about 2pm for 9pm that same night. When we arrived at the restaurant, we were immediately greeted by a screaming baby and no staff. After standing around for several moments not knowing what to do, we started walking towards an open table. As soon as we approached the table, someone hops out of the kitchen and asks what i'm doing. I told him I have a reservation for 9pm and I gave him my name. He crosses my name off a list and tells me that the table I was going for was not for us and that I would have to wait for a table to open up. 

What? Wait a minute... why did I make a reservation? Fail. We walked outside and headed for another restaurant.
author: Panos M.

description:
I can't rave enough about this place! The same waiter seems to always be working and he's so friendly that I want to ask him if he'll adopt me and let me eat injera all day. Because the food is served family style, Assab is perfect for groups. Even between two couples, the veggie and meat combinations were too much. 

But we all tried to eat as much as possible as to not hurt our waiter's feelings. He felt like Mom, only male so I guess that would make him Dad but Dad never really cared if we ate our food or not so really he was like Mom...but anyway, don't miss the honey wine!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
We went here last night to try an alternative to axum. So far Axum has stood out as my favorite of the ethiopian/eritrian places I have tried in SF. It still is.
I liked assab but the flavors weren't as bold as they are at axum. That said, the flavors and textures were a bit more delicate; they didn't taste like they had a lot of butter/oil in them.
We ordered way too much food to try as much an assortment as possible.
The red/brown lentils came with the order so we didn't get more. we should have; the red lentils were by far the best thing on the plate.
The chicken we had (boneless with jalapenos) was flavorful. The chickpeas were just odd. They were blended to have the consistency of peanut butter, and actually tasted like they had peanuts blended with them. I much prefer the chickpeas at axum.

The food was good but not crave worthy (I want to go back to axum a day after eating at axum. Not so much here).
The service on our visit was warm and friendly. A pleasant surprise after reading the reviews here.

So it's good, not great (3.5-4)but certainly better than average. Much easier parking than at axum.
author: Margie L.

description:
Great place to "test" out a (cheap) date!  Will they dig in and eat with their hands without a fuss?  And can they do so without making a complete mess?

Very casual atmosphere, with some nice African art to break up what otherwise might feel like a converted fast-Thai-food restaurant.  Efficient courteous service with a family-run feel.

Food was much spicier than I expected -- be prepared for your tummy to be doing summersaults -- and although I ordered the meat sampler plate, I was most impressed by the chicken on the bone and especially the lentils.
author: jill j.

description:
My favorite eritrean/ethiopian food in San Francisco! 

Will expound later but had to get my 5 stars in =)
author: jizzie b.

description: I live away from the city now, but whenever I return my immediate reaction is to go dine at Assab.  Every dish here is exquisite.  The side lentils and salads (comes with family style) compliments the rare spices fused with the well cooked meats in an superb manner.  The service is always excellent , the establishment is clean and cozy, and the kitchen aromas add and excellent vibe to the already exceptional experience.
author: Alexander R.

description:
This place is SO good....

The wait-staff is very nice, the food comes in a timely manner, and the parking isn't horrible.

Ethiopian/Eritrean food is a type of food I think everyone should try at least once. My friend Jen, who was skeptical at first, is now as addicted as I am!  Eating with your hands, using a crepe like substance to scoop up bits of meat, veggies, and yogurt sauce!! Yum, my mouth is seriously watering while I type this. Go try it!! You won't be disappointed!
author: Emily H.

description:
I really wanted to like Assab, but it fell short of my expectations.  Reading all the Yelp reviews, I was expecting delicious, amazing food.  Meanwhile I found the food decent at best.  The food wasn't super flavorful, and it hard to distinguish what was what on the plate.  I went with a group of four and we ordered family style: a chicken, a beef, the veggie sampler and spinach.  We had sambosas (veggie and meat) to start and above everything, I think I enjoyed those the most.  

Go to Assab Eritrean for what I can only assume as very authentic Eritrean food, and be prepared to get down with the scooping of food with the crepe-like bread...with no utensils in sight.  Three stars for a new experience.
author: Marie B.

description:
I am a HUGE fan of Ethopian food and loved this little gem.  

Food was inexpensive and the honey wine was fantastic!  

Casual atmosphere, I definitely recommend coming here.
author: Inga B.

description: Fabulous, Delicious food! I have been going here for 4 years and it keeps me coming back. The time to go is during the week because it is considerably less crowded. The food is phenomenal and they have plenty of vegetarian options. It can be made as mild or spicy as you wish. The management is also very friendly.
author: Erin H.

description:
This place was really tasty. When I first walked in, I was a little underwhelmed because the ambience of the place isn't so great, and there was no one to greet us. But we were kind of early (5:45). We seated ourselves and soon enough a really friendly waiter came out with menus. We ended up ordering one veggie sambusa, one meat sambusa for appetizers. They were both delicious. Nice and crispy, hot, and very flavorful. I really liked the veggie one because it had a kind of sweet filling with peas and carrots I think. 

For the entree we ordered one of the cubed chicken ones and also the mixed vegetable (potatoes, carrots, onions) plate which we got family style. The lentils and other stuff on the injera bread were really tasty too. I really liked the yogurt in the middle. YUM!! Would definitely go there again. The waiter was really nice too :) When we wanted to order more bread, he recommended against it, which turned out to be a good idea! Then he brought us forks so we could eat the really mushy flavor-soaked bread.
author: O K.

description:
Update - Still great, but I have to drop it to a 4 to 4 1/2 star.


Chicken #5, Vege #17, and Lamb #7 - yum...mmmm...good!

The menu is much better than Waziema - not that I take anything away from Waziema.  But, this place rocks!

The service, food, perfect spices, and good beer make Assab a must.

I can not wait to go back.
author: Kiki I.

description:
OK, let me get this out of my system first. GET THE LAMB.

That felt good. We also got some veggies (potatoes with carrots and peppers). It was definitely fun to get it family style. We got some sour cream/yogurt with our meal which was GREAT with the lamb.

I had an Ethiopian beer, Harar, which was actually quite delicious. Usually when I get a beer from a country not known for their beer, I expect a Budweiser knock-off. My girlfriend got some honey wine which was something I had never had before either and it was pretty good.

The waiters - there were two of them - were very friendly. Sure, it took a while for the food to come out but we didn't mind because it was so great when it did arrive.

I'm looking forward to coming back here again soon, which I'll be able to because of the great prices.
author: Stu M.

description:
So my sissy kept telling me about this place for a looong time. And so finally we went for her birthday dinner and wow! I have never eaten eritrean food and was skeptical at first but it is certainly amazing foo! Its like your eating at royalty level. They bring you this big round plate full of lamb, steak, potatoes, spinach, etc. with yummy yogurt to dip your magical portions on the soft pillowy cloud-like bread they give you.
If you want your money's worth, great service, a full tummy, and just yummy goodness magical food, you MUST try this place. The one on Irving was just as good, but I recommend this place because of the extra zest and spiciness they add.
I will definitely recommend and will go there again!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Met a friend for lunch here and the food was delicious. The Veggie Combo plate and the Kitfo are about as good as it gets. The service is slow, and many people here have caught on to that, but that's is just the custom in Eritrea. Not everything can be McDonald's fast and most Americans do not realize that. 

Funny enough this was my first time having Eritrean food in the Bay Area, but have run into Eritreans in other cities. My first encounter involved an Eritrean cab driver preaching to me in Vegas about sin after I had committed a few through the night and was on my way to committing a few more. Ineja is more sour than the feeling I got that night in the cab.
author: Arin N.

description:
Yummy - this is where my 400th review goes to! So far this is my favorite of all the Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants my boyfriend and I have eaten at. Granted, it's pricey, and out of the way (being in SF and all), but the quality and flavors of the food are delicious.

Easy parking across the street (street parking), and easy to find, the place is pretty clean and cheery. Service is a bit slow, but the food came out much faster than what I am used to at other Ethiopian restaurants. My boyfriend ordered the beef kitfo, rare, and also tried the honey wine, which had an interesting flavor (sweet, almost like a tea). I ordered the vegetable alicha, which was well flavored and saucy. The dishes also came with sides of lentils, which were VERY delicious and surprising. The injera bread is thin and light, and not as tangy as at other places.

Will be back!
author: Katherine P.

description:
We went here for my roommates' birthday last night, and it was really delish!  The food was great, the server was incredibly friendly, and overall the experience was EXCELLENT.

I took off 1 star because the service was a bit slow (but I guess that's part of the culture) and it's kind of quiet (my group is prone to saying things that are a bit inappropro at times).  In any case, I would definitely recommend Assab, and given the large "citysearch award" banner in their restaurant, I'm sure many others have recommended it before me.
author: Julie L.

description:
This place was amazing. I accompanied my friends who have been here more times than they can count, so it was nice to have the expert opinion on what and how to order. We got so much food that i couldn't tell you what it was, but the whole concept of using sponge bread as dinnerware was pretty great.. Messy, yes. fantastic for 5 drunkies, yes. The owner was extremely friendly, and his wife came out to talk to us at the end of our meal.. such a great environment, i'd say for 20-somethings, families, or anyone really..

We went to the Pig and Whistle down the street while we waited (30 minutes on a friday night, not bad), so when we sat down we were hungry and didn't have to wait long at all for our food...

First time eating Eritrean food and i'm hooked...
author: Danielle C.

description:
LOVE Assab.  That is a statement, not a request.

It was sad that the prices went up, but good for them you know?  Take it as a sign that business is good, they have cultivated a regular following, and let it be an indication to you that it is yummsers if you have not tried it yet.

It's not a good place if you are sensitive to Indian food (you know what I mean).  Or if you are a flatware snob and need some to eat (yep, not going to happen).  

But seriously, I recommend the vegetarian combo, and I love meat.  Staff is great, ambiance is good-  it's authentic and clean.  And also you should eat in, instead of taking to go, because part of the experience is being there and eating it; it's just not the same taking it to go.
author: Leia K.

description:
My boyfriend and I have made several attempts on the weekends to visit this place for a late lunch (the hours posted here for T-Sat are incorrect, it is not opened from 11AM -9:30 PM, refer to the screen shots of their MENU - T-Fri 4PM-9:30 PM and Sat 4PM-10:30 PM) without success.  Yesterday we were finally able to taste what all the buzz is about.  

I am glad that we made it there, the food was good (I'd say 3.5), the aromas were tantalizing, the service was friendly and you just can't beat the prices!  

This is what we ordered:

Meat Sambusa - Tasty, but a bit greasy
Kelwa-Derho - Alright, but not amazing
Meat - Combination - 
    Tsebhi-Derho - WONDERFUL
    Zigni - So/so
    Alicha-Beggee - AMAZING

Next time, I'll just go for the lamb because it was AMAZING.  The injera tastes of sourdough and has an interesting texture.  Admittedly, we were a little hesitant to use our hands.  I know, I know, we are lame.  Yet, I really appreciate the waitress providing us with forks!

All in all, I am pleased that we ventured outside of our culinary comfort-zone and tried something so unique.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I've eaten here twice now, & both times the meal has been delectably delicious & incredibly incendiary. They keep it just the right amount of spicy -- not quite "burn your face off" & not quite "I guess I don't need water after all". The service is friendly as well, but not overbearingly so. 

I love Waziema to death -- great bar, good food. But the menu at Assab blows 'em clean off the map.
author: Pete J.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect and asked them to show me Eritrean food - they didn't respond well to the request and said they serve basic food and average portions without selling the product -- The food tasted OK, not as spicy as I was hoping -- the service was blah, the atmosphere wasn't anything that I go back to -- came to $25/person 

The one thing that I absolutely loved were the appetizers..sumusa's or something like that -- meat stuffed inside a fried shell -- to die for! If they only served it with a nice sweet sauce on the side that would be worth the visit
author: Marty E.

description:
Before moving to San Francisco, I only had Eritrean/Ethiopian food once in Boston and it wasn't a good experience. The food at that place in Boston, let's call it "Crappy Food Place Restaurant II"  was of poor quality, expensive, and turned me off to trying Eritrean/Ethiopian food again for a while.  Also at Crappy Food Place II, my friend confused his napkin for the injera bread and started gnawing on his napkin instead of the doughy bread as the waiter looked at him in confusion, so nothing went right at Crappy Food Place Restaurant II.   

Then I moved to San Francisco and there are three good Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurants:  Waziema's, Rassela's, and Axum within a half mile area.  Waziema's would become one of my favorite local spots to grab a drink or grab some food.  

Recently, I had a friend highly recommend Assab Eritrean Restaurant.  I went with a few friends last night to check out the food at this place.  The food was very good.  The three of us split the Veggie Combo and Meat Combo.  We all felt the food tasted very fresh and was spiced well.  My friend also told me to mention in my review that her mango juice was a perfect complement to the dishes.  I am looking forward to trying some more dishes next time but the Veggie Combo and Meat Combo worked out perfectly for our group of three and allowed us to taste a little of a bunch of dishes on the menu.
author: Josh K.

description:
This was my first time eating Ethiopian food...yum! We ordered take-out: Zigni was delicious and the Kantisha was awesome! My tastebuds are craving the mushrooms at this moment...

I would love to go again and try other things on the menu. =)
author: Michelle C.

description:
I crashed a birthday party last night and about 8 of us went to Assab on Geary.  Solid stuff though nothing particularly special.  

The service was slow and had some attitude, but it wasn't nearly as spicy as the Sambusas - nose running and sweat beading down my face within seconds.  

All of which would have been fine and fun if our waters hadn't been immediately drained and only refilled when our server ambled by several minutes later.  we had also snotted through all of our napkins and were onto lapels and sleeves.

Which was actually OK with our server, who later actually chastised us for using our then-replenished stock of napkins for wiping our hands in between bites of the hands-on, family style meal.  "Get your hands in there, it's supposed to be dirty"  That's what she said.
author: Matt S.

description:
For those who have had Ethiopian cuisine before, Eritrean is very similar. Typically eaten by hand with all the food put into one large, central dish, the communal style of this cuisine has a very simple, yet appealing art to it. 

The food is outstanding. Spicing is gentle, though poignant and rich, and you will find your palate aroused by many different flavors if you and your dining companions have ordered a variety of dishes. 

5 stars, a "must-go" in San Francisco.
author: Frank B.

description: Rude customer service..20 mins to be seated...I highly doubt I will ever return or reccommend this place
author: Pearl S.

description:
I've not had much experience with Eritrean or Ethiopian foods, but this is by far the best I've had.  I shared a Veggie Combo platter and Meat Combo platter with my wife so we could have a taste of everything.  That was a huge - HUGE - plate of food, all of which was really delicious.  It came on one plate - something to note if you don't want meat touching your veg.  I won't stoop to "meat touching" puns for fear of being kicked off yelp....but I am tempted..... 

The meat options oddly translated to my palate as being similar to Mexican dishes.  Many of the sauces were like very nice moles (a little spicy, a little sweet, and deep with rich flavor), and one was very much like Chile Verde.  Not complaining at all - I loved them all.

The dishes came with a fresh yogurt - so nice and creamy - as well as a trio of sides: red lentils, brown lentils and a cooked greens.  All were fabulous, but I like the red lentils (I'm assuming they were lentils) the best.  

On the veg side (the menu was VERY veg friendly) the tastiest options were the spiced cauliflower / potato option (to make another cultural parallel, think Aloo Ghobi) and the zucchini in a slightly spicy tomato sauce.

It all comes with a neoprene like crepe that you use in lieu of utensils.   Ask for extra napkins!  The crepe is bland, but that's fine, as its just an edible spork.

So good -  I'm glad I was introduced to this place.  Thanks Veena!
author: Aaron M.

description:
I depened on Yelp reviews for this restaurant and I was not disappointed.  The vegi sambusa was delicious.  We ordered the meat combo and chick pea entree, both were delicious.  The bread, dough had a great tangy taste.  

The service was a bit slow when it came to delivering the food, don't they just have everything stewing in the back?  But the waitperson was nice.

One thing I wouldn't order again was the honey wine.  Very sweet, more of an after dinner drink then a regular wine with dinner.
author: Christine L.

description:
This having been my third excellent meal at Assab, I felt compelled to finally write a review.  

My lovely friend being a vegetarian, we opted for a number of the dishes off of the vegetarian side of the menu, in particular, the mixed vegetable platter (#18) and the Shiro (#11).

Although I'm not sure which meal consisted of what, as we ordered our meal family style, what promptly arrived was a delicious combination of potato, lentils, squash, garbanzo beans, yogurt, spinach and more, all served on a veritable plateau of injera.

Although the family style platter and lack of utensils may make for an awkward dating meal, it's in all a fun experience, aided no doubt by the deliciousness of the food and quality of the service.  Additionally, the fact that the entire establishment is a family-run affair with the father as the maitre-de, the daughter as the waitress and the mother as the cook, creates a very pleasant, warm atmosphere.

Washed down with either a refreshing ginger beer or the local honey-wine, this was ultimately a delicious, well-seasoned, beautifully prepared meal for any occasion.

I will certainly be back.  

Apparently the bathroom, although nothing spectacular, was quite clean and well maintained - important attributes at a restaurant where the lack of utensils necessitates all but the most skillful of diners to wash their hands afterwards.
author: Reed L.

description:
Excellent food with great vegetarian options.

I particularly liked the lentil soup.  I also enjoyed the honey wine even though I typically do not like sweet wines.  

The service was friendly - only a little slow since they were busy.
author: Sia K.

description: Been here twice and will definitely return periodically. Fills you up with delicious flavors and combinations. Even has a few unique beverage options(although my boyfriend says to mention the house wine wasn't great). Fairly nice atmosphere, can talk, and good service.
author: Alexandra T.

description:
I'm kicking myself (ouch!) for not (argh!) discovering Assab before now.  Of the 5 or so Ethiopian/Eritrean places I've dined at in my life, this is hands down the best!

I recommend starting with both the meat and veggie sambusa.  They are so fresh, and the crust is so deliciously crispy, I could've ordered 10 more and just made a meal out of these.  

Here's a tip - go with the server's recommendation.  The prices are low enough, that you can afford to experiment.  3 of us ordered the meat sampler, the veggie sampler, and the mushrooms (heavenly), and we had a little more than enough food.  Flavoring was out of this world on every single dish item, although I was particularly fond of the eggplant, the red lentils, and the beef.  

Also, the injera is delightfully sour and spongy, and even better once it's soaked up all the juices and flavoring from the servings.

Sure, we waited a little while for our food given the small staff, but it was well worth the wait and we didn't feel rushed.  If you're in a hurry - pass this place up.  But, if you want a warm, casual atmosphere  with a great multicultural crowd, try it out!
author: Barry G.

description:
Good, tasty and reasonably priced.  Now, I'm not an Ethiopian/Eritrean food conniseur, in fact it had been about three years since I last had it.  But this place really hit the spot.  I'm salivating just thinking about it.

The food was flavorful.  The waitress we had was incredibly nice.  It was a great overall experience and I can't wait to go back.

Just so you know, I had the meat combo and my fiancee had the veggie combo.  We shared it "family style" and it was a bit too much food for us.  We figured next time we would get one of the combos and then an additional dish.  The food was so good though, so we overstuffed ourselves.
author: Ben C.

description:
The good
- Spicy Beef (KITFO + Meat Combo)
- Tasty Lamb (Meat Combo)
- Flavorful chicken (Meat Combo)
- Curry Potatoes (Meat Combo's #8)
- Honey Wine
- Friendly Wait-staff

The bad
1.25 hours from when we sat down until we received our appetizers. It was a busy night with only two waiters/waitresses, but people who sat down 30 mins after we did, received their main course before we received our appetizers.
author: Henry D.

description:
This was my first experience with Eritrean food, and I had to say it was quite delicious. Spicy, but not uncomfortably so. I went ahead and gave it four stars for the food, but beware, the service is terribly slow. On a Saturday night there was one server and a manager for the entire restaurant. There's no waiting space at all so everyone just kind of hovers in the middle of the restaurant waiting for a table. Then it took about 20 minutes for anyone to come get our drink and food order. I have to say, they were friendly and apologetic, but one server for an entire restaurant, even a small one, is pretty absurd.

That being said, I totally recommend this restaurant. Just get a reservation, and be prepared to wait. 

Also, a word to the wise on the honey wine. It's incredibly sweet, so if you're not ok with that, avoid. The Ethiopian beers are pretty tasty as an alternative.
author: Lindsey H.

description:
First the food: no surprises Ethiopian fare. Well executed. Fairly priced. Good. The injera is good (if a bit bland), the meats are flavorful and the veggies are rich.

But the service. Normally, service is a non-factor for me: I don't care if the waiters spit on me as long as they're not spitting in the food. But where was my damn food! I made the mistake of coming in hungry; an hour later the food arrived; it got a bit unpleasant in the interim.

So: good food, but the wrong place to go if you're hungry at the moment.
author: Adam L.

description: The most delicious Ethiopian food i have ever had. They had abundant vegetarian options, which i have never seen in any other cuisine other than Indian. The food was lip smacking and the service was delightful. I would certainly visit again.
author: Shubhi T.

description: This is a tough one.  I love the food here, it's reasonably priced, and the atmosphere is causal.  On the downside: the service is lacking and the last time I ate here, one of the dishes had been microwaved - there was the telltale icy bite followed by the hot bite.    I'm sure I'll be back, hopefully the return visit will enable me to figure out how I feel.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
I'm not really sure how Eritrean cuisine differs from Ethiopian, but I've never been disappointed here.  I love how unassuming the restaurant is -  I love being able to fondle my food, and the portions are huge.  The veg combos are a good bet for lots of variety, and if you ask nicely, they'll make substitutions. 

This place serves the yummiest Eritrean Honey beer in the world.  I copied the distributor's name off of the bottle and tried to track some down for home consumption, but had no luck.  :(
author: Heather S.

description: Great food or both vegetarians and carnivores- delicious, nicely spiced, good sized portions for moderate price; pleasant and friendly service in a clean space. Some of the best Ethiopian food we have had!
author: Alan G.

description:
Very very good food. Quite spicy FYi, but very very good. I have been here a few times now and keep coming back.

Bill for 2 meals and 2 beers came to just under $25.
author: N S.

description:
Amazingly tasty food.  The Chicken Kelwa Mix is amazing and Africa hot.  The Vegetarian combo is also worth a whirl if your taste buds are more on the sensative side.

Extremely friendly service!  Eat here!
author: Matt O.

description:
We've passed Assab 100 times on Geary but never knew what a hidden gem this place was until the other night.  Ethiopian food is something that we have very rarely so I checked Yelp before picking a restaurant and Assab had 4.5 stars so we decided to try it.

You'd never guess from the funky interior that the food would be so great!  The owner served us and had such a sweet energy that it made the experience even better.  Parking was a breeze on Geary and the eastbound 38 bus stops directly in front of the door...extremely convenient!

I have to say that Assab has THE BEST lentil soup I have ever tasted.  It was perfectly flavored, not too much salt and the lentils were so soft and comforting.  We also tried the meat sambusa which was fantastic, flaky and spiced very well.

We ordered the meat and veggie combinations, plus the Shiro based on a Yelper's review.  The Shiro was just ok but the rest was extremely tasty without being overly spicy.  Of the meat dishes, the beef wasn't anything to write home about but the chicken was soft and tasty and the lamb was fantastic. The veggie dishes were a complete surprise.  Vegetables are really hard to make flavorful and cook just right but Assab succeeded on all counts.  Both the zucchini and okra dishes, things that could be disastrous in the wrong hands, were so tasty and were cooked perfectly.

As usual with Ethiopian/Eritrean food, we ate way too much so we had to skip dessert.  There were only two on the menu anyway.  The whole meal, including 2 apps, 3 main dishes, 2 beers and a (real!) ginger beer came to $48.  We will definitely be back to Assab and would bring friends here!!
author: Jon B.

description:
As soon as I took a step into Assab, I knew it was going to be good. The fantastic smells wafting out of the kitchen instantly smack you (for lack of a better term) directly in the face as soon as you enter. This isn't the most lavish looking restaurant, but what is there is enough to please the visual senses. Although I couldn't check out the kitchen, the dining space looked pretty clean.

 Instantly greeting us with a smile and some menus, the waiter seemed friendly enough. The menu featured enough quality selection for a difficult choice, which is much better than the alternative. We ended up getting the Meat Sambusa to start out, which although was pretty small, the size was to be expected for $2. The flavor on the other hand, was anything but small. If you've ever had any other kind of "Samosa" before, this is pretty much in the same family, but the extremely flavorful Meat in the Sambusa made it stand out of the bunch.

 Unable to pick out just a single meal, we went with the Meat and Vegetarian combo entrees. For the meat - Zigni, Tsebh-Derho, Alicha-Beggee. For the Vegetarian dishes - Veg. Alicha, Okra, Zucchini. I also decided to try out the honey wine after so many people raved about it. It didn't really "float my boat" sort of speak. The flavor was almost too sweet/tart for me, and after just a few sips, I was done. Overall, food had some really powerful/interesting spices. Eating with hands was also a plus. Even though all of the dishes were great, they all tasted pretty similar, and it was ultimately hard to distinguish what I was eating since everything was served together on a colossal sized plate. 

 This was the first time I've had Eritrean food before, but since then I have had it someplace else, and this place is easily better. I highly recommended Assab, and would come back in a heartbeat.
author: Russell S.

description: This is by far the yummiest Eritrean restaurant around these parts.  The service is amazing as well.  Stop your search, you've found it!
author: Terika T.

description:
The vegetable combination and meat combination dishes were very good.  A lot of food and well cooked.  The cauliflower, lamb and okra were my favorite dishes.  

We also ordered the kantisha (the mushrooms) which were spicy and delicious.  

The injera was just the right thickness and sponginess.  

And service was good.  Pretty quick and attentive.

We will be back.
author: Nivita S.

description: Went there last night and food tasted great, loved the stout beer, place looked nice and clean, staff was very friendly but... my girlfriend and I are now having the worst food poisoning ever.
author: Fred D.

description: Amazing, authentic Eritrean food! Staff is a husband and wife team and they are so dedicated and nice. We have been going to Assab for 8 years and absolutely consider it our go to place for a home cooked meal type.  Delicious!
author: CA R.

description:
Simply a wonderful place. The food was amazing - full of flavor but not overpowering, and a proper mix of spicy, sweet, and savory. The service was also great - the place was busy but the service was still attentive enough to keep me happy, and our waiter was friendly helpful and very accommodating of our group (which was somewhat loud and grew twice while we were there).

Go, and eat. Bring lots of people so you can try many things (everything?) - you'll like it.
author: Daniel G.

description: Oh, man, Assab rocks my socks! I am obsessed with the Kelwa Mix. It is perfectly seasoned chicken and veggie spicy heaven. I can barely stand it, it's so good. I love the connection to the food one gets from eating with their hands. Eating at Assab is like a religious experience for me, I get so lost and carried away in the flavors. It is a culinary expedition. The service is friendly, but slightly on the slow side. I once had to get up and ask for a glass of water because I had been waiting for a very very long time. But I go back again and again regardless because the food is more than worth it. Love it.
author: Maya B.

description:
I always tell people that if I was going to die tomorrow, my last meal would be the #6 dish at Assab, with extra injera bread.

And I mean it. 

This place is, by all means, heaven on earth. The portions are huge but manageable, the food is consistently incredible, and I always leave feeling amazing. 

It's definitely a family run restaurant (really only one cook, and one to two waiters at most), and a relatively small place to boot, so the only  downside to this place is the occasional long wait for a table on Friday/Saturday nights. However, no matter how long I wait it is always worth it. 

If you have not been yet, GO. It will blow your mind. Hands down my favorite restaurant in the city.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I can pretend to wax on the nuances of Eritrean food, but I don't have a clue. All I know is that it is amazing. LIke an African warlord staged a massive coup de tat over the instable government that is my mouth.

I surrender, general, you've totally won me over.
author: Jon S.

description:
Liked the honey wine (always do!), and the lentils and spicy mushrooms made for a yummy combo. The Ethiopian beer was good too. 

And eating with our hands? Paradise! Friendly service and easy parking made this a place to which I'll return.
author: Allison L.

description:
Eating here never fails to make me happy. The staff is friendly and funny, making the meal a joy. The food is exquisite (can't live without the Alicha Begge (lamb) and the Shiro (chickpeas) and Bersin (red lentils) are good accompaniments). We had the Kelwa Mix (chicken) for the first time this past weekend for my boyfriend's birthday dinner and it was really good. Nice and spicy. Everything's tasty, really. Just be adventurous! It's also fun to eat with the challenge of using as much of the injera (flatbread) on the plate as you can and doing your best not to use the extra piece they give us poor Americans. I've done pretty well several times! I'm a fan of the honey wine as well, but that may be too sweet for many. The food's not hot enough to require a sweet drink, but I like the compliment all the same. Meta beer is a popular choice for my friends.

Go try this one. It's SO good!
author: Shawna S.

description:
YES YES YES, ASSAB!

Ok. I'm a bit biased, because this was my first Eritrean restaurant, and I've been coming here for years, and have SUCH great memories in this place. But, onto the review:

Completely yummy and delicious. Wonderful spices, bold and bright and never overly spicy. You can always taste the ingredients. Huge portions. Every dish is served with little sides of three kinds of vegetables. The injera is some of the best I've had. It's spongy, and moist, and slightly sour in the best of ways. I LOVE THIS PLACE. When I'm craving good, down home, meat and potatoes, surprisingly, I don't go for meatloaf. I think this is better. Odd, for an american girl, I know. But I get hardcore cravings for Eritrean food. And when I do, this is where I go!

Now, service isn't what I would call 5 star.  But I love their service all the same! Especially if you get the restaurant owner. He is this totally sweet, smiley little Eritrean man who exudes his own personal bubble of joy! I think he's adorable! 

And, I think they've moved them to the side or something, but they have a couple of this little tables that are actually woven, like baskets, and they placed a pane of glass ontop, and under it you can see all the different kinds of seeds and spices and beans that go into the food. It's really cool. 

It's definately  a family run operation - and I love it!
author: Mindy L.

description:
I love this place. I had a good friend from Eritrea who cooked for the entire apartment complex. Since she moved to D.C. I couldn't find any good Eritrean food until I found Assab!!! 

Order the Zigni (its spicy but so so good)!!!
author: Warren D.

description:
"WE BE GRUBBIN!" - Ice-Hungry

I haven't had African food since ages ago in a long lost galaxy on Telegraph in Berkeley.  It was fun and great eating with my hands back then and it's even funner now that I'm older and can regress.  Reasons I thought this place was awesome:

1) Food was GRUBBIN': We had the lentil soup which was DA BOMB, the Kelwa Mix (chicken w/ sauteed vegetables) which was DA BOMB, and the recommended Alicha Beggee (cubes of lamb mixed w/ a variety of vegetables and seasoned nicely) which was DA THIRD BOMB, all on top of this funky, spongy bread called Injera which, similar to toilet paper, upon appearance and touch looks flimsy and soft but is surprisingly strong and great for picking up food w/ your hands.  Terrible analogy for something that was so good but it's the first thing that came to my mind. 

2) Service was sweet.  The man serving us (who I assume to be the owner) was very nice, accommodating, and friendly.  Personified service with a smile.  

3) Eating with your hands and not having your girlfriend yell at you for being so barbaric.  You would never think African but I thought this would be a great place to get together with the boys, have some beers, and eat like cavemen.  

DSK favs: See 1) above
author: Dik Shun K.

description: Wanted to try something different. This restaurant hit the spot. We got there after 6 p.m., were greeted warmly, and seated immediately. We ordered the meat combo and vegetable combo, which was served family style on a huge platter on an equally huge piece of injera. It also came with two additional pieces of warm injera. The meats ... chicken, beef and lamb ... we're tender and perfectly seasoned. The vegetables were flavorful, even the okra, which I surprisingly enjoyed. And all of it was eaten without silverware! We used our hands to tear the injera and use it to pick up the meats and vegetables. Loved the experience! Eritreans are known for their honey wine, which I wasn't familiar with. Our server brought me a complimentary sample to try. It was aromatic and sweet. I liked it and ordered a glass to go with our meal. Our server, a woman from Ethiopia, was excellent and attentive. We enjoyed talking with her. We will definitely return on our next trip.
author: Mary C.

description:
Never had this kind of food before but it's really tasty. Wo!
Eat with your hands and get nasty!
Hot!
author: S D.

description: Good Eritrean food.
author: Patrick S.

description:
wow...  opening the door and walking in to the restaurant immediately had my taste buds doing a little happy dance.  the smell was intoxicating and a small hint of the upcoming awesome-fest about to happen.
