the staff was very friendly and eager to assist.  the food was INCREDIBLE!  i'm trying to think of something negative to say to balance out this review, but i'm drawing a complete blank.  there isn't anything bad to say about the experience.  i'll definitely be back soon!
author: Anjanette M.

description:
I feel like I only write Yelp reviews when I'm seriously fuming about something, so I'm happy to write a good one for once.

We came here on a weeknight for a double date and, not knowing what to expect, were pleasantly surprised.  My mouth started watering pretty much from the moment we walked in and saw the heaping platters of food on other peoples' tables.  We got an assortment of meat and vegetarian dishes, and though I wasn't always sure what I was eating, it was pretty much ALL delicious.  The servers were also very sweet and did their jobs well.  

The only thing I wasn't too crazy about was the sweet honey wine, which I will either skip next time or save for dessert.  :)  It also wasn't super cheap, but still reasonable.  I brought hand sanitizer with me, fyi, since I knew I'd be eating with my hands.

I would definitely be happy to come back here.
author: Corinna C.

description: Remember how your mom always told you not to eat with your hands? Well, you can now tell her that she's ethnocentric. Come here and eat. It's in a very accessible area of SF (by Japan-town) on Geary (st or ave I can't remember but it's a giant road). If you're not sure where to start try the meat sampler or veggie sampler. It's similar to Indian food but with an earthier quality. Enjoy Eritrean food!
author: Al C.

description:
We just ate there tonight, and the food was fantastic!!

We had the meat combination platter and zucchini, along with a glass of honey wine.  

You do eat with your hands scooping up the food with your hands using the bread, and share it family style in one big plate in the middle of the table.  It was unusual and refreshing and reminded me a little of Indian food.  Of the food we ordered, the chicken and the lamb from the meat combo were standouts, packed with flavor.  The spongey flatbread/pancake that you eat it with was also fantastic, as was the yoghurt.  The yoghurt sauce was so tasty (a cross between goat cheese and sour cream) that we ordered an additional bowl and finished that clean.  

I would definitely recommend the experience to anyone in the mood for something new and tasty.
author: Monica W.

description: This was the first Eritrean restaurant that I've ever tried, and I've been to a couple of other joints as well as Ethiopian places and this is the place that comes to mind first whenever I think of really, really good food. I ordered the zigni, which is basically beef cubes in a dark red sauce that, when combined with bersin (lentil), injera [the thin, soft tangy crepe-type bread served with everything] and the delicious homemade yogurt, made for an amazing flavor sensation. the best part was scooping up the injera and eating it with veggies after finishing the meat because all the sauces had soaked into it at the end. I'm making myself crazy at work writing this review because I haven't had breakfast yet, I'm hungry as fuck, and I'm going here Saturday night and already counting down the hours!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Aivy C.

description: Love the Ethiopian food at this place.
author: Jim J.

description:
I didn't know what to expect coming here for dinner last night. I had never had Ethioptian/Eritrean food before.

The wait was unbearable but when with good company, I managed to get through it. We probably waited well over an hour and a half....standing in line, waiting for a table (had reservations) and sitting at our table waiting for food.

The food was pretty good...it was a little awkward sharing food with each other on a big platter...using our hands to eat. It was definitely an experience. The atmosphere was light and fun. The prices were moderate.

I may or may not come back....the only thing I didn't like was the long wait.
author: V M.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Simply Delicious. I always start with the lentil soup and then the Meat Combination....*drool* : )
Hold on one second...Im salivating......ok..... 
So anyway, I love spicy foods so this hits the spot...but if you're not a fan, then just make sure you get extra yogurt. It helps a lot!
Prices are reasonable, Service is good. Its a small, nice, relaxed place with phenomenal food. 
Definitely get your meal Family style and dont even think about using utensils! Trust me, you'll enjoy licking your fingers afterwards.
author: Judith F.

description:
If the staff were nicer I'd give this place 4 stars but our first experience wasn't good in that respect. After being seated and then totally ignored for 15 minutes we had to go get the waitress to take our drink order.  The place is relatively small and apparently they are very snarky with their rules when it comes to seating. Our intended party of 6 turned out to be a party of 4 after we were seated and the waitress seemed pretty pissed that the other 2 people couldn't make it after all. She told us if they didn't show up by the time our food arrived we'd be moving to a smaller table. As in picking up our drinks, dishes, silverware, etc. and relocating. What? Seriously? Give me a break. Maybe it was her tone of voice that irritated me the most. And the fact that the waiter seemed to avoid ever coming near our table as payback for our 2 missing friends. 

The food, however is pretty good. I kept trying to find my usual chicken dishes on the menu until I remembered I wasn't at an Ethiopian place. I found a good substitute that I enjoyed a lot. The lentils were good and not too buttery. We brought a couple that had never had Eritrean/Ethiopian before and while they were skeptical at first, they cleaned their plates. The guys had Ethiopian beer, which I tasted and found to be pretty decent although sweet. They changed options for round 2.

Overall, I'd eat here again, if everyone in my party were present and someone had already made plans for it. I am more fond of Waziema, which is close enough to justify going there instead. Much friendlier staff and their food is fantastic.
author: Kara M.

description:
I really really missed Ethiopian food. While at Cal, I visited Blue Nile as often as I could on a student budget (which wasn't often, but on occasion). 

So it had been about 5 years since I had partaken in the delights of Ethiopian food. It's sort of like Indian food, but definitely is identifiable as its own entity. It's also great food for vegetarians - the vegetables are actually my favorite part. Though the spicy beef I had at Assab was delicious. My boyfriend had the veggie sampler, which was great too - I stole plenty of it. We went family style, all the way! :D We also had Ethiopian stout, which wasn't that impressive. Maybe we should have gone for the lager.

It seems like Assab is family run, which is nice, but be sure to be patient with the service speed. Also, I was impressed that people who looked like they could be Ethopian/Eritrean came into the place - I never saw people like that at the Blue Nile. Always college students and white people.

So, if you're prepared to eat with your hands, stop in and give it a try - it's a good experience. Don't blame me when you get cravings, though! Ethiopian food is definitely one of those you really have to seek out - you can't find the restaurants just anywhere!
author: Emily M.

description:
With the nice sweet honey wine on one hand and an ever smiling friendly waiter, being the first time in an Eritrean locale, we went for the safe bet, putting together the vegetable combination and the meat combination all on one giant platter of yummy...sponge? 
Not used to eat with our hands, we dove into this rainbow of flavors and colors, sweet, sour, different types of delicious curry.....
I will definitely come back and have me some food fun again!!!
author: Paolo D.

description:
I went to this place a an year ago when my friends invited us to join them for dinner .
I became a big fan of this place after just  tasting the first dish i ordered.
"SAMBUSA" wow ! that was really well seasoned .
Then came the lentil soup ..  It had a subtle taste ( i loved it )
Followed by the combo..(which was also good)
I go to this place whenever i am in SF.
I highly recommend making a reservation on weekends.
author: deepthi d.

description:
I walked in today at 2PM with only one other Eritrean experience, and found this place to leave me wanting more! Assab is great for that "a little of this, a little of that" friend that you have...and even better amongst friends who just happen to  prefer to eat everything with their little hands. So that's not for the weak of stomach who can't handle digging in the injera for a little more mushroom.

I loved the decor, it's pretty simple, but the back tables for two that have the cool table settings (the woven thingys) are pretty neat. I find that the friendly staff made our experience all the more meaningful, in other words, they're not intrusive, friendly and able to allow a conversation carry on without interruption.


 Vegetarian combo and meat combo are a good way to get started if you're having a hard time deciding!
author: Charlene L.

description:
This is hands down my favorite restaurant, ever.

Now...after that fantastic opener...let me explain why I love it.

The food is amazing and very different from anything else that I've had before.  Since discovering Assab, I have tried two other Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants (one on Haight, and one in Oakland) and neither lived up to Assab.  I made a habit of introducing my friends to Assab and even the skeptical ones walked away loving it (even though they initially complained about the whole eating with your hands/sharing your germs thing).

The service is great (I think the owner started to recognize me after a bit, lol), although it can be hard to be seated when it's busy since it is kind of small.  However, that can't tarnish the fact that this is still one of my favorite places to go in S.F.  If you're trying it for the first time, I recommend ordering the meat and vegetable samplers because that will give you the chance to try a little bit of everything off the menu and figure out what your favorites are.  The only thing they serve that I don't recommend is the Ethiopian honey wine (unless you enjoy dessert wines).  It's suuuper sweet...
author: Stefanie B.

description:
This place is good and service is fast, but out of all the Ethiopian options in the bay area, it comes up a bit short. Yeah, you get unique items like okra here, but where's my limitless basket of injera? C'mon. I want my bread.

Don't get me wrong. This place is good. But if you're seekin' Ethiopian perfection, make the trek to Cafe Colucci in Oakland.
author: Jeremy W.

description: We have been to this place many times over the past 5 years. The Vegetarian combo is delicious especially the spinach and the potatoes. The service is always good and it is a great atmosphere. We love this place!
author: Anna Y.

description:
They serve fresh and tasty Eritrean food and the restaurant is run by a nice family (mom, pop & daughter).  I usually get the meat or vege combo and everything is great on it.  The "spongy bread" is surprisingly tasty and they will give you extras or you can eat the one underneath the entree as you go. 

Be prepared to eat with your hands - that's the only way to go.   Their honey wine is also very tasty - get the bottle for the best deal, esp. if you have 3-4 people.
author: Bessie T.

description:
Love love love this place!!!!!!! I go here whenever I get the chance to with my BF, the last time we went was on his birthday with some friends. The owners are sweet and the food is great. I think I've tried everything on the menu except dessert (usually too full for dessert). 

The lentil soup is so good with a sambusa and the kitfo is amazing!!!

I love this place so much that I think I'll go there tonight. The decor isn't overly elaborate but it is very cozy. I always leave with a warm belly and a happy feeling when I eat there.
author: Vicky C.

description:
Very nice!  I like!
Simple atmosphere,  good food/portions, friendly staff, clean establishment.  I had no problem with eating with my hands as I am a slob.  My friend asked for a fork, but the owner said they didn't have any.  The dissappointed look on his face!  HAH!.  He later came back with a fork.  Damn.  This place is hard to miss unless you drive straight into the Geary tunnel.  Then you have missed it for sure.  The fact that everyones food is served on the same big plate removes all the guilt you may have when you steal some of your friends order.....Oh yea, they also have a selection of African brews to choose from....I forgot what we had, but it was pretty good:)
author: andrew l.

description:
3.5 for tasty food! We opted for the meat combo and another lamb plate. One of the red meats (the lamb that came in the combo, I think) was a bit drier and chewier than preferred, but otherwise, the portions were plentiful.
+1 for friendly service
- .25 for freezing dining room (we went in December). I thought it was just certain Chinese restaurants that didn't believe in turning on the heat in the winter (Put on another sweater!).
- .25 for not getting a hot wet towel or wetnaps to wash our hands with before the digging in began. (I know, it's not Singapore Airlines, but I've been to another low-key restaurant that do this. You'd think they'd afford the cost as insurance against some moron suing them for getting sick when they really ate crap off their own hands).
author: Liz K.

description:
Came here with family and friends the other night, and we enjoyed a lovely meal. We split the vegetarian combo (with a couple other things thrown in) and had honey wine, Hakim beer and iced tea.
Super delicious.
Only downside, not enough injera comes with it, so you have to order more.
But that's not too bad!
Friendly, courteous service, too.
And very MUNI accessible: There's a 38 bus stop right in front of it.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The waiter said to me as I tried to use the fork: " The meat falls off the bone so use your hands" and he was right!

Most tender chicken ever. 

Eritrean beer is pretty damn good too.
author: Roland L.

description:
First, I should qualify my review by saying that I only tried the veggie combo, and that I have no standard to measure Eriterean cuisine by. Perhaps I went in expecting Ethiopian food, and I'm sure there's plenty of regional variation and it's not all a monolith (it's like folks who expect all Indian food to be like butter chicken). Having said that, I just found everything extremely bland. Again, I'm so used to the heavenly aromas of "niter kebbeh" and its gorgeous amalgam of cardamon, cinnamon, garlic, nutmeg etc. You get none of that here, and I felt that everything was really under seasoned -- once again, this could be because of my great (and problematic) expectations. The much recommended okra just sat there in a basic tomato sauce, and was not that different from the zucchini, which swam in a very similar (bland) tomato gravy. The one good thing was the beautifully creamy yoghurt which you could immediately tell was house made and not from a carton.
Very good service, though, and I hate giving it the thumbs down, but I just was underwhelmed.
author: Crushed Wi Cardamom C.

description: I have been to this place twice and both the times their food was great. I liked the food in Zeni's but hated their wait times. I was fortunate to get seated quickly both the times in Assab and the food was the as good as Zenis or even better. There are plenty of options for vegetarians and the waitress was very patient and helpful.
author: Bharathwaj S.

description:
the food here is super tasty, delicious, and filling. if you've never had it, i'd say it's similar to indian food as far as taste is concerned.  if you love spicy, i think you'll be very pleased here.

i like the family style vibe, and eating with your hands.  it was my first time here, so my friends ordered for me and we all shared, so unfortunately i can't name anything in particular.  all i will say is that everything i was brave enough to try, i liked.  a lot.
author: asia c.

description:
I never had Eritrean food, nor did I know what to expect, but this place was indeed delightful. We had a group of about 8 people, and even though the restaurant was a little hesitant in putting some tables together, they did, and we were glad. The plates are definitely big enough to share (we ended up ordering several items family style instead of each person ordering for him/herself). The flavors of the food were very distinct. Ok, I really mean the chicken, since I don't eat red meat, but it was still good. And the injera.. mmm. I know it's like a bread and it expands but I'll be honest.. it kept me going and I didn't seem to get full from it.

To top it off, the restaurant staff was kind enough to give us extra plates for our cake (which we brought ourselves) to celebrate a friend's birthday. Four stars because it was fabulous, but not five because I have nothing to which I can compare.
author: Yosie G.

description:
For someone who considers Eritrean food as a separate food group-- and her favorite, in fact, it means something to say that this is my favorite (in San Francisco).  I've tried the one on 10th and Irving, Massawa on Haight, the one on Lower Haight...basically, you find an Eritrean/Ethiopian place, and I will likely have tried it.  

Don't need the menu anymore-- our usual is #12, 14, and 17.  The service is fantasic and they love when you clean up the entire giant plate (I always do). Really good food, really good prices, and awesome people! The injera is perfect and the okra is fantastic.   I'm salavating just thinking about the injera.....mmmm...

Note:  A friend I reccommended this place to *also* said this was the best meal in San Francisco she's ever had!  That makes two!!
author: Helen T.

description:
The owner of this place used to own Massawa on Haight Street years ago. He and his wife are pros in this business. She oversees the kitchen (used to do most of the cooking) while he oversees the dining room.

They have the best Kitfo this side of the Bay (chopped raw beef spiced with extravagant chilis) and their veggie dishes are very good.

The only problem is that they are stingy with the injera (the spongy bread used as silverware). Typically (and I've eaten in most of the Bay Area's Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurants) you are given a fair amount of this bread included with the meal. At Assab, they bring you a few pieces and then you have to flag the waiter down a few minutes later for more, and then they charge you for it. This is very petty almost like charging for an extra napkin.

Besides that a great spot. The only reason I don't consider it a good spot for kids is that my kid doesn't like the food.
author: Hank S.

description:
Started with the veggie sambusa. Tasty, but a little overfried. Got the veggie sampler and meat sampler. Meat sampler was way better. I only liked one out of the three veggies (the potato/cabbage, not the okra or zucchini) Injera was perfect spongy sour goodness. I love eating with my hands. There was one waiter working the entire room and he was good. 

So, I left off one star because 1) veggies were so-so and 2) I've been to other places where we sat on these low wicker stools and we could eat family style off these wicker-like tables. It was a fun old-school way of eating.  I saw a set of table/chairs in the place and I asked if we could sit there. The waiter looked at me like I was nutso and said it would be better if we sat at a normal table.  Oh well. I guess I'm too cheesy like that.
author: Nima K.

description:
Eritrean food???

yes... eritrea... a country in east Africa...

im always good for some adventure and this definitely was...
we ordered our food knowing it was served family style...

The closest thing I can relate this to is Indian food ... but its still far off

So we ordered a wide mix: Chicken, Beef, Lamb, Mushrooms, and a Veggie Sampler....
each served on top of Injera (a sponge-like tortilla) with Lentils, Yogurt, spinach... on the side...

So when the food came out... I saw the biggest dish I had ever seen... it must have been 3 feet in diameter.... with all of our dishes laid out... WTF? this is huge!!!  

How the heck am I supposed to eat this giant thing?

We literally dug in with our hands... the traditional Eritrean style is to take your injera, tear a piece of it, then piece up some of the food with it....
and wow... its delicious... very unique taste... flavorful, "sour", and hearty all at the same time...

If you are looking for a dining adventure... come here... you will not be disappointed...by the food...

the service could be quicker... but im a yelper... i have standards...
enough said...
author: Florio M.

description:
My husband and I tried Assab for the first time last night (Friday) and we had to wait for about 10 minutes for a table around 7:30 PM, and it was well worth it.  

The place is privately run by a family who are absolutely friendly and nice.  The decor is nothing fancy, but definitely a casual place to have fun on a date or with other couples/friends.  The food is excellent and really inexpensive!  Our meal came to $30!

Also, I thought this place was strictly vegetarian, but was happy to find beef, chicken and lamb!!  :)  We did the #9 (meat) and #18 (veggie) sample specials - and that was a perfect combination to try a bit of everything.  The lamb wasn't my favorite, but the beef and chicken were amazing.  Not sure how they prepared it, but it was well marinated/seasoned and spicy.  Definitely better than what I was expecting.

OH and be prepared to eat with your hands!  And also be sure to go with someone you are comfortable eating like this with!  

We'll definitely be going back and recommending it to friends.
author: Gina K.

description:
This place is great for groups. If you want, you can get a family platter with whatever dishes you want and they will serve it in a bigger than big platter for everyone to share. 

If you haven't had Eritrean or Ethiopian food, you basically get the Injera, made out of teff, wheat or sorghum, and resembles a spongy, slightly sour pancake and that is your utensil. Get some Injera and scoop up whatever you want with it.

Make sure you wash your hands before you dig in.

It's fun and different. Don't bother getting the beer. Hubby tried the "stout" and the "lager". Both were...hmmmm...bland. The honey wine was pretty good. It's honey wine! Can't really go wrong with that. No, it's not that sweet. Well, it's sweet, but not that bad.

The place was packed by 7 p.m. on a Saturday. We're glad we got there a little before that to get a table quickly. We had a good time and enjoyed our food.

One thing though, I kept eating and eating because I'm a pig long after everyone else stopped. I think my full trigger is off. Then after we got home I kept getting fuller and fuller. I think that Injera was expanding in my belly as the night went on. Here's my advice, don't stuff yourself and pace otherwise you'll get bloated with Injera. Enjoy!
author: Wendy B.

description: IF YOU ARE EVER IN SF YOU NEED TO EAT AT ASSAB.  This place serves food family style, so bring lots of friends/family.  This way you get to try a larger variety of Ethiopian food.  I came here with about 7 friends and no one was dissatisfied with the food.  One of the friends I went with hates spicy food, and to his surprised also loved Assab.  Also, try the honey wine...it's a really tasty treat :-).
author: A K.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city.  The food is fantastic and huge portions.  Definetly try the honey wine & african beer as well.

I really dig the family run vibe of the place too, they people working there work their tails off and deserve all the great reviews they get.  Peeking into the kitchen, it was spotless also :)
author: Don J.

description:
Delicious.  Despite it being technically an eritrean restaurant, this is really the only place in town you should go to for your Ethiopian food cravings.  Don't waste time elsewhere.  

The food is spicy, fresh and succulent.  I adore the dorowat and have always had a weakness for the boiled egg in the bowl that soaks in all of the delicious berebere spice.  

The service is friendly and very attentive, and the prices are reasonable.  You'll walk away feeling VERY full and very satisfied with your meal.  Parking's pretty easy in the area; there is the BofA lot on the roof that has plentiful spots. 

The only gripe I have is that sometimes it's hard to tell when they're open, since I always want to go there!
author: Eji Y.

description: Great place. Friendly, good food, cozy, authentic. Awesome place.
author: Christian S.

description: Love the restaurant. The best Ethiopian restaurant in SF. Great costumer service & authetic & delicious food. I am hooked!
author: Cindy C.

description:
Tasty tasty tasty! Is that where Eritrea is? (OK I knew, but the menu will show you if you didn't). 

This place was packed when we got there at 830, so its either really popular, or people just really love Eritrean food. I hate that smell you get in your hands after eating with your hands, but hell, I'll deal with it if it means I get to indulge in some of this stuff.

No frills, just good food. Eating with your hands is part of the fun. The honey wine is also very good, and for the price, the dinner/drinks was a great deal. I'll be here again in no time.
author: Rocky K.

description:
Excellent food! On my all time favorites only compared with one other place in the states and another in East Africa itself.

Excellent preparation of food and amazing homemade cheese. A must for any foodie and every other person besides that as well. I implore you to go.
author: John S.

description:
Do make reservations if you are going on a busy night (Friday, Sat)! The bf and I went Friday night and it was packed. Since the restaurant is modest sized and everyone leisurely enjoys their food, wine and conversation, the turnover rate for tables was pretty low. 

Venue: It was really clean! Assab even passed the restroom test! I mean, it wasn't a fancy lounge space with flattering lighting or anything but it was neat and clean. My only gripe was I couldn't lock the door (anyone else have this problem?) which added an extra edge of excitement and urgency when using the facilities. 

Food: Yummy yummy yummy! We got the veggie and meat sambusa - the veggie was much more flavorful and yummy. It was amazingly crispy and NOT overly greasy. The bf got the meat sampler and I got the mushroom for our main course. We both thought the chicken was the most savory literally falling off the bones delicious. The mushroom was super delicious and really yummy companion to the chicken. All the sides were good. The only item that caused us any consternation was the bread you're supposed to eat anything with. There was nothing offensive about the flavor (it's just a means to get the other food into your mouth after all), but the texture was really weird! It's spongy! 

On imbibing: The bf liked this Ethiopian beer. The honey wine was ok - really sweet but I guess that goes well with the spicy dishes. 

A really fun and delicious experience. Both of us would definitely go back!
author: Kelly K.

description:
I've tried a few Ethiopian and Eritrian places & this is definitely the best.  The food is the most flavorful, the injara is great & not too sour, the guy that runs the place is supremely happy, and they ask if you want your vegetarian items on the same plate as your meaty items. I love that they remember to ask about that since I don't want my delicious & unspoiled veggie grub to be tainted by my friends' sloppy meat stuff.  

Get the honey wine- it is a great counter-point to the food.  Your first time trying it might make you wince, but you learn to love it.
author: Karyn J.

description: Assab is delicious, the Tsebhi-Dhero(chicken) is spicy and falls off the bone, the Okra and vegetable dishes are excellent. It's a treat, something you can't eat every day in San Francisco.
author: Pablo R.

description:
This place WOULD have been 5 stars but seriously don't wear clothes when you go to dinner here because it is so hot inside you feel like youre in the african bush....I guess that makes things more festive?

Anywho! My friends and I came here looking for some good and interesting food for dinner. We definitely found our place. We ordered all sorts of delish options full of clarified butter and other health food items. While we were waiting however, we ordered some ethiopian beer which was very interesting/sweet tasting. I really enjoyed it and I am not even a beer fan. 

Then, our meal came. We ordered family style so it came on a plate the size of a Big-Rig wheel and we dove in to our platter of curried meats, lentils, veggies. Using nothing but our hands and a bread-like concoction that is like a hybrid between a sponge and a tortilla, we dug it. Eating almost too much but loving every last minute, We wiped our sweaty foreheads, gulped our ethiopian honey wine, and called it a job well done.

Impressed I am. A+
author: Michelle A.

description: The best eritrean restaurant in the city. I'm not a fan of the location (Geary) but the food and the service totally surpasses it.
author: Alice G.

description:
Lovely.  Family owned and run.  Feels like your at home.
If you know about East African cuisine you know that this is the real deal.
author: Ruby s.

description:
Prices have gone way UP and the portion sizes have gone way DOWN... 
what happened?  Even the injera has gotten teensy weensy.
Food is good, but you can get a pretty fancy dinner for what you are paying here which ends up being $20 pp at least just for food.
author: Trecker J.

description: This is a great Ethiopian Restaurant! Wonderful servers and staff and clean,pleasant dining room.
author: Adele D.

description:
I completely love this place!!!

Have never had a bad meal or bad service - the owners are very nice.  And, the food IS delicious.  Plus, I love going native and eating with my hands.  I always leave full and happy after dinning at Assab!

Great place to take a small group of friends and have a relaxed and yummy meal!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Excellent excellent Eritrean deliciousness. 

Every now and then, you'll find a special friend. 
Who rarely eats meal using his bare hands. 
Sans hamburger or sandwich. 
And says, "What's Eritrean food?"

So you take him out to Assab and make sure he tries injera. Cause you know, it's like eating spongy, sour clouds of chewy yum bread. J. and I shared the mixed vegetable platter which is comprised of a layer of injera topped with: okra in tomato sauce, zucchini in tomato sauce, spinach, curry potatoes and cabbage and sour cream. It's all quite delicious and filling for two people. Even with the extra injera and tea (smelling of cloves and nutmeg-which makes me wish I had swiped the extra tea bag) the total bill came out to $15 + tip. And we were full. 

Service was charmingly sassy, but prompt and always responsive-which is so much better for me than polite but aloof. 

Thus saves my two for two batting average for  new eating experiences.
author: Alexis W.

description: Assab is my favorite Eritrean restaurant ever, so I'm lucky that it's within walking distance from home.  We always order the veggie sambusa, kantisha and the veggie combo.  It's the perfect amount for 2 adults plus a toddler who doesn't eat spicy food, but loves injira.  The owners are so sweet, but they're pretty cautious about kids, it's the only place we've ever been reprimanded about out toddler's behavior, and we eat out a lot with her.  But they're so nice about it, it makes us want to go back so they can see how well behaved we can be.
author: k n.

description: Went to Assab's last night with a few friends. It was so tasty with a really friendly environment. I'll be going back again soon!
author: Helen G.

description:
I'm still not clear on the difference between Eritrean and Ethiopian food, but I do know that they are very similar and both completely delicious.  I think my favorite of the vegetarian options is the okra, but they are all worth trying.

And who doesn't like eating with their hands?
author: Caitlin O.

description:
This place has amazing food and can make my least favorite vegetables scrumdiddlyumptious. 

I've been here three times so far and look forward to many more delectable dines here!
author: Matt G.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in town, and probably the best Ethiopian/Eritrean I've ever had. 

The food is EXCELLENT, especially the beef ("Kitfo") and the lamb. And the honey wine is SO good! The service is really friendly--but expect a wait on a Friday or Saturday night. Still, it's WELL worth the wait if you're not in a hurry. 

P.S. You can make reservations, so that helps if you want to go on a Fri or Sat.
author: J K.

description:
YUM YUM YUM YUM YUM
Super yummy

Service was good! despite other reviews,  not super fast,  but good.
Best ethiopian / eritrean food I have had.
author: Chris M.

description: TONS of Injera! I can't eat gluten because of my Celiac disease and so the owner gave me extra lentils to make up for it! Really kind owners. Explained all the different types of Teff flours and was very attentive. Highly recommended!
author: Jefferson S.

description:
Went here last week for dinner on a monday night. After reading all the reviews I was excited to try this restaurant. We have had ethiopian food many times before and this was just the same. Nothing different. Service was good and pesonal.

I am a fan of sweet wines so tried the honey wine and loved it.  My husband and I ordered the lamb and the chicken. The chicken was a little dry and the lamb was a little tough.
author: P From CA C.

description: So delicious, yum! Only one basket table. Ambiance is the only missing factor.
author: S M.

description: I have no complaints about this little eatery. The service was quick and pleasant, the food wonderful (I suggest the Shiro) and the atmosphere better than average as far as Ethiopian, excuse me, Eritrean restaurants go.
author: Daniel S.

description:
This should be a three star review, but I am a fool for eastern African food.

There are better Ethiopian/Eritrean options in the city on both flavor and value, but this is the only one 4 blocks from my house.
author: r g.

description: I really love this restaurant. I went for the first time a few years ago, never having even heard of the cuisine. At first I thought it was weird eating with my hands but now think it's great, and even fun. The service is pretty good. The food is very delicious!
author: Holly F.

description: For those from DC, it's not what you're hoping for, but it's still good in a pinch.  People were very friendly.  The vegetarian sampler says it will only have 3 things on it, but actually ends up with 5 (6 if you count salad), so it's a good amount of food.  A little more expensive than I'd really like, but not too much.  The injera is a little thin, and they only give 1 piece ( you have to order more if you want it).  Overall though, good food, and I'd probably come back.
author: Phil J.

description: Awesome food and very friendly staff. This was my first experience with Eritrean food and I was not dissapointed! My group ordered four vegetarian dishes and they were all fantastic.
author: Robby N.

description: Always sad when they're out of shiro wot and the sauce between the zucchini and okra is kind of similar, but amazing mushrooms (kantishara) and overall tasty quality = best place in SF for ethiopian foods. Enjoy!
author: Ara S.

description:
I've been to another Ethiopian place in San Diego before and can only compare Asaab to that place. Asaab is clean, the atmosphere is nice but they don't go out of their way to be friendly. 

There were four of us and the waitress told us to order three dishes since the servings are big. There was enough food but I would not call the servings big. We ended up ordering another two dishes. In the end i think, one per person is perfect. 

We ordered one lamp, one chicken, and the rest vegi dishes. Overall I think the vegetarian dishes are the best way to go. The meat was too chewy. We asked for one dish to be made mild instead of spicy but it came out very very spicy even for me and I eat spicy food. 

The food had a nice range of flavors but nothing really that stood out. What I was surprised about is that they do not bring out extra bread. They give one roll per order and if you need more they charge. In the place that I've been to before they gave us extra and kept bringing more as needed. I've heard other places in the Bay Area give you free bread as well. The bread was ok but I it wasn't as good as I've had and was a bit bitter for me. 

We came around 6 on a Saturday so it wasn't busy but the place quickly started to fill up closer to 7. They only have a few people working the front so you will have to wait. But if you are in the area and want to try something different you can come here. But I would stick to the vegetarian food.
author: Frida C.

description: good not great. i do think if you're going to disallow certain menu items with a groupon, you should say that ON the groupon. we were a little disappointed not to be able to get either of our favorite dishes without warning. still a nice meal.
author: Erica W.

description:
Best Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've ever had!
I've been, I think to all the places in SF now (except Axum on Haight), but the food here is head and shoulders anything I've had anywhere. The COLORS of the food when it arrives at your table are almost psychedelic. I brought my Brazilian girlfriend here and she can't stop raving about Ethiopian food- it was like a taste revelation to her!
author: Gregory G.

description:
Assab,Assab,Assab...
The best ethnic restaurant in the city!
It is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I love the food (meat sambosa,veggie dish) and also you can order family style and share a huge big rounded dish in the middle..Great!
author: Sophie C.

description:
the food: amazing! I really loved it. we ordered: the platter with Kitfo (groung beef) and the meat combination which was a sampler of Zigni (beef), Tsebhi-Derho (chichen) and Alicha beggee (lamb). The dish can with a little salad and one Ingera (a bread like pancake) All was delicious although WHEN I go again I will opt for the vegetarian options as the style of food really complimented the veg more than the meat. The spinich and the lentils where hands down the best, but you get so little with the meat dishes. The chicken was the nicest of the meats. it had so much flavour! the meat was really good quality.

the service: Fine for me but I can see why some may complain. It is on the slow side though that maybe part of the experience. the whole world does not run at our pace. I did eventually stand up and ask to be served but once we got the ball rolling service was fantastic... I came to realise that although the waiter was attentive he came when he thought you required him rather than when you asked. We just went with the flow and overall he had good judgement.  our server was very helpful when we chose our dishes and kept our glasses full of iced water. One other thing I noticed was that we only got one napkin each... it seemed too few for a restuarant where you eat with your hands. I guess its a learning curve.. eventually I'll only need half a napkin. Over all Good things. 

Price: very reasonable. portions are large and very filling. $10-13 a dish. we didnt drink.

over all experience: It was all new to me, I love new and interesting experiences. I feel like I had more of a taste of Eriterea than just the food. I had concerns over cleanliness other than that of my hands! Chilled.. good for groups.Happy customer. 

Tips: wash your hands, dine with hygiene aware close friends, SLOW DOWN, sit back and enjoy
author: themba l.

description: Owner serves with great care and a great big smile!  The fun begins when he "helps" you pronounce the entrees.  Everything is served on a large platter to share...Channel your inner 2 year-old and dig in with your right hand (sorry southpaws).  Delicious food that is saucy and spicy.   Red and brown lentils and spinich accompany your meat dish, all on a bed of the spongy pancake bread.  Great place to have a fun, tasty meal!
author: Will W.

description:
i'm not one for religiosity (which might just be the understatement of the year), but if the Almighty himself were to gift us a taste of the divine, it might just take the form of a platter of eritrean delights at assab.

i'm partial to ethiopian and eritrean food to begin with, but for some time i had been visiting restaurants with such fare accompanied by a friend who spent part of his childhood in ethiopia.  each restaurant we explored he still decried as being wholly unauthentic to his memories but then a miracle struck.  his girlfriend, who is not only eritrean but a culinary student, changed our world by opening the gates to valhalla.

kitfo, chopped steak tartare cured with spices and topped with a crumbly cheese, has long been a favorite of mine, but anything i've tried before pales in comparison to assab's.  my mouth is watering at the thought of kantisha, a spicy mushroom number.  no meal is complete without the veggie combo, a trifecta of okra curry, zucchini curry, and a potato and cabbage curry.  every order is accompanied by injera, the spongy bread upon which the food is served, and also with a trio of lentils, split peas, and spinach.  of additional note are the gored gored, tsebie derho, and a lamb dish whose name i've forgotten.  each dishe is deliciously spiced and simply spilling over with flavor.

wash it down with some harare (ethiopian lager) and some honey wine, and the celestial ascent has commenced.  although i'm already in bed and the hour's past midnight, the mere thought of assab sends pangs of hunger shooting through my stomach.

customer service is attentive and friendly, and the owner always comes and teases those who were unable to finish their feast.  if i could recommend one improvement, it would be to dole out two pieces of injera per person instead of just one--as it stands, we always have to order more midway through the meal.
author: Roshni R.

description: Ordered take-out, loved everything. Tried the KELWA-MIX which is chunks of chicken breast mixed with veggies and a dallop of yogurt, the MEAT COMBINATION, a sampler of three meat dishes on the menu including chicken beef and lamb, and the BERSIN, mildly seasoned lentils. I thought the chicken dish rocked and when I ate the lentils the next day there were a lot of accompanying "mmmmmmmmmm's". Possibly a way to avoid what sounds like horrible service is to keep Assab on your take-out rotation. Very delicious and flavorful food.
author: margot b.

description:
assab is wonderful!!! a great place for meat eaters and vegetarians alike. when i last dined at assab we ordered most of the veggie options which were served on one enormous plate (family style). every veggie dish except one is made without the traditional clarified butter, and the one that is made with butter can be prepared without upon request. each item i samepled was unique in its deliciousness. and though i can't personally attest to the quality of the meat dishes, i've been to assab with several meat-eaters, all of whom gobbled up their orders with alacrity. 

the service is consistently friendly and the prices are reasonable bordering on cheap. in addition to our lovely meal, we also ordered a large carafe of wine which set us back only a modest $13. assab is a great place to share a casual meal with friends or family, and eating from one shared, nearly table-sized plate enhances the sense of the communal breaking of bread (or injera). seriously, if you haven't been to assab you need to log off yelp, hop on the 38, and treat yourself to some quality food.
author: Jessica C.

description:
HUGE portions!!!!  Lots of veggie options, which were even enjoyed by the two meat eaters in our group.  They also enjoyed the meat dish, so carnivores will be pleased as well.  The honey wine was reasonably priced and delicious.

The only reason I can't give 5 stars is that the service wasn't ideal.  Two of us arrived before the rest of the group, and asked if we could be seated while we waited.  We told the host/waiter that our friends wouldn't be arriving for 1/2 hour, but we didn't feel like waiting outside because it was a really cold day.  He said it was fine, but then acted like we were in the way and was annoyed that we didn't order right away (even though we ordered an appetizer and honey wine while we waited).  I thought maybe it was because we were seated at 1 of only 2 tables in the place that didn't have a "reserved" sign on it.  However, only 2 groups came in during the time that we were there.  One group clearly didn't have a reservation because they asked a bunch of questions and then asked if they had any room for their group, and the waiter removed one of the "reserved" signs and seated them.  The restaurant was never more than half full while we were there.  He then teased my friends for being late throughout the entire meal (they weren't late, they showed up exactly when we said they would).

However, the food is so good I will absolutely be going back anyway.  The interesting service didn't really bother me, although some may not enjoy it.  I think you should go anyway!
author: Rachael S.

description: Absolutely delicious food!  The stretchy bread/ pancakes/ sour crepes were much tastier than the ones I've tried in similar restaurants (see my review of Sheba Lounge).  The food at Assab was just amazing - I had lamb with potatoes and my boyfriend had some kind of spicy beef.  It all comes on one huge plate and you eat with your hands.  EVERYTHING on the plate was fantastic - the little lentils on the side, the orange stuff, the green stuff - I don't know what it was but I wanted more!  We ate until we were too stuffed to go on, and the waiter still shook his head at us for leaving some on the plate.  Sorry!  Altogether the experience was top notch and I will definitely be returning for more Eritrean food!
author: Laura W.

description: I can't wait to go back to this restaurant!  It is absolutely DELICIOUS.  I've never had Eritrean food before, but I am absolutely hooked now!  I wish I lived closer so I could go more often.  Every dish was spiced PERFECTLY - both meat and vegetarian dishes were equally AMAZING. (If you're going there for the first time, I recommend trying the veggie meal with a glass of honey wine). If I had to compare it to a cuisine people are more familiar with, I'd say it's a better-spiced and less filling food than Indian cuisine.  The honey wine went excellently with the spicy dishes.  Just thinking about it is making me salivate!  The service was excellent and the friendly owner even stopped to chat with us and tell us couple facts about Eritrea and the nearby region.
author: Army C.

description:
The customer service was so bad that it inspired me to create a yelp account to reiterate to you all that some things just should not be put up with even if the food is phenomenal. Upon first arriving at the restaurant I waited in the entryway for a long time, but realizing it was a busy night I didn't mind. I was quite relieved after finally being seated, then kind of startled when the party of two behind me had to wait longer because one of their party wasn't there and a table for two was given to someone who just walked in. There may have been other reasons but by the look on the person's face who had to wait, I doubt it.

Again, I didn't think too much of it because this place's food came highly recommended on this site and I was looking forward to a good meal. I quickly decided what I wanted and waited the 15 minutes or so for the waitress to come around and take the drink and food order. If that seams a bit long to you then don't go here because the wait for the food was even worse. I got my drink, surprisingly, though didn't get any refills offered in the literal hour and twenty five minutes I waited. I don't even know if that's how long it took for them to get the food out to the table, that's just the amount of time it took for me to get up and walk out.

Not once did the waitress stop and say, "Gee I'm sorry it's taking so long but we're kind of busy tonight, let me get you some more water." That would have been enough, I would have stayed if I had even been spoken to and apologized to because I work customer service and understand when things get hectic. Not even receiving that, however, I said good night and left and picked up some food on the way home.

I did leave the money for the drink because I didn't want to not pay for what I received, but I was not about to pay for the meal which I did not receive.

Worst customer service I ever received, and that's saying something because I subscribe to Comcast. I would not recommend this place, some people might for non busy nights but if they can't get their act together when they have customers then their not worth visiting during the slow hours either.
author: Chas P.

description: The decor of this place is very cozy and has a homey feel to it. I think the people who own this place are a couple, and the wife helps cook in the back. The food, very similar to Ethiopian food, is very flavorful. I love the combination of sauteed onions and jalapenos with the meat, and the sour injera bread goes really well with the spicy flavors. Since this is in my neighborhood, I will most definitely come here again next time I crave Eritrean food
author: S K.

description: Best Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant in San Francisco.  We've tried 'em all and Assab is consistently the freshest and most flavorful.  Family owned and operated, they recently added a limited selection of home-baked desserts to the menu.  I've introduced many people to Assab, including some who never had this type of food before, and all have become fans.
author: Cindi L.

description: I love Eritrean food and this place does a good job of dishing it out.
author: ryan c.

description: It's one of my overall favorite places to go when i'm in the City, or at least after watching a movie at the Bridge across the street. the portions are served on huge platters, large enough for groups up to 4 or even 5 people. the lentil soup is a perfect appetizer for all the goodness about to come your way. I usually order the Kantisha, sauteed mushrooms with peppers & onions and/or the veggie platter, which is more than enough. i've also figured out that the harar lager is the perfect accompaniment to the food. you couldn't ask for better service, either.
author: Chris C.

description:
UPDATE: 03/04/08
i had to drop two stars from my original 5-star rating. i've been here a few more times, still amazing food, but my last visit did it for me. poor service. if i'm going to dine at a restaurant like this, i really expect great service. i brought a friend from out of town here for dinner. we came on a saturday night, waited about 20 minutes for a table. when we ordered our food, it took probably almost an hour for the food to come! so sad is, my poor son was starving, he just ended up turning cranky and sleepy and missed his hunger window of opportunity. once the food came, they never came back to check on us. they only refilled my water once, and we had to request for the check. i HATE asking for the check. just because things get busy, quality of service should never be lost. AND, if you know you're gonna be busy on a weekend, hire more help!!! i heard of another eritrean place on haight, i'm going to check that place out.

01/28/08
amazing, AMAZING food!! i want to take all my friends here. i spent my birthday here for dinner tonight with my husband, son, and friend who was in town from the east coast. we ordered three entrees family style. it's served on one giant platter. the entrees are atop the bread, and each person is served one piece of bread (and seriously, it's filling). we had one beef dish, one chicken dish, and one vegetarian dish (#3, #6 and #17). the sides that come with each entree order is lentils, sweet potato (i think) and possibly seaweed. we also got two appetizers, one meat sambusa and one vegetable sambusa, both delish. the beef one was a little spicy, and most of their dishes are spicy (you can order it milder for certain dishes). my husband and friend ordered beers and they said they were really really good. i ordered a guava juice and the man cracked a joke at me and asked for id (and my naive self was like, "i didn't know it was an alcoholic drink! har har). after all that food and being stuffed, we still ordered dessert (what's a birthday without cake?) one tiramisu and one cheesecake. the cheesecake was a chocolate cheesecake and was not super sweet. the tiramisu seemed more like a sponge cake, i don't think they were ladyfingers, but still very good. this place is very clean inside, friendly staff, and kid friendly. the check came out to less than $50 too, which is so cheap for all the stuff and beer we got! i'm definitely coming back!
author: Tawny A.

description: I had never had Ethiopian food before and this was a good first experience.  I have since gone back for another turn, and the food was just as good as the first time.  The staff is very friendly and were nice enough to understand I have a very low tolerance for spicy foods and gave me some good recommendations.
author: Britany F.

description:
First time here- great food!

Just as a warning, the food can be spicy! I handled it ok, but my boyfriend could not. Fortunately, you can get Tums at the convenience store next door. =)

We asked if there were any dishes that were mild or not spicy at all, but they didn't have any. The server brought us extra yogurt, hoping that would help. 

We ordered beef and a chickpea dish, and both were very good. Portions were generous and the food was very flavorful.

I would come back to this restaurant, but my boyfriend might not because the food was just too spicy for him. He couldn't eat it. 

If you like food with a kick, I definitely recommend this place!
author: Zhila E.

description: My favorite Ethiopian restaurant in SF.  Slow service, but worth the wait.
author: S Y.

description: Being a product of the 80's, eating Ethiopian food always seems strangely ironic and in poor taste. How many commercials were there about starving children in Ethiopia!? Nonetheless, the food is gooooood. I recommend the veggie mushroom dish and the honey wine. Mmm....
author: Jerry S.

description: I love Ethiopian food!  I used to live with Ethiopians and I would beg them to bring me their food. This place is the best I've had.  nice service, reasonable prices, excellent food.
author: Kevan M.

description: Compared to the Ethiopian restaurants I've frequented, Assab's dishes are spicier and more flavorful.  Their injera is less sour and the dollops of yogurt really complement the stews well.  We had the lentil dish (I love lentils and this was great), spicy chicken and a spicy lamb dish.  The chicken was very tender and the egg was an interesting touch.  I also liked the salad that they put in the middle of our huge platter of food.  Yes, service was slow but the place was packed.  Get there early if you go.
author: Lolia S.

description:
so mom, I've been wantin to try this hole in the wall place on geary cuz I am not sure what Eritrean is.
hmm, not sure if they are open.
cool in here, wonder what these wooden structures are on the floor.
the woman running the show (ie chef, server, cashier and hostess) was concise but certainly congenial. 
at her suggestion we got the special platter and selected the lamb, beef and vegetables, though not entirely sure what would appear. fifteen minutes later she rolled out a platter that nearly covered the table. three glorious stewy dishes sat atop a spongy flatbread. accustomed to south indian dining mom and I went in hands first for succulent and flavorful preparations which we wrapped in the flatbread. 
excellent experience, unusual flavors, and I might have spent $20.
oh, and hours can be unpredictable so call ahead.
author: Jeremi M.

description: I looovvvvveee this place!  I am an Eritrean/Ethiopian food connoisseur (in my own right :) ).  I have to say that this is one of the most authentic, yummy Eritrean restaurants I've ever been to.  The family who own it are so nice.  The wife does all the cooking and the husband helps out in the front.  The chicken and vegi kelwa is the BOMB.  Lentils are cooked to perfection, perfectly spicy and everything is FRESH!  I keep coming back halfway expecting to catch a bad day and it NEVER happens.  Everything here is good.  When i moved here from Seattle, I was worried that I'd have to go all the way to Oakland for decent Eritrean or Ethiopian food.  I am so glad that I found this place.  Enjoy!
author: senait m.

description: This place has amazing food and amazingly bad service.  The staff are all on their own time schedule which doesn't seem to coincide with when people get to their table.  I've given this place at least 5 chances because I love Ethiopian food, but I have to say it's not worth the abuse.  The only reason for the 2 stars is the quality of the food  which is good.   Do not come here!  There is more than one Ethiopian place in the bay and most of them don't ignore you for excruciating periods of time.
author: Nate W.

description: Really good food.  I'm craving their okra as we speak.  There was only one server last time I went, so I felt more sorry for the poor guy waiting us than upset that the food took a while to get to us.  I hope they'll hire more help soon!
author: Lily T.

description: This place is seriously, reliably great food. I usually order take-out, but my one sit-down experience was extremely pleasant, attentive service, etc. Great spot for dinner because the place is usually only about 1/2-2/3 full, so you can usually get a spot with a smaller party. The owners are extremely sweet as well!
author: Ryan B.

description: Probably one of my favorite restaurants in the city! If you don't know what Eritrian food is, you're missing out. It's very authentic with a lot of spices, and you get to eat with your hands. I would recommend the mushroom dish & the lentil soup appetizer.  One dish is more than enough per person which just means you can take the leftovers home.  If you go on the weekend, prepare to wait, but go on a weekday and you barely have to wait. Definitely need to try this place!
author: Margit H.

description: Great meal, but we were soooo full afterwards!  As many mentioned, service is very slow here, but once you get your food, it doesn't really matter anymore because you'll be digging into your dishes with both hands!
author: Allan H.

description: My favorite Etritrean restaurant in town. The proprietor used to run Massawa on Haight Street years ago, and the new place is better! Bring some friends (carnivores and/or vegetarians) and try the zigni, kelwa derho, okra, and alicha family style. The food is excellent, the staff couldn't be nicer, and it's super-cheap. The honey wine is tasty, too. Catch a movie at the Bridge when you can't eat any more.
author: joanna p.

description: I've had better...but I've also had much worse. The service is courteous...food is nicely seasoned. It's vegan and vegetarian friendly.
author: OKAY O.

description: I had always wanted to try Ethiopian food and my dinner at Assab did not disappoint.  My aunt and boyfriend said the food here is much spicier than the Ethopian food they've had elsewhere, but despite the heat it was really tasty!  We had the samusas, veggie sampler, meat sampler and another chicken dish.  The chicken and lamb were so tender and delicious!  The "bread" tastes a little funky to me by itself (like a sourdough crepe), but it's great when it's soaked in flavorful food.  I was very impressed with the service as well.  Our waitress was very friendly and attentive.  The only thing keeping me from going there again is the fact that my fingers smelled like Ethiopian food for like 3 days.  And yes, smartass, I did wash my hands (very thoroughly; multiple times).
author: Krystle S.

description: I'm giving it 5 stars even though the S...E....R....V....I....C...E is REEEEEEEEAAAAAAAAAAAAAALLLLLLLLYYYYYYYYYYYYY slow. It's the best Ethiopean/Eritrean food I've had (including in DC) and it's reasonably priced.
author: mazzy s.

description:
I got the weird eye thing again. And this time it wasn't from my friends but the waiter...cause I completely forgot 2 people in my party  were coming in late when we arrived to sit down and kept flip flopping on the tables. Yes I'm getting senile, but it doesn't have to deter me from gumming my food, people.

Our handy group of eight were game for anything even eritrean food. None of us had this cuisine but from looking at everyone else's table I hope we all came in with empty stomachs cause those family size platters were HUUUUUGE!

I should have went native and ate with my hands but I knew this was an exercise in futility, cause I suck at rolling vietnamese spring rolls and make it yourself burritos. So I know, without utensils, everything will get eaten by my lap instead of said mouth.

All of us ordered #5, #2, #9...plenty of meat for everyone. What we forgot to ask for was to mild up the spices...cause we're wimpy that way. The dishes were jacked up. I love the lentils, sweet potato mash, curry potato and the lamb was succulent. My tongue went up in flames, but it was sooo good, I refused to drown down my saliva. I kept looking at D and A and seeing them wimp out each bite with a swig of water brought out my inner (and TUMS-strengthened) stomach. It was kinda strange because my other friends had their own platter with the same entrees and they said the ground beef was too spicy, but my group thought it wasn't, & our chicken was too spicy but they thought it was mild. We thought they were nuts..friends...go figure. We all liked the flatbreads...it was really spongy! What we didn't like was the desserts. Foodies...stay away from all their dessert offerings. All the cakes (cheesecake, chocolate cake & tiramisu) were frozen, and tasted meh. They looked like stuff from Costco and they stuck in the freezer then pulled it out to thaw prior to serving. We were completely underwhelmed by that offering.

The 2 servers were extremely nice and accommodating. With a packed house on Sunday, I can see how sometimes they lagged a bit, but always quick with our requests. 

Parking wasn't a challenge. There's plenty of 2 hour free parking around. I like the african decor and the music was low and soothing.
author: Pauline L.

description: Came here randomly, cause i wanted something different...glad i stopped in because the food here was great.  I've had ethiopian food before, mostly in Berkeley and Eritrean Cuisine is very similar...I havent really found any in the city i liked (Massawa just doesnt cut it)  Anyway, had their lentil soup and the Combo plate to share...it was great...in expensive and the service was good.
author: Steph S.

description: If your looking for good east-African food in the city, look no further.  This place is really fabulous.  I love item #7 on the menu, the spicy lamb dish.  You might have to wait a bit, but it's worth it.  The folks that run this place are so nice and friendly that it really feels like a special neighborhood eatery,  It's great food for a reasonable price.
author: J D.

description: The stuff looks amazing but unfortunately the taste really disappoints.  Do they really need to make the bread sour too?  EVERYTHING is so sour and I thought I was a big fan of sour.  Three stars cause the service is good, presentation is great and I'm probably just not a fan of this type of food.
author: Herbert W.

description: I absolutely loved this place - great alternative to the typical sushi meal for a first date!  The staff there was super friendly and the atmosphere was very relaxed and comfortable.  Certainly not a 4 star setting but  great place for groups to get a little of everything.  I can't remember everything we had, but the lamb was fantastic and the curry was very flavorful.  Definitely recommend checking this place out!
author: kerry l.

description: We were looking for a snack before catching a film at the Bridge Theater.  We weren't super hungry therefore decided to split an entree instead.  We settled with a vegetarian entree called KANTISHA (sliced mushrooms and sauteed with clarified butter, specifically seasoned red pepper, onion, tomatoes & jalapenos with little yogurt). It was certainly different than anything I have ever had but it was very yummy! I would suggest ordering an extra side of  Injera (their bread) next time given the dish was a little on the wet side (and yes, you have to eat with your hands :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Best vegetarian (vegan if you ask for no yogurt) food ever!

Have tried many other Eritrean and Ethiopian restaurants (Some quite good) but none ever compared to Assab!  Almost always order the same dish; the Vegetarian Combination plate with a vegetarian Samboosa as an appetizer.  Everything is so good here and the variety in the combo plate lets you have a little of it all.

These folks used to own/run Masawa on Haight Street and loved it so much that I tried to eat there once a week.  I left the state for about a year and a half and missed their food so much that I would often dream that I was eating there!  It was one of the first places I returned to when I moved back to SF. Then one day Masawa was being operated by different folks, what a disappointment!  The portions were small oily and laking flavor and the help were so thuggish that I was a little concerned as to how this change occurred as well as for the family who originally ran the restaurant.  Then a friend asked if I had tried, Assab, the new Eritrean restaurant on Geary.  Was so pleased to find the smiling family from Haight street!  This latest location has really caught on, last Tuesday I was there around 8:30 and they were so packed that I had about a 15 minute wait for a table, but very well worth the wait.
author: Mark C. J.

description: I really like the food here and I've had a lot of Eritrean food.  The spices are just a little different than other restaurants but unless you're in the East Bay, it's hard to get anything better.  It seems that they could put together some different combinations so you can get more vegetarian or greens with the meat dishes instead of having to order two meals just to get the right mix.  And it seems to be getting more expensive but what do I know?  If you don't have a reservation, make sure you're not starving when you arrive or you could be waiting quite a bit.  It's a small place but worth it.
author: Eileen L.

description: For years, I had driven by Assab on my way back downtown without paying it much attention.  Having eaten at most of the Ethiopian/Eritrean places in the Bay Area, I finally got around to stopping and checking it out, and was hooked.  In fact, during my "farewell to SF" eating tour that accompanied my final months living in the city, I ate there three times.  Assab, like almost all its peer restaurants, is no frills, and it's a family operation, so service tends to be on the slow side.  But the food and beer?  Nicely, nicely done.  And the prices?  Completely reasonable, which is likely why I always see so many students there.  Definitely a place to check out if you're into Eritrean food, as it is one of the better examples in the Bay.
author: Ty D.

description: Haven't experienced better Eritrean food then this! I always order their kitfo and gored gored raw, it's super delicious and very spicy! Portion sizes are very generous, just make sure you bring enough people to help eat all the food as the owner frowns at unfinished plates.
author: Ericka A.

description: This place is so good, I tried to go there two nights in a row (except that it's closed on Sunday)! My absolute favorite dishes here are the okra, and beef. Staff is sooo nice and service is very prompt. I can't wait to go back!
author: Quyen N.

description: A definite two thumbs. Be a rebel and eat with no utensils cause that is how it's supposed to be done. The ambiance is colorful and teeming with the aromatic spices only found in the exotic wonderland that is Assab. I particulary enjoy digging into the lamb and chicken combo. For those not accustomed to the heavy spices, it has all the trimmings for an aquired taste indeed! It's a great place to hang with friends and I highly recommend them. Prices are descent and not to mention very clean.
author: Dennes H.

description: Nice people, big portions, impressive presentation, but my party agreed the (shared, eat with your hands) food was very average. Veggie preps seemed more authentic and the means tastier at the East Bay Eritrean/Ethiopian joins we'd tried. No urge to go back. Tab was $23/person with tip.
author: Nick C.

description: Excellent food at great prices. This is my favorite African place in San Francisco. Service can be slow when it's busy, but it's well worth the wait!
author: Tim A.

description: If zero stars was possible this place would get it. This might be the worst restaurant I have ever been to. We came from San Jose and we walked in the door with seven people and they wouldn't accept us and put two tables together. The manager was the one who "couldn't" seat us and was beyond rude. Worst customer service of my life. I highly discourage visiting this establishment. Never shall I return and I'll make sure anyone who reads this shall not go. Spend your hard earned cash elsewhere. I might suggest Axum where we ended up. Delicious and rated the same.
author: Chris S.

description:
Other reviewers were spot on in describing the service.  While there is only one waiter, there were also only 8 or so tables - one would think he'd be on it.  He did apologize profusely for the fact that our drinks didn't get to us until after our appetizers were finished, but that was really the only time he interacted much with us.
The food was yummy, spicy, hot and just what I wanted on a cold, rainy night to celebrate a similar meal two years before.
The injera was lighter than I've had, with lots more holes which meant much messier fingers, but I wasn't complaining as I licked every little bit off.
We had the mushroom dish based on other reviews, and the meat sampler.  The beef and chicken were great, I loved the lentils, and the injera was perfectly tangy.  The mushrooms were good, but I don't think I'd order them again, or the lamb.  Not that they weren't good, just that I liked other things more.  The sambusas we started with were also good (and flaming hot), but lacked any kind of side sauce.
Overall, I'm really happy we managed to have a good Eritrean dinner last night, but I think I'm still slightly partial to New Eritrea.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Loved this place mentioned in the recent "Bargain Bites" edition of the SF Chronicle.  Inexpensive, yummy, and nutritious.  Great Eritrean beer, too.  It seemed that one waiter was tending to multiple customers, so the wait was somewhat long but worth it.  High recommendations -- we're going back!  A bonus, too -- parking on the street was easy : )
author: L H.

description: What a tasty tasty place! I love the easygoing feel and the friendly service. I haven't anything I didn't like here....and try the Honey Wine..nice compliment to the spicy dishes!
author: Henriette P.

description: I am already planning a second visit.  Spicy, flavorful zigni and kentisha were matched with great service.  We started with the beef turnover thing.  They should look into marketing those to the hot pockets people.  Excellent!
author: T-Bone L.

description: Wow, I think Assab is so far the best Eritrean/Ethiopian food I have had in the City.  At New Eritrea and Axum you only get the dish you ordered.  At Assab you get some extra stuff on the side like lentils, spinach, some yogurt and another vegetable thing that seems to be made with tomatoes.  The pricing is reasonable and I find their food less oily than the other restaurants I've been to.  I was really happy with my food and with the pricing.  Now that I have tried Assab, I am never going back to the other Eritrean restaurants.
author: Kandi K.

description: Absolutely delicious food. Try the honey wine as well. Myself and my guest are both vegetarians, so we stuck to that portion of the menu, but it was truly excellent. If you don't like spicy food or aren't fond of eating with your hands, you might not be so into it. Remember, eat with your right, wipe with your left.
author: Zach C.

description: This place is great.  Super delicious food, huge portions, and really friendly staff.  I love to share the veggie combo plate with my boyfriend.  the Injera is fantastic, and besides . . .who doesn't love to eat with their hands!
author: Jorie p.

description: Food was awesome, service was decent, conservative decor, and a-ok street parking. Try Kifto, Gorda, and Honey wine.
author: James T.

description: It was a little different I guess, but nothing mind blowing. The Mushroom dish we ordered was really good, other than that the vegetarian combo was just alright. The meat eaters enjoyed themselves, but for a restaurant that is rated for its vegetarian food.. theres MUCH better eritrian/ethiopian food out there! Most ethiopian/eritrian places I know bring in baskets of injera as part of the meal, was peeved that this one with sub standard food charged extra for every measly injera. Oh have had better injera too. So vegetarians keep looking.. meat eaters maybe you might enjoy this place!
author: S R.

description: I called to make early dinner reservations for our family of 2 adults and 3 children.  They REFUSED to make me a reservation b/c they didn't want to waste a table on a party with 3 kids.  Are you kidding me?  We have dined at far better restaurants then this all over the U.S. and Europe and have never had this type of unacceptably rude response.  I will never eat there now not even without my kids.
author: Debbie M.

description:
my friend had requested ethiopian and so i found this place on yelp and had high expectations going in based on the great reviews and while everything was tasty, i wasn't overly wowed by it. or maybe it could be that this was my first time trying eritrean cuisine (the difference between this and ethiopian is that it has an italian influence. who says wikipedia isn't helpful?) so i didn't know what to expect. 

we ordered the veggie combo (alicha, okra and zucchini) and a lamb dish and i washed everything down with honey wine on the side. i found it hard to eat without utensils since the injera (thin soft bubble bread - i took this straight from the menu) was so porous that when i went to go pick up the food with it, it fell apart or the sauce dripped through everything that i finally had to ask for a spoon. blasphemy i know. 

i went on a weekday and there was no wait or anything, in fact half the restaurant was empty and about thirty minutes before they were supposed to close, they started putting up all the chairs and turning off the lights so we got the hint and made our way out of there. overall i would say it's a fun spot to try a different type of cuisine but i'm still undecided whether i need to make a return trip or not.
author: georgette y.

description: Went with a group of 8 without ever having eaten Ethiopian food before on a recommendation of Yelp. The staff was extremely friendly and very helpful. The food is delicious and to my surprise, you eat everything with your hands! The only thing I would knock them for is the interior decoration could be better, but I am not going to let my snobby design sensibilities interfere with my starred rating here.
author: K. C.

description:
i love this place, if only for the fact that it possesses the distinction of being the fastest meal ever eaten as a team sport.

now, you have to understand, i am ALWAYS the first person finished at a meal, often getting to the point of idling my thumbs while the rest of my fellow diners slowly & meticulously feed themselves. i try to slow down and be calm, but damn! i am always hungry.

so, a few months ago, i'm at assab, where i've dined many a time. their food is quite delicious, their service powerful slow. we arrived at 6:30 or so and waited nearly an hour for dinner. at this point, the entire party is about ready to start tearing into each others limbs, apart from the fact we're all vegetarians.

food arrives at 7:20. by 7:25 we have consumed the entire plate of mushrooms, lentils, okra, spinach and injera. someone has even gone around the side of the plate with their hands to scrape up the minute chunks of okra that remained.

yes, it is possible we were that hungry.

ambiance in minimal, but not too loud. food is fantastic, but don't go on an empty stomach.

place gets packed even on a monday night, so be there before 7 for a table without a wait.
author: Carla B.

description:
Despite having to wait for a while because the server / host gave our table away just as we walked in to the restaurant (granted, we were 20 minutes late so I didn't blame anyone but ourselves), this restaurant is a definite 5-star.  The server was very apologetic and promised that we will be seated within 15 minutes (we did). 

They must've hired extra help since these reviews were written, because there were two servers (which is probably just about the right number given the size of the place).  Our food and drink came out in no time and we got the attention that we needed.

First, the honey wine.  Must try if you haven't already.  

Then, the two dishes that we ordered - one being meat dish (super spicy lamb stew) and one a vegetable dish (I think it's chickpeas) came on top of a giant pancake-like bread.  Highly recommended as well (if you take spicy food well... otherwise, ask the server for less spicy alternatives).

Eating without utensils is a big part of the fun.... it's worth having to soak your hands in lemon water and spend 20 minutes scrubbing it afterwards to get rid of the lingering smell.
author: Ange L.

description: Best Ethiopian food around, hands down. Fresh, yummy, and relitively inexpensive. I love you, Assab.
author: Amanda D.

description: Good food, horrible service. Came here with a party of 4. It took us 20 minutes to place our order, 40 minutes to get our order and then another 20 minutes to get our check. But this is true about most dining experiences in the Richmond.
author: Natalie T.

description: Amazing food, for vegetarians and meat lovers alike. Great foreign beer. great service and even better prices.  So Yum.  The food is so great and you eat it with the bread....lentils are amazing!
author: Jackie M.

description: Finger-licking good.  Went for the meat combo.  Yummilicious.  Try the Meta beer - tasty.
author: David B.

description: Not that I have eaten much African food, but this was very delicious and different.
