I went with a vegitarian friend who basically ordered pureed vegetables and preferred my whole veggies with chicken over her meal.  We both really enjoyed it as we are always going out to eat and appreciated how this restaurant broke the monotony.  Service was good if not a bit slow.  However, DO NOT order the Ethiopian honey wine.  It tastes like cough syrup.
author: Jessica Y.

description: I had been wanting to try this place for over a year. Finally we made it over there and it was well worth it. We got there around 6:30p on a Saturday night and it wasn't over crowded so we were seated right away. Tried out the veggie and meat samosas (sooo good) and the lentil soup. They brought out our order of vegetarian and meat tasting menus, okra in tomato sauce, additional lamb dish, and additional beef dish in a HUGE platter. This is how they serve family style and I loved it. The price is really reasonable too. With 5 people, 5 entres, 3 soups, 2 appetizers, glass of wine and tea, the bill was less than $20pp incl. tip. Unfortunately, the only reason I wouldn't give them 5 stars is because the service was really slow. If yelp would let me, I'd give it 4.5 stars.
author: Janelle C.

description: Only been to Assab once, not what I expected, but I think it was good. Would like to try other things on their menu next time around.
author: Rommel N.

description: It was good. The service not on point... and alright atmosphere.
author: Al T.

description: in one word it was delicious. I ordered a chicken and beef dish along with the soup. The soup was my favorite part, I usually don't like lentils, but this was a spicy and tasty,
author: Sarah W.

description: The food was really good, but the service was very mediocre. The food took forever to come, i.e., we came at 8 and left at 10.
author: Alex Y.

description: Thought the food was great! You can get a family platter with whatever dishes you want and it is good and enough to feed 2 or more people at your table. Never had Eritrean or Ethiopian food before, so it was a new experience and a very good one. I had honey beer for dinner, and it was good. Can't go wrong with honey! Would like to come again and try the appetizer.. didn't get to try it.. looks yummy!
author: Daisy S.

description: I love this place whenever I have my cravings for super delish Ethiopian food.  I think the service is great, if you take into account the fact that most Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants are known for taking their time with the service.  It's a family-run establishment, the man who usually takes the order is always there with a ready smile.  The food is incredible and can be quite spicy, which I love.  Their samosas are incredibly good!  Now I need an excuse to go there soon!
author: Lucky T.

description: pretty good.  a little pricey for the amount of food you get - a lot of sauce, not a lot of veggies or meat.  I ordered the okra stew as recommended and it wasn't very much at all. It was fairy good, but not the best I have had.  Service was a little distant at first, but warmed up after bringing the food.  Though it is not expensive, it is not a good value since each entree is basically sauce and bread.
author: Madison W.

description: Hallelujah- I've found a place to get amazing eritrean food in the city.  A former east bay girl, I've been missing blue nile and asmara.  Now I can get an injera and tej fix any old time I want.  The location is a bit of a bummer for me (I live in Russian Hill), but it's so reasonable, so tasty, and so pleasant that it warrants a special trip on occasion.
author: nicole l.

description:
Summary of my update: Assab choose 7 packets of Splenda over customers who have been giving them business for 5 years.
Over the years we figured out that the owner/one-waitress-staff were kind of curt/borderline-rude(?) but we liked the food so ...whatever.
We have seen them talk to other patrons like: You should have made a reservation - I can't accommodate you, or, (No please) Go out and talk (while you are waiting to be seated) or (No please) Don't block the doorway.
Anyway, yesterday my son was playing with the salt and pepper shakers (not breaking them, not making a noise with them, not throwing contents around) and the waitress came and took then away. After a bit he was rearranging/counting the sugar packets and she came and took those away?! Really? 
Honey, I would have been a-ok with you adding the 75 cents to my bill for the splenda but this has turned me off your restaurant for good AND made me write a bad review.
author: live to eat C.

description: My sister took me to this place for my birthday last week, I had never had  Eritrean food before, but I was certainly down -  it was really tasty. You know what, if you are looking for a slight deviation from Indian food, you'll like the dishes they have to offer as it has that spicy and saucy thing going on. I had the vegetarian spinach dish, my sister the lamb, and every dish is served with injera(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Injera), this amazing pancake like goodness that is used to scoop and soak your entree of choice; so, please be prepared to eat with your hands, no utensils needs . Speaking from a place of complete newness to Eritrean food, this place was a wonderful surprise, a jolt to my taste buds that made me wonder what other foods on this Earth have I been missing out on.
author: Brian S.

description:
4.5 Stars. Definitely a great place to have some unique flare of eats. If you've never had Ethiopian food, this is definitely the place to try it. Unfortunately since I haven't been to Ethiopia, I can't speak to the authenticity, but I do recall having Ethiopian food at the age of 7. 

A very intimate atmosphere, in which you cannot get away from the great smells of its kitchen as you enter. Filled with spice, Ethiopian food brings you to this ethereal experience of flavor. If you don't like spice this perhaps may not be the place for you - but if you like spicy, sour, salty (not necessarily all at the same time) - this could be the place for you!.  We ordered the Tsebhi - Derho and Zucchini. Huge portions, well stewed and off the bone chicken. I'll be honest, when I first read the menu I feared that all the dishes would taste the same, as the ingredients seemed similar, but to my surprise there was a huge contrast.

For those who haven't had Ethiopian - I would describe it similar to Indian, South East Asian (The chicken I had reminded me of Rendang), but with a much earthy flavor.

Have fun & enjoy! Bon Appetit!
author: Jeannette L.

description: Good food and horrible service. There is waiter service, but they hardly ever come around. Don't expect your water to be filled once it empties.
author: K W.

description: I'm obsessed with this place. It's the best East African food I've had in this city, and it's so affordable. You can just order one meat and it comes with 2 (I think) vegetables. The staff is helpful and efficient and the food is excellent. It's a little dive-y, but it's a nice alternative to the pretentious places that seem to populate much of the city.
author: Anonymous F.

description: This place is great! They have an awesome Vegi platter and meat platter, all the food was very tasty, they have decent cheap wine and the service is great too!
author: Michele G.

description: The food is great.  The experience is perfect - casual but interesting (goat art on the wall!?)  And you all huddle around a big ol' plate of food and scoop it up with bread.  Went with a party of 8 and everyone was happy - the vegetarian loved the potato dish, the meat eater was happy.  Recommend the sambusas as an app (sorta like samosas only flat and hot-pocket-ish.)  The Okra was great.  The Mushrooms were flavorful - tasted oddly like pepperoni pizza.  And the lamb was a huge hit. Try the honey wine, it works perfectly with the spicy flavorful food.
author: Kelli R.

description:
This restaurant was my first foray into African dining and I loved it!!! In fact I have loved it on all subsequent visits. 
In addition to deliciously well prepared food the dining experience itself is a hoot. If you are squeamish about sharing food/plates with others this may not be your cup of tea. It is considered good form to order 1 entree per person and all of them get served on these beautiful platters. Everyone gets some injira (sorta sour crepe type bread stuff; very good) then you dive in. 
I should have taken a picture of the menu because I can't for the life of me remember how to spell the dishes. The vegetarian one with potatoes and cauliflower is fantastic. There a beef one that starts with a g (i think; or is it a k) and that is also exceptionally good. I am not a huge lamb fan but I did enjoy their version and would probably order it again. The lentils, the spinach, the yogurt sauce; all good. So the take home on this is that is place is darn tootin' good. I have heard that it is spicy but I think it is just right.
This place is not very big and there are only two servers so be prepared to wait if you go on a weekend night. But as I and the rest of the people who dug in for the 45 minute wait know it is totally worth it. When you want Assab nothing else will do.
Oh yeah, the beer is good. They used to have one called Tusker (it was named after the elephant who killed the owner of the brewery) but it got too expensive to import so they don't have it anymore :(
author: colleen b.

description: I have been to this place a few times. The food is amazing. The zigna (beef) dish has a great mixture of different spices, I also love the shiro. I am always VERY pleased after a meal here. A nice touch, is the the place is family run. The male is so nice and has a great rapport with the customers. I highly recommend this place! LOVE IT.
author: claire F.

description: Loved this place!  Food was delicious!  Service friendly and the prices were reasonable.  Seasoning was perfect.
author: patty h.

description:
Veggie combo. Most items in the combo had a sort of tomato pasta sauce. I wasn't expecting this based on other Ethiopian food I've had (is Eritrean that much different?). They only give you one piece of injera bread and you have to pay for extra. 

I did really like the chard item though. I tried honey wine for this first time and it tasted like plum wine - really sweet and not great. 

The service was good and fast and the price was normal. Atmosphere was fine and clean.
author: Sarah J.

description: The food was great.  However, definitely ask what bottle of wine/chardonnay before ordering - you' ll definitely overpay.
author: Lil Jinni L.

description: Had a really delcious meal here with a friend visiting from NYC.  Very friendly staff (albeit persistent about finishing up the enormous feast!).  The food was great and I will certainly be going back!
author: Jason M.

description: I like this place more and more. Such unique flavors and spices! Sometimes the food takes awhile to be prepared, but it's for a reason. It's fresh and tasty! Much better than the Ethiopian restaurants I've been to.
author: A Y.

description: food is absolutely amazing and the service impeccable. It was our second time there and there will be definitely some other ones...
author: Carpe D.

description:
I really liked the food.  I went with 3 other people and we each ordered an entree which was put on on big serving platter to share family style, which is the best way to go so you can sample everything.  We also ordered the honey wine, which had a very interesting taste to it, but I wouldn't order it next time I go.  
The service is slow only because there was only one waitress, who was also probably washing the dishes and maybe helping the cook too.  It's obviously worth the wait and I will be back!
author: LT B.

description: i have to say this place is okay because this is the first time i have had Ethopian food.  I went with a group of 8 and we got two family platters with dishes 5, 2 and 9.  I had fun eating everything and sharing.  We eventually all had to get forks to eat properly but the pancake thing that we used to pick up our food was delcious with the things you can fill it with.  We had the chicken, pork and beef dishes and forgot to ask for it mild.  Overall, I had an educational experience for my tastebuds and wouldn't mind going back there with people.
author: Daphne A.

description:
Only negative is the service can be a little slow.

Food is consistently excellent.  Been going for a few years now and we are always pleased with the meal.
author: John W.

description:
Love love LOVE this restaurant.  Amazing.  I've tried a lot of Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants, but this one is BY FAR the best I've come across.  The injera (sp?) is a perfect blend of sour taste and spongy texture to soak up the delicious sauces and drippings of the food, and the food is perfectly spiced: complex but not overwhelming.  

Be prepared, though, if you come on a weekend night--the sweet family who runs this place haven't quite figured out the balance of servers/cooks to tables yet, so when they're super busy the food can take a bit to come out of the kitchen.  But the food is so good it totally makes up for the wait--hence the 5 star rating!
author: Liz N.

description: Maybe it's just me, but the food here was nothing "amazing" or "fucking incredible".  Sure, I enjoyed the culture and the traditional African cuisine, but the service here was quite slow (friendly servers, however) and I just couldn't cream my pants over the food here.  Sorry.
author: Scott G.

description:
Had the lamb, enjoyed it.  The injera was a little thin.  The service was very good.  Really liked the Ethiopian Lager.  Again one of the few restaurants that seats well.  Pretty empty when we arrived, not a free seat in the house when we left.  

Atmosphere was accommodating.  Liked the spaces between the tables, we could talk without yelling.  Which we won't do, so we have spent more than one unintentional silent dinner together.

It isn't up to the quality of Massawa's in the late 80's but it's not bad.  Probably won't eat there again, but will be back for takeout.
author: The P.

description:
Compared to an ethiopian restaurant we go to on Valencia, this place is pricey. I believe the quality of the food here IS better, but my wallet has the final say, and we are not coming back.


This place is located in a restaurants's no man's land, so it doesn't have much competition.

We noticed they have a local crowd following,only one waiter who you have to wave to get his attention.

Nice decor, easier parking, but that's about it. I guess I am on crack!
author: Rod A.

description: I love this restaurant!  The food is amazing!  If you like lentils, this is the cuisine for you.  Try the lentil soup appetizer - very tasty.  The injera is yum too.  It can get quite busy so be patient.  I have only ever seen 2 people working there - one waiting tables and one in the kitchen, so things can move slowly.  Bring along some good friends with good conversation and enjoy!  Oh yeah - and try the honey wine.  It has a wonderful honey aftertaste.
author: Maya S.

description: I love this place.  Service is great.  They are very friendly and can handle busy crowd.  Last time we were there, every single table was filled.  The food is excellent, we always get the Meat combo and Vegetable combo for the ultimate in variety.
author: E C.

description:
Recently visited SF to partake in all the ethnic delicacies.  We were so glad that we took a little ride out into the hood to enjoy Assab.

Never had Eritrean/Ethiopian food before, but this meal represented the beginning of a love affair.  Loved the simple, hole-in-the-wall atmosphere.  Our waitress was delightful.  She "quizzed" us on how to pronounce our entree (needed to do that cool pop in the back of your throat to pronounce it correctly).  Lots of fun.

And then of course the food was fantastic.  The stout beer and honey wine threw us for a loop at first, but the pairing with the ultra spicy food eaten without utensils made a lot of sense in hindsight.  Whatever jokes you may have heard/told in grade school about Ethiopian food aside, this place sets this pre-adolescent convention on its head by serving more food than you can possibly eat.  Definitely get served "family style" to enjoy the full experience.  Bring your appetite!

We weren't brave enough to try the lamb raw.  The samosa-type turnover as an appetizer was the bomb (keep your napkin handy).  We loved everything about this experience and would heartily recommend it.
author: Michael A.

description: I really liked this place: good food, good prices, good veggie options. The mushroom dish was my favorite (can't remember the name). I do agree with Adam L. that the service is on the slow side.
author: Krista S.

description:
i think all the ethiopian places in the city are total crap but if you dont feel like making the trip to the east bay and dont want to eat in a bar (waziema) this is probably the best option.
one should be aware however the service is slow and they are injera nazis.
author: rachel k.

description: Food was very tasty...except I did not like Sambusa (appetizer) so much. It does not come with any sauce and only has spicy peas and carrots. The place was nicely decorated as well. It took forever to get food though.
author: jigna b.

description:
Assab's food is pretty darn delicious!  I especially like their tesbhi-dehro, which is chicken legs stewed in a deep, dark, deliciously spicy sauce.  Some reviewers commented about how little meat they give you in an entree - but with a sauce that good that's been stewing with the boned chicken, every bite has the flavor of the chicken, regardless.  So reach in deep with your injera and really savor it!  The spinach is amazing as well.  

I've been several times, and I have to say that the best experiences are when I've come with a small group.   I agree with other reviewers that the service can sometimes be a little slow, but when you're enjoying the company of friends with a few Ethiopian lagers, it's actually quite nice not to be rushed through the experience.
author: amy b.

description: Every since living in DC, I've been obsessed with Ethipoian food as they have the best in the country.  So when I moved here, I was on the hunt for something similar and I have to say, this place is it!  It's really fun with big groups, but make a reservation, this place is busy!  The service is great and food is awesome!
author: Luci B.

description: i been going to this restaurant for years , this restaurant is simple but one of the  unique san francisco restaurant.
author: Stan m.

description: Had a lovely lunch at this restaurant after seeing it featured in the Chronicle's bargain bites.  Shared a vegetable combination platter (zucchini, okra, and potatoes) and meat combination platter (lamb, chicken, ... beef?) with a friend for $20 total, including tip. It was more than enough food for the both of us.  The potatoes and zucchini dishes were a little bland, but everything else was tasty.  The host was very attentive, too.
author: christina l.

description: I admit, it takes awhile to get your food, but my friends...it is totally worth the wait!  Like nothing I have ever had before, but yet, so familiar.  I would rank Assab as one of the best spots for comfort food.  As much bread as you can eat, delicious Honey wine, spicy and flavorful dishes all around.  And about that slow service...probably the nicest people I have ever encountered, and thoroughly gracious.   This is a great place to come with friends to share a meal, and take your time.
author: Meg C.

description: Food was awesome.  Sambusas are delicious ( I liked the veggie one better).  Be prepared to have your clothes carry the dinner odor afterwards.
author: Mike K.

description: Simply outstanding food.  Really slow (but friendly) service.  We went on a Saturday night and the owner(?) and one other person were all alone to wait on the 30-40 diners - it was painfully slow.  We had to basically flag them down to get anything.  The food was worth it though.  Perfectly cooked with great spices.  We all agreed that the mushrooms was the best of five dishes we tried.  Five star food, with 2 star service
author: Ziya D.

description: If you are looking for a different dining experience and good food to boot, go to Assab.  Be in the mood for some spicy food though and I would suggest at least 3 or more people.  We went with 6 and there were 2 large plates brought out.  We had the beef, chicken and lamb....all were great.  Oh, we had the stew too, the first time I ate stew with my hands!!  Don't go in starving, service was a little slow, very pleasant though.
author: K P.

description:
The meat samosas are awesome.   The host/waiter is very friendly, and service is good.  I ordered the honey wine to try it, and it was not good.  Too syrupy and sweet.  

We ordered the Vegetable Combo, and that was tasty.
author: Howard-Daisy L.

description: Fantastic Eritrean food (similar to Ethiopian). The best in the city. Extremely nice staff. Try the Zigni and any of the vegetarian items. Good beers. Better than New Eritrea on Irving. Hours are a bit confusing sometimes.
author: Tucky D.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood spot. Great flavors and a fun place to take visitors, family, friends. Makes just a so-so date spot, as it's better when you order multiple dishes and share family style. Super friendly staff.
author: Yelper B.

description: This place has fresh and tasty cuisine.  If you like Eritrean food - this is the place.
author: Mia T.

description: The food was perfectly adequate, nothing special. With many other Ethiopian and Eritrean choices in the area, I wouldn't return.
author: J R.

description: best eritrean that i have found so far in SF. really delicious. i always bring people visting from out of town here.
author: Jessica M.

description: Assab may not serve up the best Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've ever had, but it's certainly pretty tasty and there are few enough African restaurants in the Bay area that it's well worth an occasional visit.  The only real complaint I'd have about the dishes I've sampled here is that they're perhaps a wee bit on the oily side, and some are a little heavy on the vinegar for my taste.  That being said, the food is otherwise flavorful and pleasing, with plenty of choices for vegetarians and a reasonable handful of entrees that pack a pleasing amount of heat (for those who like a little sizzle in their meal).  Assab's look is modest and comfortable, festive and rich in color, and it's a good spot for conversation over dinner.  The service was helpful and friendly, and (maybe most important of all) the menu choices provide a refreshing change of pace from the more heavily-trod styles of cuisine to be found--as much as I love Thai and Japanese, it's true that sometimes I want something different.  I'm glad to have a good Eritrean spot right up the street.
author: Michael T.

description: Nice ambiance, awesome food, and the price is right. This was my first time dining at an Eritrean restaurant and it was a fun experience. I'd definitely recommend this place to a friend. Cheers!
author: J J.

description: i've eaten here 4 times now and every time it's been excellent!  we always get 3 different types of meat dishes (usually 1 chicken, 1 beef, and 1 lamb) and they are served beautifully on a huge platter with green salad, yogurt, cooked greens, two different types of lentils, and that wonderful spongy bread. yes, everything is spicy, but the sauces are delicious so order lots of water and extra yogurt and sponge bread up front to help cool things down.  and it's fun to use your hands to eat anyway.  service is, unfortunately, very slow but the food is so good and owner is soooo nice and charming that we don't mind waiting.  and for what it's worth, i'm not an african food expert either.  i just like what tastes good.   it's a find!
author: Cyn B.

description:
I always leave Assab so full I could vomit.  For me, this is the highest praise I can give a restaurant.  I've been coming here for over two years and it's still a top favorite of mine.  The thing to get is the Tsebhi Dehro, the chicken stewed in heavenly juices (that's not what it says on the menu but it's basically what it is).  Falls off the bone, juicy, flavorful, god almighty might walk through the door any second....and you'd still be focused on the chicken.  All of the veggie dishes are epic too, okra, spinach, 'shrooms, lentils... and each dish comes with a smattering of each, so you're golden.  
Honey wine, too sweet for me. Order one for a group just so everyone can have a sip and say, 'Hey, I tried honey wine from AFRICA.'  The lamb and beef: unbelievable flavor, not super tender, but like I said the flavor makes up for it.
Love the service.  Quite slow, family run mom&pop and it's lovely-it means they're taking their time with my food and its not sitting out all night.  You can actually stand by the kitchen door and watch the nice lady cook if you get on their good side... 
Then when everyone at the table is food coma-ing, the lovely man comes over, appraises the remaining jalapeno and injera on the plate, proceeds to tell you you're not done eating, then smiles hugely and offers dessert.  

Bottom line: great food, lovely people, not a quick meal... an incredible experience of Eritrean excellence!
author: josselyn g.

description: This was my first time going for Eritrean food and I was pleasantly surprised. First off, be sure to order the Eritrean Lager - it's astonishingly good - a complex nose and pleasing finish, it is a great deal for $3.50! The whole meal was a great experience although it was pretty messy eating with my hands, even with their bread (kind of like a crepe but with more bubbles it in) to use as a pincher for grabbing the tasty, spicy food. In regards to the level of spiciness, we orders ours to be less spicy and it still had a little kick and was far from being mild/bland, a great option for the spice averse. It took us a while to get someone to take our order, but once it was placed, service moved quickly and we had food in about ten minutes. The dessert options were kind of dull and didn't sound Eritrean, so we passed. Overall, it was great fun and I would definitely recommend it to a friend...plus, with the economy how it is, it's pretty reasonable - $24 per person with tax and tip, with my friend and I each getting one beer.
author: Kara A.

description: The food here is decent. I guess I had my expectations brought up by all the rave reviews. I've had much better Eritrean/Ethiopian food elsewhere and the service, though friendly, is very very slowwwww.
author: Amy L.

description: i LOVE this place. a very cozy atmosphere.  food is served either family style or on your own. family style's much more fun!  i tend to get either the meat or veggie dishes.. usually preferring the veggie combo dish since it's a bit of different things. the veggie sambusas (they look like hot pockets and have filling inside) are yummy. i recommend ordering extra yogurt as sometimes the food gets spicy (but is sooo good). i really like the waitress here who recognizes me. don't know her name but she's so sweet and just one of those people that make you want to go back to a restaurant. overall, a good place to try ertirean food if you haven't had it before. parking is also super easy around this area for SF.
author: ally o.

description: My wife & I went to Assab for dinner recently with our 1 yr old baby. The restaurant was almost empty. Even then the waiteress gave us a very small table (1.5ft x 1.5ft) in the extreme corner of the restaurant. It was rather small for two of us and a high chair. When requested her to move us to a different table (75% of the restaurant was empty), she just refused. Anyway - decent food but nothing special. So 3 stars.
author: V M.

description: Delicious food, a bit pricey vs. other Eritrean in SF/Berkeley. Lotsa food, good service. Atmosphere about average. Ask for extra injera as the owners are a bit stingy on this count.
author: Oscar C.

description: Never again. I went for wonderful west African food and walked away disappointed. The food was bland and they didn't have a large selection. I am used to having many options. I am not a beef eater, but wanted to sample more then one kind of meat. When i asked them if they could substitute another type of chicken they said no, but offered to just add more the chicken and leave out the beef. I thought this was a great idea until i received the bill and saw that they charged me 3 extra dollars. 3 extra dollars for chicken? Correct me if i am wrong but 1) beef costs more then chicken and 2) shouldn't this have been disclosed prior to the billing?!?!?! In addition, they do not give you enough of the spongy bread stuff. They give each person one piece. When partner and I asked for another peice to split they brought it and failed to mention they were going to charge us another dollar for it! People, save your money and drive across the bridge to Berkeley. I have never been disappointed with any of their many Ethiopian food options. My favorite is the Ethiopia Restaurant on telegraph. Tons of choices, all the bread stuff you can eat, and wonderfully nice staff!
author: Marina H.

description: Wonderful food and great service. It's one of my new favorite city haunts. Come hungry!
author: Tim M.

description: The word 'yummerific' comes to mind. The food here is great. The service is inattentive and the ambiance is nothing special.  But the food is amazing, my mouth waters just thinking about it.  Totally worth going here to eat.  If you go, bring friends and order family style so you can sample many dishes.  This place is also good for take-out.
author: Amy H.

description: I had eatern Ethiopean/Eritrean food once before and declared myself not a fan. A friend persuaded me to give it one more shot at Assab. So glad I did -- it was delicious. The food was so savory and well spiced. I recommend the Mixed Chicken (Kelawa Mixed, I think is the official name). Ask for extra napkins, as it is messy, and extra injera bread as one piece won't be enough. Really delicious and filling and well priced. I'll definitely be back.
author: Pidge M.

description: perfectly seasoned vegetables, delicious sauce that causes a post-experience crave.
author: Tammy N.

description: wow!!  the flavors explode in your mouth.  you can't be hesitant about eating with your hands.  not so great for really big groups cause everyone's just fighting for food and it gets a bit messy, just shows how good the food is though.  we had to wait quite a bit for some service because we were just a group of measly college students, definitely a huge minus, but i'm willing to suffer and wait for the delicious food that comes.
author: Amanda N.

description: homey,friendly atmosphere. the owners genuinely care that you enjoy the food they serve.simple yet very flavorful dishes.( must try item: lamb dish and the lentil soup!)
author: aj s.

description: Only Eritrean food I eat in the city, period.  Lots of food for relatively little money.  They're not the most efficient, so wait times can get a little ridiculous, but they're super nice and the food's always worth it.
author: Gregorio S.

description: I love this place. I'm a vegetarian so I can't vouch for the meat dishes but I get the sampler dish that has a little of all the veggi offerings and somehow they take some of my least favorite vegetables and make them  soooo delicious. Of course eating with your hands is always a fun experience too.
author: Haven L.

description: This place has good food. The only problem with this place, is that you have to wait a while for your food to come. I had ordered take out, and it wasn't ready when I reached there. I had to wait for 20 mins or so, before it was ready. I would prefer going to New Eritrea than here. The food is comparable at both places.
author: Kuldeep T.

description: I come back to Assab every time I'm in San Francisco. Words aren't going to capture how good it is, but the dishes are hearty and spicy and just make you happy. Ask for extra napkins -- you'll need them.
author: Joshua T.

description: luv their food. a real gem. great service and prices. will definitely be back again and try out other dishes.
author: Dan P.

description: This place is delicious!  We had a party of nine because some of my friends from out of town were in the city, and the experience was great!  We ordered six entrees for all of us and I was full and happy at the end.  My favorite dish was the Alicha Beggee (Lamb), which was "mildly seasoned cubes of lamb mixed with potatoes, carrots, and bell peppers."  It was super tasty and I loved the sourdough-ish flavor of the injera (spongy flat bread stuff that you use instead of a utensil).  The other dishes that I got to try (we ordered a platter of three dishes per table, so I only got to try the ones on my side of the table) were the Kelwa Mix and the Vegetable combination.  Both were delicious.  The Kelwa was marked as being spicy, so I was a bit worried because I'm not very good at handling spicy things, but it was delicious!  It wasn't that kind of spicy where your mouth it burning so bad that you can't enjoy the rest of the meal, but it added a zing to the dish that I found really enjoyable.  One star off because my friend ordered honey wine and it never got delivered, but there was only one server so I suppose it's slightly understandable.  Oh, and the other great thing was that we ordered 6 alcoholic drinks with our entrees and the total for nine people was just under $100.  Pretty damn good for San Francisco!  Mmmm.  I'll definitely be back... I've already been fantasizing about the lamb all day and I'm looking for an excuse to go back asap!
author: Kelli M.

description: I brought a group of 7 friends + my well-behaved 4-month-old baby to Assab for my birthday dinner last weekend.  We made a reservation in advance, and although every other table in the place was packed, our table was reserved and we were seated immediately upon arrival.  As I knew from my previous dining experience at Assab, the food is delicious -- especially the chicken drumsticks.  Dishes run hot, but the friendly owner kept our water glasses full.  Family-style eating is always fun with the right group.  But what makes this a 5-star review is the friendly service to a rather boisterous bunch of friends and smiles for my baby.  I wouldn't dare to bring my baby to most restaurants in the city; you get dirty looks the moment you walk in the door with a stroller.  Since our daughter was born, we've been sticking to clearly family-friendly fare like Mel's, which means uninteresting food and atmosphere. On top of serving excellent Eritrean food, Assab is a family-owned place and we were welcomed.  Thank you, Assab, for a very happy birthday dinner!
author: Jenny G.

description: I had never had Eritrean food before but everyone loved the food. I'm personally not so sure that I like the sponge pancake that is served with the food. I would have given it 5 stars if it weren't for the mediocre service.
author: S N.

description: My friends and I went to Assab with the knowledge that it was well liked and popular.  I had never had this type of cuisine and was greatly looking forward to it.  When we got there, we gladly waited a half an hour to be seated.  Once we were seated, we ordered our food.  Well, we ended up waiting an hour for our food to come.  In that time we were waiting, NO ONE acknowledged our table.  No one checked on how we were doing.  No one offered some bread to tide us over.  No one apologized for the long wait.  I had ordered hot tea, and no one came to refill my hot water.  We were furious.  My stomach was aching because I was so hungry.  Needless to say, we ended up walking out without getting any food.  At that point, we didn't want to pay the restaurant for our experience or the food.  The service was ridiculous.  Even when we told the waitress that we were leaving, she didn't apologize.  That's just bad business.  I was very tempted to tell the table next to us being seated that they shouldn't waist their time.
author: Nani S.

description: i was completely weary when the boyfriend said "let's try some eritrean food!" uh.... what? what is this eritrean you speak of? is that like mediterranean but missing some letters? africa you say?spicey you say? oh this is going to hurt. we ventured in on a wednesday evening to find a nice, quaint place with a relaxed atmosphere and family friendly seating. i felt a bit better as i had expected the place to not be quite as nice for some reason. anyway, the menu sounded terrific and we decided on the meat combination plate and i got the spicey beef round chopped into chunks. mmm beef. ordered two glasses of honey wine as well. you have to try the honey wine. its honey with alcohol. could it get any better than that? no, i didnt think so. anyway, the meal came out and the portions were pretty huge. served family style, it made it easier for us to pick off each other's plates. i really really liked the bread... a spongey thin material that had a hint of sourdough taste. it was perfect for putting yogurt and spicey beef in. the beef was excellent and not at all chewey. if youre not used to spicey, id go heavy on the yogurt. it defintely helped to cool things down. all in all a wonderful experience. id give this place five stars, but it kinda didnt agree with my stomach. i just need to get used to spicier foods :)
author: Aly L.
